description:
Loved the food! What a display even for the vegetarian food.
I have a good appetite for non vegetarian food but was pretty full with the vegetarian dim sums, the lettuce wrap, rice cutlet and papaya salad.
The clay pot chicken was great too.
author: Japna C.

description:
Wow this is a great place. The food was exceptional, and the service made us all feel special.
Great for vegetarians too! We got a lot of vegetarian food and it was all delicious. Rice cake was tasty, as were the lettuce wraps (can you imagine lettuce wraps being tasty?)

The ambience is really quiet and nice, good for a small group or even date night. Might be on the expensive side but totally worth it for a nice evening out. I would recommend this place any day.
author: Arjan N.

description:
3 stars because it was truly an average meal. Not bad, but nothing that made me think "Ooooh this is interesting!" or "Wow so tasty".

This is a review for their brunch menu at the Bush location. It's pretty limited, and you won't see some of their classic items (like my favorite Claypot Chicken from Slanted Door/ what you can find at the Ferry Building location on weekend brunches). I suggest that if you want tastier food, you should check out the location at the Ferry Building. It's significantly less comfortable a dining location because there's only a little bar and some standing tables there, but they share a kitchen with their sister restaurant Slanted Door, which serves the same dishes at about 2-3x the price. ANYWAY,

For brunch, I came with a group and between us we got the soi man roll, spring rolls, chicken pho, beef pho, chicken congee, and banh mi. Honestly, there wasn't much else to choose from. I usually do quite enjoy rice plates, but looking at other reviews and pictures the food looked pretty dry. Table beside us ordered the rice plates and they looked dry to me. 

My beef pho was pretty flavorful. The broth was good. There wasn't much meat in it, but that was alright for me. I think the quality of the beef is pretty decent here. However, at $15 for a regular pho, I'd get it elsewhere. It was definitely passable, at-the-very-least average pho. The thing is, if not because my friends wanted to come here, I probably would not come here for pho. I got the pho because I just wasn't too enticed by the other dishes. Chicken congee is usually pretty good here, but I wasn't feeling another grain dish after the soi man roll (sticky rice). 

Soi man roll was alright, spring rolls were alright. Too much vermicelli and not enough greens for me in the spring rolls. Also, they definitely put like a bit of mayo or something on the pork, or margarine? It was a little less flavorful than mayo, but oddly greasy and creamy. I didn't really like that addition since I like my spring rolls refreshing. I mean, like Spring, right!?

Our server turned out to be very attentive and nice. But when we first entered, the staff wasn't helpful at all. Saw us standing and waiting to get seated with our reservation, but just kinda looked at us and stood at the back. I was like uhhhhhhhh... but then after a while he looked to his coworker and sloooowly sauntered over. Sloooowly sauntered to seat us at a table in the far back in the dark. Place was very empty so it wasn't like he was busy tbh. Our server however, was a different person, who was way more effective at his job and very friendly and nice.
author: Su Lin Y.

description: Had a couple of dishes. Dumplings and fried chicken were the highlights. I wasn't a fan of the shaking beef as others were
author: Laura D.

description:
Food is definitely pricey but the quality is definitely there. I would say that this is one of those places I would come with a date or special person. Customer service is spot on amazing! All the staff are so helpful and friendly! 

The pan fried shrimp chive dumpling was definitely my favorite dish, so good! And the skin was made perfect!

Definitely would come back again for a special occasion!
author: Christopher G.

description: This server named Sylvia M.  was really rude. Never coming back again.  She has a really bad attitude. This is an asian restraunt but most customers here are Caucasian. Im asian and she treated me with a very bad attitude and after that she treated other caucasians normally cuz I watched her to see if she did that to other people.  For all my asian people, don't come here cuz u will feel discriminated by her. I will tell all my friends don't come here again.
author: Nam D.

description: A very nice hidden spot right off Fillmore. This place definitely has a "Bourgy" vibe but it's a nice one and not too stuffy. It is expensive, a little too expensive for what you pay for. I came with vegan friends and they had a very comfortable time eating here.
author: Drew F.

description:
Feel kind of dumb writing this, but I don't really like Vietnamese food. It always tastes very seafood-y/fish-y to me, and I have a real seafood aversion.

Having written that, a friend recommended it, and I saw there were vegetarian options, so away we went. Boy, am I glad I did!

She started with some fresh spring rolls (they had shrimp in them so I passed, but she loved them). She then had the green papaya salad, which looked super fresh, and again, she really enjoyed; I asked them to make the grilled 5-spiced chicken with tofu instead of chicken, and they complied -- and it was delicious!

My one unfavorable comment I'd share is it was pretty expensive for lunch -- over $60 for what I described here, plus coffee and tea. So I might suggest saving it for a special occasion or for dinner. It's also very busy at lunchtime, so got a little noisy and a little difficult to hear -- again, just keep that in mind depending on the type of gathering you're having.

The folks who worked there were all super nice and helpful -- really appreciated them all!
author: Elizabeth S.

description:
This place was always a bookmark on my yelp page so finally I had time to check it out. 

Well to my dismay it was a huge miss. For one it was a tad hard to find because there's no huge sign denoting the restaurant.  Only if you walk by can you see the small menus on the windows of the restaurant. Upon entering the vicinity you can visually see that it is spacious and very modern. The decor is pleasing to the eye, but the servers on the other hand killed that ambience for me. I was going to dine in, but it took the front so long to just acknowledge me and to just let me know that there will be a small wait that when she approach me I just asked for the to-go service. She pointed to the bar and said I could order there. 

Upon encountering the bar I grabbed a seat and waited a bit for a menu or for the servers/bartenders to ask for what I wanted. 10 minutes in and no help. I can understand the idea that you are busy, but it doesn't hurt to let a customer know that you would be right with them. 

The bartender finally came over and handed me a menu quickly and tended to other customers. At least I received a menu. I waited about another five to ten minutes, but it seemed like a life time, to get my order taken. I order a simple dish and iced coffee. 

The order time took about another 20-25 minutes because I finished an episode of Friends while waiting. 

I took the food to work, which is across the street, and delved right into it.

For the price I paid it was just average. There are better Vietnamese restaurants in the city that have better pricing and service. Don't waste your time here. I wouldn't recommend this place.
author: Daw M.

description:
My friend brought me here when I went to visit her in San Francisco a few weeks ago. It's near the Filmore District that has a lot of nice shops and some nice restaurants that you can walk to. You kind of have to know where this places is to find it or you will miss it. It is across from Walgreens, which help, but there is no sign on the door. It just says OTD.

On the food, we ordered lemongrass chicken, crispy imperial rolls, grilled pork with spicy sauce, and jicama and grapefruit salad. Everything came out great. We started with the imperial rolls, which I wish there was more of because they were so good. They came out hot and crisp. The sauce was sweet and bit tangy. The grilled pork was my favorite thing. I love anything with a fried egg, and the spicy sauce was amazing. I wish the pork was sauteed and in it and then had more served on the side, but the next time I go, I'll just ask for extra. The grapefruit salad was light and refreshing and I also enjoyed the chicken. The lemongrass gave it a nice taste and it wasn't overwhelmed by the the sauce.

I love tea as well, and I really liked the green tea that I got as well as the presentation. My friends got the vietnamese coffee. It looked great, but was entirely too sweet for me. 

Service was quick and they got the food out to us quickly. If I was by myself I would probably sit at the bar to have a view of the kitchen.

I'll be back when I'm town. Hopefully my favorites will still be on the menu.
author: Alanna T.

description:
A solid 4 stars for a classy neighborhood staple.

If you prefer to have the world-class experience of The Slanted Door without the wait and touristy vibe, this place is a great alternative. They serve all the hits from the Slanted Door menu and everything is prepared, plated, and tastes exactly the same.

We had a reservation for 4 of us around 6:30 on a weekday and were seated right on time. There was still plenty of space at the bar area both when we arrived and when we left, so smaller groups could definitely get by without a reservation if you go early.

There's an excellent wine and cocktail list. Our table had 1 bottle of Donkey and Goat "Twinkle" Mourvèdre (exactly what this means, I don't know, but it was local, fantastic and slightly effervescent) which paired pretty well with the dishes we ordered.

Between 4 of us we shared the imperial rolls, dungeness crab noodles, jicama and grapefruit salad, roasted vegetables and fried chicken. The portions were enough for everyone to get a taste, but we weren't completely full. This is definitely a restaurant you come to for the seasonal flavors and pairings, rather than the portions. Even so, for the price, a bit more food on the plate would be nice. The imperial rolls and dungeness crab are completely worth it though. I've visited multiple locations and order both dishes every time. 

I also prefer this location over the Ferry Building because of the staff. The staff here are friendlier (probably because they are less rushed) and very helpful with navigating food allergies. I am allergic to wheat so they were able to modify dishes to be gluten free no problem. The restaurant is small, but feels cozy rather than cramped. This is a great option for a date night or take out for neighborhood locals. Will be back for more soon!
author: Kathryn P.

description: Get here before lunch or right after because it will be crowded. But it's well worth the wait. The food was delicious and the service is great. I highly recommend this spot if you're in the city.
author: Kevin G.

description: Got the spring rolls and chicken bun...good stuff.
author: Sunil R.

description: Upscale vietnamese restaurant. The place is very clean and has a friendly atmosphere. It almost feels like I'm eating at a friends house and I am being taken care of every single second.
author: Paelo M.

description:
The customer service is professional and food is always consistent.  Papaya salad and short ribs are my go to s.
It can get a bit noisy however if you are there to enjoy a great Vietnamese food this place is great.   Not big on the desert s.
author: David W.

description: Every time Out the Door comes to mind, the dunegeness crab noodles are my first thought. I'm obsessed with this dish. If you go there, you must try it. I enjoy family style here, so we can each try each other's food although I will probably devour an unfair portion of my favorite dish, so I'll take this opportunity to apologize ahead of time to my friends for such incidents (maybe we should order multiple of my fav dishes going forward) Last time I was there with a friend, and we also shared the I jicama grapefruit salad and Mary's organic clay pot chicken, along with a bottle of Cava. As always, the service is good. I would say if you get there at a busy time without a reservation, you'll be waiting a long time, so if you don't have time, try it off hours/days or make a reservation.
author: Danielle S.

description: I just love love love all the flavors happening here. This is the little sister to the Slanted Door over on the Embarcadero but this one still is a stand out. What's nice is it's a bit more casual than the other one so you can come and get the same really amazing flavors but just in a more laid back setting. Love the buns, the noodles, the meats, everything is super flavorful and rocks that palette! Mmmmmmmm.
author: Alicia C.

description: Not a great experience and did not stay for dinner.  The friend I was with had been there for lunch and loved it, so suggested for dinner.  Not impressed.  We did not have a dinner reservation and it was a Friday night, so yes, that's our fault, but hostess was so rude and unwelcoming, that we should of walked out then.  Instead, after hearing her rambling on about how booked they were, she led us to the counter overlooking the kitchen.  That was the best seat in the house if you ask me, however the place is small, over crowded and lots of diners with screaming kids.  AND i know it's SFO, but the prices were outrageous, and I am from NYC, so usually much doesn't surprise me - and for the serving size, forget. Oh, and smallest wine pour on the planet.  Maybe 3.5 ounces for $13.00 glass - we decided to start with two appetizers - the shrimp dumplings and the imperial rolls - literally both were to delivered to our table within 7 minutes - didn't even have a bite in our mouth when the waitress came over and wanted to take our dinner order.  We told her were would like to get through our appetizers first, and our small wine pour, before ordering dinner.  That apparently did not sit well with her because five minutes later she was breathing down our necks. That's when I decided I did not want to spend another minute in this place or anymore money I had to on bad service, okay food and being way over charged.  Once we told her we would not be staying for dinner, she rushed over the check and stormed off.  Such a horrible experience - never going back.
author: Lauren A P.

description:
Came here on a Saturday afternoon and was seated the "chef's table." This meant that I had a view of the food being prepared and that was a great experience. The people behind the counter really knew what they were doing!

The brunch menu was fantastic. I personally ordered the chicken pho, and while I don't usually have chicken in my pho, I really enjoyed the dish - it was spectacular. A friend of mine got the wonton soup, and she said it tasted "mom's soup from back in the day." The atmosphere was great, the noise level was fine and the staff was quick and easy to work with.

I would like to come back here for lunch or dinner - I really enjoyed the food and everything was not too horribly priced either.
author: Waleed S.

description: I love this place!  It's close to my home in San Francisco.  The menu over many options for me, as a vegan, and the food is to die for!  The people are courteous and the place is immaculate.  Highly recommend!
author: Elizabeth G.

description:
Bad service: server was obviously not interested in serving us, fake smile and doesn't feel like we are welcomed. Didn't check on us or how everything was until she had to clear some empty plates. Kept talking with other servers/host. It was not busy at all, but service was like mcdonald's. 

Food was okay: The dumplings dish was nice. But the squid vermicelli noodles was waaaaaaay salty. Dish serving size was too small. Not worth the price for both taste and serving.

Ambience was great: I loves the decorations and open kitchen style of the restaurant. Good vibes killed by awful service! 

Not coming back here and will never recommend!
author: Karl L.

description:
My first time here at Out of The Door is alright.  It's like a step down from the Slanted Door Restaurant.  I like the high ceiling and open kitchen area.  The place is clean and looks modernized.   Wine selection is great.  The service is amazing!  The dishes are quite traditionally flavorful and savory!  The chicken noodle soup is not the best here so I won't return for it again.   I like my pho ga (chicken noodle) with lots of broth but was charged extra when asked.   Hmmmm. Once added the bean sprouts, my bowl of soup was disappointing cold. This is not a true Vietnamese restaurant if charging extra for a tiny bowl of broth!  Haha....  the egg rolls were very yummy and the pork/ vegetables buns were very yummy.   

I'm very picky with nuoc man (fish Sauce), which was used on the papaya and jicama salads but I must admit that it was very yummy!

The portion was super small so order lots of dishes or don't expect a happy belly after!    Haha.  One more thing, make reservations so you won't won't have to wait long to be seated.  

Parking is terrible around here...  probably won't come back.  There are many other great Vietnamese restaurants in the city.
author: Ivory B.

description:
I came here for a special birthday dinner with the love of my life.  My intention was to make it the best birthday for him even though I didn't have much time to make plans.  I called to make a reservation and the lady on the phone was pretty short.  I explained to her that it was a special celebration and as much as I tried to explain the situation, it felt like she didn't want to listen or was too busy to help me out.  I think I remember some fuss about not being able to guarantee the reservation.  I asked her about the menu and seemed like she was pre-occupied.  When we got there, we were seated at the bar.  I asked to see if we could be seated at a normal table if one comes up, though their attitude wasn't very warm - even though I told them that it was a special occasion.  

We ordered an appetizer and two mains.  The food was ok, though not absolutely amazing.  It was standard Vietnamese food, though pricey because of the ambience, decor and atmosphere.  They were dishes that we would likely be able to make ourselves at home.  As it was his birthday, I tried my best to make the best out of the situation.  We watched our food being made at the bar which was nice and entertaining.  They were able to coordinate a piece of cake with a birthday candle and I was grateful that they were able to do something to make my love's day.  

Service was good, though I would really recommend improving the front of house service!  First impressions are massively important and I googled this place as a recommendation from their sister company.  Will likely go to another place for a special occasion next time.  I came here over a year ago and was skeptical about writing this review, though I know that it will surely benefit others in the future.  I was saving up for a special occasion for a loved one and I am sure others can relate how this feels like living in SF and the service def. didn't live up to our expectations.  Trust that you will improve for the future!
author: Carolyn L.

description: Have been to their ferry building location before; this one is much more formal in a good way. Food and service were very good. Everything is served family style. The dumplings and crab noodles were our favorites
author: Evan M.

description:
I was a bit hesitant to come back to OTD after my last experience many years ago. I remember the food being fine, but very pricey for what you would get. This time around was different, it was legit Vietnamese with a California twist. 

The lunchtime rush here can get pretty packed and I think you need a reservation most days, so make one. I didn't know that but our walk in was welcomed and space was made. We decided to split the spring rolls as a starter and it was a good decision. Fresh, clean and bright with a solid peanut sauce made me want to order another round. For my lunch I ordered a bowl of piping hot pho ga. I have a fair amount of experience with pho ga as it's my go to order and I gotta say, this one was super clean. More onion than most authentic Vietnamese spots but, enjoyable none the less. 

All in all, it's a solid lunch spot. Yes, it's still a bit pricey but no complaints here.
author: Benjamin F.

description:
I visited Out the Door when was in town, so we got to ball out and order a bunch of stuff.--Much more than I would have ever ordered if the bill was on me! 

Starters: 

Gau Choy Shrimp Dumplings--These dumplings comes in orders of three ,and they're quite substantial filled with lots of mini shrimp. One per person is enough, and the flavor was good + sauce was divine. (I'm all about the sauces!)  

Hue bean Dumpling--Surprisingly, I liked this better than the shrimp dumpling, and trust me, I am NOT a veggie/vegan person normally. The dumplings were bite-sized (in comparison to the shrimp dumplings which were the size of a coaster) but came in orders of 6. They had a very nice sweet, starchy flavor to them that went well with the salt of the sauce they were dipped in. 

Rolls: 

Crispy Imperial Roll--In my opinion, this is a MUST-get. Everything about this roll is right in terms of texture and flavor. The fried roll complimented by the crunchy peanuts complimented by the lettuce. All is right in the world with this roll. 

Soup: 

Dungeness Crab + Corn Soup. I know you may not want to spend your calories here filling up on soup, but the broth was amazing and the sweetness of the corn went well with the sweetness of the crab. If you're into soup, you will not regret the decision to get this. 

Mains: 

Dungeness Crab Noodles--This was my favorite dish in terms of flavor. It's power-packed with all things good and they give you a hearty helping of crab meat. 

Chicken Clay Pot--The clay pot is where it's at. The only complaint at the table was that this was dark-meat chicken and not white-meat chicken. I loved it, and wanted to basically lick up every part of the caramel sauce. Would highly suggest getting a side of rice for maximum sauce-sopping. 

Vegetables: 

Corn Dish--LOVED everything they served with corn. It was very sweet, perfectly cooked, and I wanted to eat it with everything. 

Overall the service was amazing. Our server was friendly, fast, and accommodating of the fact that my boss had a flight, and we had to get in and out of the restaurant in under an hour. 

If you're in the neighborhood, OTD is a must-stop for great food and great service for a reasonable price. (... Well... the San Francisco version of "reasonably-priced" at least!)
author: Liz S.

description:
Finally got to stop by and actually eat in. I normally just order the steamed buns to go because they are so good. The chicken bun is savory and juicy and the pork bun is sweet and savory. Today, we ordered the crispy imperial rolls, porridge, wonton soup, steamed buns, green papaya salad and chicken pho. 

My favorite item is definitely the crispy imperial rolls--finally a place that gives you plenty of lettuce to wrap the rolls instead of just treating it as garnish. The rice paper wrap was nice and crispy, thin enough to bite through easily without being chewy at all. The fish sauce was also great with it, not too fishy at all. 

The broth for the chicken pho was fantastic-flavorful and clean. The meat was tender and didn't taste boiled and dry. My 4 year old loved it. 

The papaya salad was good, I liked the crispiness of shallots on top of the salad. I guess I was expecting something a little spicier like the ones at a Thai restaurant, but this was good too. 

Our friends ordered the porridge and wonton soup and I think they enjoyed their dishes as well.

Service was friendly and the restaurant was bustling during lunch time--make a reservation if you can. We didn't have a reservation so we were seated at the communal counter height tables with bar stools. This was fine, a little difficult for dining with a 4 year old but we managed. Overall, great experience. We will most like be back!
author: Susan K.

description: An upscale place to eat a PHO!! really nice enviroment provide bright inside feeling and the food absolutely delicious. Recommend to make a reservation before you go, especially during weekend.
author: Faye L.

description: Great spot to pop by for lunch or dinner. Dishes are upscale Vietnamese favorites such as pho, vermicelli, and rice plates, all of which are excellent! I personally prefer mom and pop Vietnamese restaurants, but Out the Door surpasses in service and quality where smaller Vietnamese restaurants are lacking.
author: Monica M.

description: Downhill alert....actually it's probably been downhill for a while.  I hadn't been here in years, and noticed that tables are usually available.  I live three blocks away, so I wish OTD were still good.  The benches are still cold metal and uncomfortable, the prices still high and the menu is unchanged -- but not one dish was special.  I suspect it will go out of business soon and hopefully be replaced by something as good as OTD used to be.
author: Robin W.

description: Just as good as the slanted door and much less touristy. Great wine selections by the glass.
author: miss v.

description: Out the Door is a modern and trendy restaurant right off of Fillmore street. Keep your eyes peeled when looking for this Vietnamese restaurant because there is a lack of signage on the exterior of the building. The vegetarian spring rolls are an excellent light appetizer and the smooth peanut sauce that is served with them, elevates the taste. The chicken pho was basic but authentic and filling. Finally, the dungeness crab with cellophane noodles had a rich taste of garlic and a hint of sesame oil. The service was good and the wait time was minimal on a Thursday afternoon.
author: Meredith R.

description: Good. Expensive.  Are there better, cheaper places? Yes. Is it worth the price? No.  You may ask, 'Where should I go?'. 'Yummy Yummy,' she said.
author: Sondra H.

description: The open air kitchen is pretty cool. The food was okay..... nothing special. The fresh spring rolls looked very good as well as the sauteed boc choy and the spinach. The sauteed prawns were drenched in sauce..more Chinese style than Vietnamese. The restaurant is worth trying...keep your expectations low and hopefully your expectations will be exceeded.
author: David S.

description: Four words: GLUTEN FREE IMPERIAL ROLLS. I haven't had a real imperial roll since I was diagnosed with celiac like ten years ago so this place is a gem for me. Their pho is okay (I like dirty TL places better), the spring rolls also okay (they have both shrimp and pork in them together which isn't my jam), and their salads are solid. Really, I only have eyes for the imperial rolls. Make a reservation cuz it gets super busy.
author: Lindsay W.

description: I loved the food and it was so kind of the place to divide one bowl to two separate bowls for me and my friend! The food was great too. But my friend didn't like the food much so that's a minus.. And if you're lookin for authentic Vietnamese food not this place! Little bit Americanized I think. I still liked it though.
author: Hyun Ji O.

description:
I hate to update my review, but this used to be my go-to brunch spot...
Hadn't been for a while and upon revisiting lots had changed.
Menu was boring...just regular vietnamese food and nothing fun like it had before which was more of a fusion of food and cuisines and much more experimental.
Service was pretty bad....the host was just under so much pressure and couldnt handle the busy brunch period.
Food was still good, but it was just regular vietnamese and nothing to write home about anymore.
author: E B.

description: Another new stop in my neighbourhood that is absolutely in the rotation for the foreseeable future.  OTD is not too much different from the Slanted Door in the Ferry Building.  While the restaurant is quite a bit smaller, this staff doesn't miss a beat, the kitchen seems to be firing on all cylinders, and the dining experience rivals the FB location.  Highly recommending the Mary's organic chicken clay pot for $20 and the vegetarian spring rolls in both locations, are automatic.
author: Vince C.

description: Out the Door has two restrooms, which is nice. They both seem pretty clean. Nothing too fancy.
author: Rest R.

description:
In the words of OutKast, this place is so fresh and so clean (clean). It hands down has the most repeat value of any I've been to thus far since moving to San Francisco, I'm back almost every week!

Things I like:
- Clean, flavorful food -- it makes my tastebuds happy without that "oof...so gross" feeling you get after eating out
- Spacious interior -- you can talk here without screaming
- Good price point!

Could be better:
- Timing: the food takes its time coming out, so this isn't the place to come if you're in any kind of a rush

Dish recs:
- Green papaya salad
- Grapefruit & jicama salad
- Crispy imperial rolls (they have a vegetarian version I like)
- Beignets & vietnamese coffee (FYI they only have beignets for weekend brunch)
author: Neha S.

description: Been eating here since it opened. I have remained a fan. Stopped in for lunch today with cloudy skies and an after storm vibe of the day. The beef pho was the clear choice. It was simply delicious. Tasty, fresh, clean and lean. I think it's among the best.
author: Harris T.

description: I would not suggest ordering the shaken beef. An hour after leaving there I was throwing up that night and still sick the whole day after which ruined my trip to San Francisco. The meat was red from the inside but the server said the lime juice would finish "cooking" it so I figured it would make it safe to eat... I was wrong. The server was really nice but after that experience I wish I hadn't found this place on yelp.
author: Daisy P.

description: OTD never fails to live up to expectations. The menu has been revamped since Executive Chef Robert Edwards has come onboard. The vegetarian dishes are a third of the menu and really expand the options. The spring rolls are some of the best you will have in the country. Our squad is partial to the cellophane noodles with crab and the shaking beef. Mix in a side of kale or a seasonal veggie dish and you are sure to have a meal to remember. Daniel runs the front of the house and leads by example. From the servers to the bus staff every aspect of services is excellent. It's a neighborhood gem where everyone is made to feel welcome.
author: Ben V.

description:
Located in the lower pacific heights area. This place is so cute and hip. You walk in and your greeted by a very energetic gent while the sweet grooves of "boogie nights" serenades your ear drums. The decor is cute, upscale architecture art and succulents. The food is beautifully displayed and delectable! 

This was my second visit to OTD and I was actually even more impressed this time, than the first time. While my coworker Jia order a tasty beef Saigon Pho (southern style) garnished with Thai basil, mint, bean sprouts, and jalapeños; I enjoyed a delicious papaya salad topped with tofu and fried onions (different, and I like it!) Each ingredient of this delicious dish complimented one another quite well and by the time I was finished, I wished I had ordered a double!
I didn't try Jia's pho, but I could see the broth was very clean. Although Jia said she wished the beef cut was a bit thinner, she said the pho was very tasty and the beef was good quality . 

Portions are small, prices are a bit higher than I would usually dine for lunch. Total damage for 
Papaya salad, and Beef pho was $30. 

Now, remember I mentioned that I was more impressed THIS visit, than my last... During my first visit, the food seemed to take forever to come out and the service was not the best. I figured it may have been because the restaurant was very busy that day. But today was just as busy. Food came out within minutes (less than 10) and the service was exceptional, and Jia and I were OTD (out the door). 

We did have 2 servers and I unfortunately did not catch either of their names, but overall I had a lovely experience this time around. Food was great both visits!
author: LaToyia G.

description:
I think 3 stars is accurate for Out the Door. If you're looking for decent Vietnamese food around Financial District, this is your place. It's not amazing, but it's also not going to ruin your appetite.

I ordered the 5 Spice Chicken Vermicelli. The name "5 spices" makes it sound like it will be super flavorful, but it was not at all. It was your typical vermicelli bowl with fish sauce and there was really nothing to be super excited about. The portions were good enough to keep me full for about 1-2 hours. I also ordered the spring rolls which are just standard. No excitement there either.
author: Christine L.

description: Good spot in San Francisco with great service. Food is tasty and authentic. They offer some yummy sparkling water. We ordered the signature appetizer dish with the egg rolls. It was delicious, as expected with a crispy shell. We were a group of 4 adults and 1 child. Reservations are a must but they do accommodate walk-ins at the community table or bar. We tried some noodle soups, pork buns, porridge, wonton soups and papaya salad. Everything was great. A higher end experience. The best part was the coat and purse hooks underneath the table. Overall a quaint San Francisco eatery with a little sparkle.
author: Lila L.

description:
Over the years I've been to OTD at least a dozen times, but I am done with this place. The quality has gone down, the portions have gotten smaller, and the prices have gotten too high.

This past visit was the final straw. My $15 banh mi had two small strips of pork and barely any vegetables. I could go anywhere for a better sandwich for 1/3 to 1/2 the price. The $12 imperial rolls were so so. For three people at lunch with tax and the total was nearly $80. Not doing it again.
author: Rob H.

description:
If Slanted Door was the expensive penthouse that had a broken toilet, unmade beds, and no TV, Out the Door had the same crappy things that were wrong with a hotel room AND it was a regular hotel room not facing the ocean. Being sister restaurants, their menus featured a lot of the same style of Vietnamese fusion food. Both restaurants are too expensive for just A-OK food.

Located inside the Ferry Building, Out the Door has four counter seats right next to the cashiers. They also have a standing table on the side, but most people just take their food to go.

- Chicken Claypot Special ($13.50): cubed chicken cooked in claypot with caramel sauce, fresh thai chili and ginger. This dish didn't taste much like all the other claypot dishes I've had in other restaurants. The chicken and sauce tasted just like chicken pan cooked with some sauce. (Nothing too special here!)
- Beef Noodle Soup ($12): pretty typical Vietnamese pho, but with wide noodles. Although they don't skimp on the noodles, the noodles were definitely a bit overcooked. The broth wasn't too flavorful, so I had to keep adding hoisin sauce with each bite.

Two mediocre dishes for ~$28 made me cringe and die a little inside, but hey, this is my punishment for dining at the Ferry Building!
author: Christine S.

description: I ordered take out from OTD last thursday, the 8th. While the food was good, when I double-checked my bill, I was surprised and disappointed to find that five out of the seven items I purchased were at a higher price than what was shown on the website. It amounted to $12 more on what should have been a $99 bill. I called OTD and they said they were going to comp me, but that was three days ago and nothing has happened. Having also been to Slanted Door, which has related ownership, both restaurants charge aggressively. So read your bill and be aware. If they treat their ingredients the way they treat their pricing, the food will not be as good as it once was.
author: Tom P.

description:
Went to lunch here the day before 4th of July with my cousin.  There weren't many options for lunch in the area that were open and seemed attractive.  We just decided on Out the Door.  I saw the mixed reviews but figured since I enjoyed Slanted Door that it may be a good option.

It was bustling but we were able to get counter seating.  Do get the imperial rolls and banh xeo (rice crepe pancake).  Both are a little greasy at they are fried, but both are crisp and filling and filled with veggies and pork.  The wonton noodles' broth was clean and I liked the cracklings, however the noodles weren't cooked long enough and the wontons were just standard.  The chicken jook was a little on the thinner side for my liking and we both agreed that it was very bland. 

I would say it's a generous 3 stars.  Asian fusion/upscale Asian is done better elsewhere, but you can't go wrong with the appetizers here!  Perhaps we ordered the wrong things.
author: Cat C.

description: Astonishingly good, even the take-away food. My favorites are the Spring Roll, Vegetarian Spring Roll, Chicken Claypot, and all-time favorite:  Shaking Beef.  Just amazingly delicious.  Oh -- and the Star(?) Spinach?  DELICIOUS!!!
author: Saskia Fiona S.

description: Slanted Door on the "cheap." Came here for brunch and was not disappointed (even though most of the mains are basically the regular dishes with an egg added).
author: B. Y.

description:
I don't often give 5 stars but the food and service at Out The Door has blown me away twice now!

Food: You can't go wrong at this little sister to the Slanted Door. Obviously everything is cooked perfectly and seasoned beautifully. The wine list is strong and the servers are very well versed in wine pairings. 

Service: Here is where they really shined. I've been twice and had two great experiences...

1st time: Some friends and I had made a reservation for a birthday, and we arrived to find that Out The Door has messed up our reservation and didn't have a table for us. The manager was waiting for us when we arrived, extremely apologetic, sat us at the (not at all shabby) bar, comped our entire meal, and gave us a free bottle of champagne. That is seriously good service. They made customers for life! 

2nd time: Even though our whole party wasn't there, they seated us immediately because our elderly grandma was with us. Our server was extremely patient as our large family group bickered over the order, made modifications to everything, and asking a million questions (oof!). And as we were leaving, the host asked us how our service had been. 

I have major heart-eye-emojis for Out The Door!
author: Paloma N.

description: There is no shortage of tasty and affordable Vietnamese restaurants in the city. Out the Door is tasty, but to some may seem overpriced. However, I come here exclusively for their beef and chicken pho because it's delicious, they use really good ingredients and most importantly no MSG. I also love their salads and stir fry veggies.
author: Robbie R.

description:
Out the Door is good, but it has a dirty little secret: It's less than authentic Vietnamese food being served to the Yuppies who are happy to pay top dollar for an upgraded dining experience. 

The Imperial rolls and spring rolls are bomb. Actually, everything is pretty great -- even the host and bar tenders were great! I just work and live in some neighborhoods where I can get 3x the quality at 1/3 the price. I bet if you were to venture into the Sunset (as most pac heights people are afraid to do) you can find a sick Vietnamese spot and have a super authentic experience at a third of the price. 

Imperial rolls - good. Lean on the shrimpy side. Would like to see more pork, bean sprouts, cilantro. Why the mint? 

Spring rolls - maybe the best I've had. Really nice portion for $10. Awesome peanut sauce.

Shrimp soup - Pass, flavorless. Its basically corn, chicken stock, shrimp, and a little herbs. Not worth it. The shrimp were beautifully cooked though.

Louisiana shrimp with onions - Shrimp were medium sized but tough. Had that classic rich soy + onion taste but with less salt - decent.

2 apps, 1/2 bottle of 1, 1 soup, 1 entree, 1 side rice = $81.

If you're white, you want some spring rolls, and you're basic-- come here. If you have a breadth of knowledge or a taste for authentic Vietnamese -- avoid.
author: Peter T.

description:
I like this place. The food here is good, my friend ordered the five spice chicken vermicelli noodles while I got the beef pho. We also ordered the imperial rolls for appetizer. As for the service, when we arrived the hostess didn't come to check on us, the guy behind us actually got really mad and stormed up to tell her to seat everyone lol. 

My friend really enjoyed her dish. She had told me it was very flavorful and she liked that it wasn't dry. 

The imperial rolls were perfect!! I just wish they gave us more pieces of the rolls. I really enjoyed it, it was super crunchy which I love!!! 

The beef pho was good. It's like any Pho Tai, but I notice the portion itself was small. They gave a lot of slices of beef, and the only thing I'd complain was that the broth wasn't hot enough to cook the beef. I was eating my beef pinkish and it was super chewy :( 

I'd come back here for dinner. I really wanna try their dinner menu! It looks amazing.
author: cadence p.

description: I love the chicken porridge with lots of ginger!!! Order to go and stock it in the freezer  just heat it for dinner.
author: Florinda R.

description: We wandered into this place on a neighborhood stroll and found a seat at the end of a shared table. The host immediately made us feel welcome with his friendly vibe and witty humor. Our server took great care of us. We liked the unique selection of wines by the glass and enjoyed trying some Austrian wine. The claypot chicken (apparently a signature from their parent restaurant - Slanted Door) is one of those "last meal" kind of dishes. It is stunningly delicious. If we lived in San Francisco, we would have to eat here on a regular basis.
author: Tyler B.

description: Love the shaking beef, jicama and grapefruit salad, iced tea. Sound a bit loud, sometimes they don't answer their phone during normal business hours when you call to make a rezzie. Solid recommendation.
author: Ottis M.

description: I've lived nearby for a while but never got the chance to go. I was recently walking by and decided to stop in for a snack. I had the fresh veggie spring rolls, which were good sized and tasted incredible! In addition i was pleased to see so many vegetarian options on the menu. Finally, the staff members I interacted with were very friendly and even made it a point to pronounce my name correctly. I will definitely be back to enjoy a full meal here and look forward to trying the other items which I'm sure will taste just as amazing!
author: Kesav R.

description: I ordered the brunch and it was good. One time I ordered their dinner and the chicken was too salty..
author: Julie L.

description:
If you are seeking pho, turn back now.

This place is a Vietnamese restaurant but you actually won't find comfort foods like pho and banh mi. This seems more of an upscale dining establishment. 

I came here with some friends and we shared all the dishes. Overall, I was pleased with the food even though this is not normally what I eat when I think of Vietnamese food.

Here's what we ate: 

-Mung bean dumplings: We were all disappointed by the filling since it was just so unsettling, but we really liked the simple soy sauce mixture that came with the dumplings.

-Fried chicken: It was literally fried chicken. It didn't really strike me as Vietnamese but the chicken was juicy and the skin was delicious. A good dish, overall.

-Chicken clay pot: this was yummy. It's a simply soy sauce with some sugar and maybe a few other spices. It tasted really Chinese, actually. This dish obviously goes well with rice.

-Spicy broccoli: just okay, tasted like steamed broccoli with a little bit of chili flakes and not much else.

Service was fine. Our waiter was pretty cordial about recommendations and service.

Overall, the meal was tasty. I really liked the chicken claypot the best. I probably wouldn't go out of my way to go here (I don't live in SF) but if I were in the area, yes I'd stop by.
author: Danielle C.

description:
Love the marble tables and open kitchen. 
Really good food, but comes at a $$$ cost. Expect to pay $10 for even just appetizers.
author: M S.

description:
Ordered 2 rice porridge. Over $20 with tax. After seeing what appears to be medium sized takeout bowls, I was looking forward to enjoying rice porridge in this cold day. However, upon arriving home, big disappointment greeted me when I opened the containers. They were filled less than 1/3 of the way. More air than porridge. Needless to say, in order to satisfy my hunger, I had to go to the nearest dim sum restaurant for more porridge. $6 at the dim sum with identifiable pieces of chicken meat and ginger and 10 times the amount. Rice must be in short supply on Bush Street. 

Too bad, second time I've been disappointed at this restaurant in a period of 3 months.
author: Ben O.

description:
Living in San Jose there is no shortage of Vietnamese food options. But, OTD is not just overpriced Vietnamese food for yuppies as other reviewers have stated. To compare Charles Phan's food with a cheap Pho joint is comparing durian and jackfruit. This restaurant uses top notch local ingredients and the freshness of the produce and meat is obvious. It truly reminds me of Vietnamese food that I have had in the fanciest of restaurants in Ho Chi Minh City. 

The Imperial rolls and papaya salad are to die for and the yummy tea selection is a great accompaniment to all the dishes. Pretty much everything I've tried here is super tasty. Again, the FRESHNESS  to me really sets the food here apart from the rest. What's also great for me is that my young kids love the food here. Unlike most restaurants, the menu items at OTD appeal to both parents and kids, so the little ones don't have to resort to some janky chicken tender/spaghetti kids' menu. Fresh veggies are in almost every menu item, and my kids gobble it all up because the dishes are prepared with so much flavor to appeal to even the most discerning toddler palettes. 

The ambiance is minimalist, industrial, and modern. But, the design surprisingly still gives off a cozy and homey feel. Also, this restaurant is clearly managed well because the servers are all on point, the place is very clean, and with it being busy pretty much all the time it runs like a well oiled machine. Service and ambiance goes a long way. Yes, you pay a little more for this experience versus the super authentic Pho #56 type place because all things considered, the rent in Pac Heights is higher, the servers and staff are well trained and experienced, and quality food just costs more. 

Honestly, this place is so good they don't even need a sign outside. Clearly the people in the neighborhood know it is here and appreciate its goodness. There are so many regulars that eat here daily, yes daily. You will be hard pressed to find open tables if you just walk in, so try to make a reservation before coming and enjoy Vietnamese dining in style at Out the Door.
author: Annie W.

description: Came here for Mother's Day brunch and I was already expecting it to be good because I love their sister restaurant, Slanted Door in the Ferry Building. Definitely a pricier version of your typical Vietnamese food, but this restaurant has minor tweaks that bring the "fusion" to the restaurant. Spacious and minimalistic decor with attentive servers. I had the lychee tea, but it lacked lychee flavor. We started off with the Soi Man Roll, which is very similar to the dish Com Suon (Vietnamese rice plate), but made into Banh Tet form. There was an egg inside which is not usual in the Viet dish, but it definitely brought a texture and taste I really liked. The fish sauce helps with the flavor too. Being that I like the chicken pho at Slanted Door, I opted in for pho because it never disappoints & sure enough, it didn't. The broth was super rich in flavor and plentiful noodles to leave me full. My sister had their beef with really crispy baby potatoes and egg and my mother had the 5-spice chicken with a poached egg (the fusion part) on top. The chicken had a very nice crisp to the outside and juicy chicken on the inside - chicken done right! My mother is also a fan of coconut and panna cotta so we had that for dessert. The lemon brought all the flavors together so it wouldn't be too sweet. A fan and would return :)
author: Amanda C.

description: I go to Out the Door quite frequently and I just love it! The food is quintessential and they make zero mistakes with your order.  The spring roll is the best thing to get there. It's just so good. My usual order is the spring rolls and the chicken pho. It is in a very expedient locality to walk around and explore Fillmore street. I prefer coming here for brunch mostly because their pork buns are so delicious. Before I was diagnosed with Celiac disease, I would eat them every time I went there. I definitely advise you to go to this place to anyone who is looking for good food.
author: Matias G.

description:
Dear Out the Door,

Thank you for having my friends and I over last weekend. It was Brothe's Birthday and he had the best time! Your staff were tremendous in every way. I appreciate that you went above and beyond to make sure everyone in our party was taken care of. You asked each person individually if they had food allergies. That was kind of you. 

Here's the deal, OTD: I think you're hella cute. You mean well. And you're in a posh little nook of SF. However, with that being said I believe it's important to acknowledge the weaknesses in our relationship. Though I think you're hella cute, I know you're over charging me based on your expensive outfit and sleek atmosphere. 

Why anyone would pay $36 for 6 meager, scallop sized bites of shaking beef is beyond my comprehension. I LOVE shaking beef. Yours was not up to par. It was overcooked and flavorless. It should have been tender and succulent but it just wasn't. Your spare rib appetizer also had the potential to be outstanding. But the rib meat was so tough and laborious to get off the bone I couldn't enjoy it. The sauce was scrumptious but the meat fell short. I also didn't care for your cellophane noodles. They were bland :(

I am not an idiot. I know I'm paying you almost like one would pay for an escort: for you're good looks and fast, filling appeal. That's why I keep coming back for your shrimp spring rolls and imperial rolls. They're very, very satisfying. In fact, your shrimp spring rolls are the best I've ever tasted. I was also pleased with your string beans and chicken clay pot, though the portions were über tiny. 

OTD, I really gotta give it up to your happy endings. You do know how to please people. You really got my loins burning once the desserts started bursting out. One after the other they just kept getting better and better. The ginger cookie and ice cream was unexpectedly packed with decadent, usual flavor. The moist cake with pineapple custard was phenomenal. And of course, since you are by nature a crowd pleaser, the chocolate peanut butter pie was to die for. Must haves to end the OTD experience. 

Like I said earlier, I know we can never take our relationship to the next level because you're over priced and you know how to work me. But I enter our relationship knowing that I'm mostly paying for your attractive interior and sexy happy endings than I am for REAL food.
author: Rosalyn W.

description: We eat here quite often (The Slanted Door has a low health rating so this is our preference) for brunch more than dinner. We love the wonton noodle soup, imperial rolls and steamed pork buns. At dinner we like the shaking beef. But other dishes have gone down recently, in particular because they've become inedible with salt. The ribs are probably the worst example, but the pork/rice/egg combo has changed to a salty sloppy wet mess as well. We'll keep going back but since what we like has become very limited, we won't go as often.
author: Nancy R.

description: Probably our favorite restaurant so far.  We walked in and immediately got a seat.  We ordered a few different dishes. I loved the spicy and sweet flavor to most of the dishes.  We got a chicken pot dish that I could for days.  It was a great tasting dinner for a reasonable price.
author: Anthony N.

description: Dear trim, stuck up male host with the good hair, such a bummer when I tell you my husband had a bad back and a seat with back support would be great. Despite no less than three tables being open when we walked in, we were firmly told the only available seating was at the bar stools. Fast forward one hour and two of the open tables have NOT been seated. Granted, they were four tops so perhaps the host was banking on walk-ins, but they never materialized. Bad call my friend. Service is half the battle in a good restaurant game and you failed Out The Door miserably. Good thing the food still shines (minus the flavorless broccoli raab) and the girl behind the bar was cool.
author: Elizabeth D.

description:
Vietnamese brunch? Why not!

One of my favorite weekend pastimes is to sell clothes at Crossroads in Pac Heights (it's the best location, even if it's small) and take the cash to a nearby bar/restaurant. Whatever money is made that day goes straight into my belly. 

After my most recent trip, had about $40 burning a hole in my pocket, so Out the Door we went! There was a short wait for a table, but per the usual, we sat at the bar. And with any good brunch, wine was immediately ordered. A small carafe of rose to be exact.

+1 was feeling slightly under the weather so chicken pho is just what the doctor ordered. Sitting so close to the kitchen gave us the perfect vantage point. We got to watch the staff putting together boiling hot pots in live time. Soup looked good but I wasn't sampling in fear of catching Mr. Sickey's germs.

Plus, I had my very own lemongrass pork over rice. Not a huge portion but not skimpy either. Just enough for a small appetite like mine. Kudos to the fried egg, made it feel extra brunchey.

My favorite part of the meal was probably the wine. But that's often the case, so not much surprise there. Food is good, I'd go back for lunch or a lighter dinner.
author: Abby S.

description: Terrible service. Doesn't take to go orders (only when they feel like it). Overpriced. Go elsewhere.
author: Jacob J.

description: I went to this place on a Monday night during the summer when I was out of school. I came here because Rome burgers was so packed, so we needed somewhere else! That led me here! It was really great trying somewhere different, and the food was just great! I really loved the chicken bowl,  the noodles, and the rice as they were all so tasty! This place definitely beats out other Vietnamese places out there in the city, and nowhere else might come as close! You should really check this place out if you haven't yet!
author: Asher D.

description:
Tasty food and drinks, but uneven service and not flawless.

We've been here twice as four and six people. The food is solid (especially the 5-spice chicken), and I like the green tea. They have Vietnamese coffee (cold or hot) which looks great, and some thing tastes really good. I don't like sweet coffee, especially when it is dark roasted, so it's not for me, but I like watching it drip at your own table.

The pancakes were pretty good as well. I heard great things about the beef and it looked tasty to me.

We had a poor experience being seated recently. We were waiting for around 30 minutes. It was admittedly a larger group of six, but there were several options we observed where more careful allocation of tables would have had us seated much earlier. Then, even when the table was ready it took a long time to be seated. They didn't give us a lot of updates or concern, despite our long wait.

Once we were finally seated the service was good.

I may come back, but won't be running back, and will probably avoid waiting if there is a wait.
author: Jake N.

description: I really like the layout of the restaurant, but the attractive decor doesn't offset bland pho. The imperial roll was the saving grace.
author: Huey N.

description: Always great consistent food with high quality, love the service and friendly atmosphere.  This is my go to spot for Pho in the city! Love this place!
author: David K.

description:
This WAS my favorite family special occasion go to place, it is NOT any more , mind you the food is DELICIOUS , the best and trustworthy vietnamese food (yes Iam picky as hell and have high standards. 
Went there after my son had run the SF Marathon, this was a celebratory lunch for him, put our name down with the very bitchy person, told us we could sit right after the family at the communal table left. OK  they left . Mr bitchy walked by my entire family many times without giving us eye contact and when he did it was a dirty look??  WTF? Ever heard of customer service ?? A nice waiter came by and finally told us honestly that that guy who was seating people was a complete idiot and he was new and that honestly we wouldnt get our food for an hour anyways. Needless to say, we went to a lovely Fish and chips place around the corner and the lady who seated us was delightful. I really wish that this gets to the owner of OTD, it is a great place to eat., but after my experience with the guy that took our name and the way he treated us after my sons very joyous marathon finish, as a consumer I would like speak with the manager to please dont hire a-holes, you lost a loyal customer. We came all the way from San Jose.
author: Mdr M.

description:
3.5 STARS for food
3 STARS for price/value

I was pleasantly surprised to find that Out the Door had a Fillmore location, much less crowded than Slanted Door at the Ferry Building, and nicer than the Westfield San Francisco food court location. When I walked in during prime time (Saturday around 11am), there was no line and I quickly grabbed a seat for 2 at the communal table. The brunch menu is somewhat limited, but I found several things I wanted to try. 

* 5 Spice Chicken over Rice ($15) - 4 STARS: This was the most unique fried chicken I've had. Lightly fried, packed with Vietnamese flavors. Really tasty dish, which would've been even better if there was another side.

* Chicken Porridge ($9) - 3.5 STARS: Simple, but made with a rich chicken broth. Topped with crunchy fried shallots, which made this especially delicious.

* Vietnamese Iced Coffee ($3.50) - 2 STARS: This was way too milky, and came in a small glass (pre-dripped); wish there was more coffee!

Overall, another above average brunch spot with a beautiful, clean and spacious feel. If price was no issue I would return, especially to try the biegnets!
author: Jess C.

description: Disappointing, lackluster dishes: the jicama and grapefruit salad (which I've had many times at the Slanted Door), was shockingly bad, a plate of red cabbage with three faint slivers of jicama; this was not a main ingredient, but more like a garnish, and 4 small pink grapefruit slices. The salad I've come to expect should be sparkling clean, with bright bold explosive flavors, tangy and slightly sweet, layered and complex. This salad was nothing like what I've had before. It was basically a shredded pile of red cabbage. The dressing was flat and barely covered it, the candied pecans seemed an afterthought. I ate it only because I was starving. We got the fried chicken and brussel sprouts, the chicken was excellent, terrific flavor of breading, crunchy and faintly sweet, with pickles on the side and shredded carrots. It's solely because of the fantastic chicken that I'm giving two stars. The sprouts as a side were awful; not crispy and not braised properly, they were insipid with zero flavor, and if a Vietnamese restaurant can't do flavor, it has nothing going for it. We also got the panna cotta with passion fruit gelee and coconut flakes; this was good, not great, the texture was firmer and not as creamy than what I've had at Slanted Door. Am I being unreasonable comparing it? I don't think so ... a pile of raw cabbage and mushed sprouts just doesn't cut it, especially not at these prices. The saving grace was the service, which was awesome, our server friendly, patient, and efficient. And of course, the acoustics are a nightmare for aging ears, all hard surfaces, noise bouncing off ricocheting from table to counter to walls. We got out of there as fast as we could. I don't get it: the Phan experience is something to write home about, but something was sorely off in the execution of these dishes. Because of the remarkable chicken, I know the kitchen has cred and potential, but it needs a serious tune-up, re-training, or overhaul, and someone to oversee the subtleties of each dish as it goes out, e.g. a plate of barely dressed raw cabbage with three microscopic slivers of jicama ... seriously? Not.
author: Ranjan P.

description: FOOD IS ALWAYS FOOD HERE except it's small portions and a little pricey. All in all we love it here. STAFF are always friendly an A PLUS !!!
author: PerK N.

description:
I had no idea there was an Out the Door in Lower Pac Heights. I was bummed about the closure of the one at the Westfield Shopping Centre as it was the only decent place to eat in the food court that didn't require taking a tray to a table that was never available. They had to close it because of a flooding issue, and there is now a useless Asian import store in its place, at least useless to me since I'm not in the market for a ceramic elephant flower stand. Anyway, I was taken to this location by a colleague new to the city who was thrilled with Charles Phan's operation. I remember that euphoric feeling when I went to Slanted Door for the first time two locations ago in the Mission.

In the meantime, so many like-minded upscale Vietnamese restaurants have come and gone that I have forgotten how good the food can be in the right hands. I was with two people, so I was able to share a number of dishes that would have been elusive to me otherwise. We started with two of the classic $10 rolls - the first was the Spring Rolls with shrimp, pork shoulder, and mint rolled in transparent rice paper and served with a spicy peanut sauce (photo: http://bit.ly/13Qft3Q); the other was he Crispy Imperial Rolls, deep-fried with pork, shrimp, mint, peanuts and red leaf lettuce (photo: http://bit.ly/18xlqM2). Both were expertly executed, immaculately presented and resonantly flavorful. Who am I to complain if the prices are roughly twice those to be found in the family-run holes-in-the-wall in Little Saigon?

We then shared three entrees, and while none sang out with transcendent glory, each offered certain joys. The first was the $20 Stir-Fried Louisiana Prawns with Roasted Chiles and Ginger in Caramel Sauce (photo: http://bit.ly/1dOC2Me). Yes, I wrote 'Caramel Sauce'...and the sweet-savory combo fell short in this case even though the prawns were big and fresh. The second was quite pricey for the quantity, the $36 Shaking Beef since it was made with fancy-schmancy Grass-Fed Estancia Ranch Filet Mignon and mixed with Watercress and Red Onions in a Lime Sauce (photo: http://bit.ly/14w2DOu). Of course, it was deliciously tender. It had to be as there would have been a riot otherwise. It was certainly the priciest shaking beef I've ever had. The third dish was the cheapest and ironically the most satisfying.

It was the $18 Dungeness Crab mixed with Cellophane Noodles, Garlic, Green Onion and Sesame Oil (photo: http://bit.ly/15Amusz). I basically love any noodle dish, and the unadventurous flavor match between the see-through noodles and the shards of fresh crab really worked together. Our evening was just getting going at that point, so we decided to have $2.50 Pacific Espressos (photo: http://bit.ly/12GdgsR) and share the $8 Strawberry-Pistachio Tart, which provided bitefuls of creamy sweetness to the end of our meal (photo: http://bit.ly/14w2RFn). The 2011 Giornata "Il Campo" from the Central Coast was the lovely, hearty Sangiovese red that accompanied our meal. We closed the place as the staff gathered at the community table eating housemade burritos that looked awfully good. Too bad they won't be on the menu.

FOOD - 4 stars...upscale Phan creations are tasty, keep your credit card warm
AMBIANCE - 4 stars...spacious and modern like the late, lamented Westfield place (photo: http://bit.ly/15AoMI6)
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...nice enough, not overly warm
TOTAL - 4 stars...now I have another Out the Door to go out the door for
author: Ed U.

description:
Good service and a friendly ambiance! Surprised on a Tuesday that only the community table was available when we were there right when it opened, we are community people so that was just fine. 

The halibut was perfectly cooked and very tasty with a nice salad to compliment. Tuna tartare had a bit too much soy sauce, not my favorite. 

The imperial rolls were absolutely delicious! Id definitely go back here again! :)
author: Cassedi C.

description: Best fried chicken I ever had. The sriracha sauce they serve it with is orange crack.
author: Jason G.

description:
I am very very sad to have to write this review...BUT I think it needs to be said after much thought about writing it or not.  I have been coming to this Out The Door restaurant since it opened.  It is down the street from my house and is a great place to take friends who want to try something delicious and different.  Last week I wanted to surprise my niece with a lovely dinner out for the holidays, so of course I made a reservation here.  I was so excited to take her so she could see what a great unique place this is to have dinner. 

Like I said I live in the neighborhood and have eaten here more times than I can count. I even do take out on occasion when I want to treat myself after a long day. I have always been greeted by name as I am a regular.  Last week I was more than disappointed and may not return.  Here are the bullet points:

* We were seated and waited TEN minutes to be acknowledged by the waitress
*When she arrived there was no apology so I said "Oh we are so excited. This is her first time here!" The waitress barely cracked a smile and was visibly uninterested.
*She disappeared for awhile and then finally returned.  I ordered a glass of wine and we said we need just another minute to order.  My wine came about ten minutes later again.  She had disappeared and had clearly forgotten to put in the order because as she reappeared she saw me and went over to get the wine.  We ordered the food.
* The food came and was just delicious and savory.  My niece was delighted. BUT we never saw the waitress again. SHE NEVER CAME BACK!
I was not asked if I wanted another glass of wine, never asked if the food was ok or if we needed anything else. What kind of service is that... She again had disappeared in the back.
* Then to make matters worse, when she did appear she was talking with the other staff AND THEN sat down at the bar and started eating her dinner with her back to us.

Now mind you the restaurant wasn't crowded as with all holidays in SF people head out and places are less crowded.

I was appalled by the lack of service and her blatant disrespect for the customers she was serving.  She was one of the single most rude servers I have ever encountered. As I have said Out The Door has been my FAVORITE restaurant by far and has won me over with the folks who USE to work there.  This waitress was obviously unhappy and didn't give you know what about her service. At the end I was so upset and hurt that my niece had such a horrible experience.  I told the bartender upon leaving my utter dissatisfaction of the entire experience.  She on the other had was enjoying talking to the other servers and eating her dinner. He apologized but said the manager had left and that he really wasn't in a position to do anything but he would relay the experience.  I am certain she didn't care.  For the very first time I left a small tip and was even on the verge of not leaving one at all after paying $90 on such a terrible experience.  Now mind you if she had ever came back and checked in I would have had a couple more glasses of wine and dessert.... She didn't even deliver the check to us!!

I hope that this message is heard and feedback is given.  At this point I do not plan to go back and would not recommend it to anyone which is sad. Part of dining out is the food but certainly the ambiance and service are just as important.
author: lawana s.

description:
Would be 4 if the service were better. Out the door is right up the street from our apartment and we frequent it a lot for brunch. We love Vietnamese food and the food here is very good. The spring rolls, lemongrass pork with rice, daikon cake and shredded chicken salad are our favorite dishes. My husband is Vietnamese and he also agrees that the food is good and authentic.

However, every single time we come the service is very, very poor. We never once have been greeted at the door and it takes 10-15 minutes for anyone to come to the front of the restaurant. The food comes out at different times and the all around vibe of the restaurant is disorganized and slow. It feels that they could make a few changes to how they operate to make this a much better experience. I'm always shocked that a Charles Phan restaurant would allow for such poor organization.

Hoping out the door reads these common complaints and does something to change and make the restaurant great.
author: Simone B.

description: I was pretty disappointed in the $15 banh mi it wasn't very flavorful and was really light on meat. I'm fine with small portion sizes if the food is decent but I just got the vibe that the lack of meat just came down to being stingy with ingredients. The service was really bizarre and off putting. There's these tiny cups for water which is fine except that someone comes by and refills it every time you take a sip, it started to get farcical after the 7th or 8th time in 10 minutes. The bathrooms were simultaneously occupied by employees for several minutes. Not going to waste time with this place again.
author: Justin M.

description: Overrated, overpriced Asian food made to accommodate the elitist. Horrible service if you do not look like you belong. Expect to wait 10 mins after they finished with the person ahead.
author: Angela S.

description:
Fantastic food is not enough! Although we had crunchy Imperial rolls coupled with wonderful green beans, lamb and shrimp dishes, sitting on backless bar stools for a full dinner service is a poor way to treat guests. 

Customers have a right to comfortable seating, particularly if they are planning to enjoy a full meal. The bare bones decor here was unexpectedly cold and seemed like a mismatch with a restaurant serving so many lively, spicy dishes.

Criticisms aside, we shared dishes and enjoyed quite an enjoyable taste experience. Service was just okay. The restaurant's large wood dining table with bar stool seating was positioned right up front--best for quick lunches.
  
TIP:  Skip the glass noodles. I thought they were too oily and skimpy on the crabmeat.
author: Lynn S.

description:
Upscale Vietnamese is served hot and fresh off the grill in this tucked away restaurant. Have a seat at the chef's table to watch all the ingredients blend into one sinful looking dish, or sit along the windows for some natural light. This place fills up fast, but they manage to keep it so that you can still have a conversation with your meal partner (I'd suggest no more than 4 people total).

Come here to impress someone that's only comfortable in a modern, sleek, upscale restaurant and they'll be comfortable enough to try OTD's adventurous menu.
author: Regina D.

description:
Reasonable appetizers and tasty - entrees are on the pricier side and definitely fusion rather than traditional. Highly recommend the imperial rolls, green papaya salad. The waiters are really helpful and genuinely nice. They marked out all the gluten free options.
A good selection of European wines too. The lychee infused iced tea is quite tasty too.
author: Van-Anh N.

description: Very friendly staff and welcoming atmosphere. Nice place to come with family. Loved the spring rolls, very fresh. The asparagus soup was a bit bland, but overall it was a lovely meal. The brussel sprout side dish was also very tasty - as long as you love garlic! We walked in on a Friday night without a reservation and they were able to seat us.
author: Katie J.

description:
We Loooove Out the Door...this is our Favorite spot to eat in Pac Heights. The service is fantastic...the food is Amazing and the vibe is super chill.

We love coming for brunch and dinner...everything on the menu is perfection.

They always welcome you here with open arms and warm spirit.

I wish we could give them a million starz!!
author: T Maria L.

description: I went to Out the Door with colleagues after work one day and we had an amazing lunch. Our boss placed the order and she knew what she was doing. I especially loved the pork buns, the lemongrass chicken, the broccoli and the chocolate peanut butter pie dessert. But I had multiple (albeit somewhat small) helpings of everything and often added a bit more to my plate each time. This is a great place for large groups, because you can order so many different things and share it all.
author: David B.

description:
We came here for brunch this morning and the food was pretty good! We had the spring rolls, veggie steamed buns, and I had the bavette steak with scrambled eggs. My friends had the 5 alarm chicken/rice, and the congee. All were flavorful. No complaints on the food.

Service was probably one of the worst I have ever experienced. If I have to ask for water 3 times before I get it, that's a problem. If I have to wait 25 minutes for my order to be taken, that's also a problem. Servers had complete lack of awareness and no sense of urgency. 

Hostess was completely clueless and was obviously new. We asked if the communal table was available (apparently there were no tables available, but when I looked around, there were about 4-5 tables that were empty) and she had to walk away and ask someone. She said it was reserved. When we left 2 hours later, the communal table was still empty. 

I would expect a lot more experienced servers/host staff at a restaurant located in Pac Heights.

We left less than a 10% tip. 

Love the food, not a fan of the service. I'll probably have to wait a really long time before returning, unless they can assure me that their staff has been properly trained.
author: Victoria B.

description:
fancy fancy Vietnamese food for when you're on a date and need to make sure you're seen as generous. it's a gesture, not a dinner. *sly face emoji* 

In the same vein as, unless it's seafood banquet status, Chinese food is delicious and the cost performance is excellent. 
Vietnamese food is the same. this is the low level viet hakkasan equivalent. 

$12 spring rolls that are tiny af. 

That being said, the food is decent and the wine selection is good. 

Cool wooden minimalist decor uhhh and lighting I guess......
author: Megan L.

description:
I love the restaurant interior - it's open, industrial but warm at the same time. It's busy - we got there at 1pm and there was a wait - but it goes fast.

Service is very efficient and friendly - 5 stars.

The food is fine - I love the attention to ingredients, but it was mixed execution.

5 stars: The omelette/crepe thing was delicious-  executed perfectly, the outside egg crepe was crunchy but not at all burnt. a must order.

3 star: chicken porridge. Again the chicken was generous and tasty, but the porridge was way too thick. Perhaps we arrived late and so we got the stuff at the bottom of the pot. In our porridge was also 2 huge chunks of ginger (which is fine when you are cooking it, but usually it comes out when you serve it), but I prefer the ginger finely slivered as a finishing touch. Outer Geary, Clement street do porridge way better in terms of consistency.

3.5 star: pho. It was okay. I like that good quality meat was used, but the meat was not as thin as I prefer and it was overcooked - I prefer my pho meat to be thin an almost rare. I've had much better pho in the South Bay (San Jose)

It's pricey for average fusion, Vietnamese food - the decor, the service, the location jack up the prices.
author: Madison W.

description: Really impressed by this place. Pancakes surprised me.
author: Christopher F.

description:
"I'm NOT waiting in that line!"

"Plan B?"

"OUT THE DOOR is near here."

"I did say I would try it again.  The manager handled the situation very well."

"Two? Yes, the bar is fine."

"Street parking has gone up.  It was $4 for an hour."


"Are the beignets good?"

"No."

"But I really want beignets."

"Don't you remember?  They were doughy.  Get the scone instead."

"That is a LOT of lemon curd.  Mmmmm.  You're going to lick the bowl aren't you?"

*nods*

"For the Steamed Buns you only get one?"

"Yes, but they're about this big and they are really good!"


"That is a HUGE piece of salmon.  What's the stuff on top?"

"Crème fraîche."

"Hey you remember that South Park episode with crème fraîche?"

"I showed that to you."

"You did?"

"I didn't know you liked jook."

"Sometimes, they make a good one."

"It looks kinda soupy."

"It's delicious!"


"We should sit at the bar again next time, the service is really good."

"Interesting crowd.  Upscale hipster."


"How many stars?"

"4."
author: Amy C.

description: If you like bland and over priced food, you found it! When I saw "Vietnamese" - I was sure it would be great with all the reviews. But this restaurant is the best Vietnamese restaurant for anyone who's never tried the cuisine before so you'll have nothing to compare it to. Tasteless, uncreative, and all in all disappointing. Awful experience. Never again.
author: Hanna G.

description:
On a relaxing brunch Saturday accompanied with the Blue Angels in the skies from Fleet Week, we three decided to go off the cusp and Out the Door. Started with a refreshing selection from their Crisp white wines: the Felix.

The three dishes we shared tasted excellent. In no particular order, they were the Pan Roasted Opah, the Dungeness crab w cellophane noodles, and Mary's Organic Claypot chicken with ginger. If I had to choose a favorite, it would be the Dungeness Crab, primarily for the tasty seasoned cellophane noodles.

Also shared a dessert wine: the oro puro (pure gold). What a delight! ...As was our service: efficient, knowledgeable and enjoyable to talk to.

Still to come post twilight were Upcider, The Tipsy Pig, and how to view "Gone Girl" at The Kabuki the next day. The weekend was young, my friends!
author: Garett T.

description:
Great chicken pho, steamed chicken bao, and chicken salad. The service was great, and sat us for brunch without reservations. Staff was all attentive and on the spot. They split everything (soup etc) as we needed.

Would like to go back and try the pork with looks great!
