author: Brent T.

description:
Pretty good food. We shared the prawns, scallops, and chicken clay pot. I would recommend the scallops and chicken. Need to order more rice bowls for a table of 4.

There were a couple flies around my food and I found hair in one of the dishes. 

Great wine list.

We were an annoying table and the server managed and treated us well. 

I wouldn't recommend getting any of the deserts. We tried all four and we not impressed. The peanut butter crumble was the only one worth ordering again. 

However, I did really enjoy the Vietnamese coffee. Not too sweet!
author: Hilary R.

description:
Ordered: Chicken porridge, pork bun, hot milk tea

Pork bun: Delicious! Dough was very moist and filling was very good with a good mixture of vegetables and pork. The difference was it didn't have that bright red food coloring, which is a plus. The downside was it was just one for $3!

Hot milk tea: Delicious! It came in a glass container and you pour it into a small glass tea cup. flavor of black tea was perfect....not too strong and not too weak. I like my milk teas to be not as sweet and sugary as some boba places.

Chicken porridge: Delicious! I love my porridges to be thick and not watery. Flavor was good and had a few slices of the chinese breadsticks.

Overall very good, but just a bit on the pricey side. I wouldn't mind coming here for my Friday's office lunch gatherings.
author: Marcus Y.

description: When I'm not in the mood for authentic hole in the wall Vietnamese (which is never), but I'm in the mood for "modern bouge" Vietnamese food (which is my girlfriend always), than I usually come here to OTD.  OTD is one of my favorites.  Great ambiance: modern / trendy.  My favorites: crispy imperial rolls, spring rolls, green papaya salad, dungeness crab cellophane noodles, shaking beef, and chicken claypot.  I recommend this as an overall great place for a date night, family visiting, and group of friends.  If you enjoy OTD, than you'll definitely enjoy The Slanted Door (parent restaurant, pricier) located in the Ferry Building!
author: Kevin N.

description: food is pretty good but service is too frustrating. Couldn't order last week because they refused to take my order because they were too behind on other customers and when I tried to order again today they forgot my order entirely and said I never placed it. So frustrating
author: Jenn J.

description: I am South Vietnamese and have been in United States since 1975.  The food here is not authentic Vietnamese cuisine.  Food here is Americanized bland and overpriced.
author: Michael D.

description:
Solid 3-stars. This place had a nice ambiance with tasty food, however, it was a bit pricey (enough to make me feel that I could have found similar quality elsewhere). 

We ended up getting the fried chicken, lamb, broccoli, daikon rice cakes, and papaya salad (I'm not remembering the actual names of these dishes), which were all delicious and prepared well -- nothing over or under cooked here. I simply cannot get over the price of the food as I didn't feel that there was a "wow" factor to any particular dish.

In short, this was a nice place to go, though there wasn't anything specific that makes me want to come back.
author: Brandon C.

description: Chicken porridge and wonton noodle soup are good except the egg noodle are stick together cannot bring apart, they didn't stir well or cook it thorough. Also the waitress is not so friendly, didn't not explain the menu. Expensive for the portion size. Like the open kitchen though.
author: Shin T.

description: I don't get to San Francisco as often as I should considering the amazing ethnic, especially Asian food, including Vietnamese. When I do I like to visit Out the Door in the lower Pacific Heights section, which is my favorite Vietnamese restaurant in the Bay Area. The setting is casual and friendly and so is the service.  Spring rolls are really great, both regular and vegie and in the regular you'll enjoy pork and shrimp. I love the hue dumplings and the shaking beef and the papaya salad.  Everything is good, and be sure to get dessert which includes chocolate cream/peanut butter pie, the panna cotta, and a cheese cake. Just so you don't think they forced me to write this, I do have one criticism, which is the noise level. Just a bit too noise for me. But I will just make sure I go during off hours.
author: Julia H.

description: Fresh seasonal modern vietnamese, great wines, good atmosphere, not very casual/more dressy. Love it, always incredible food and service.
author: Paris I.

description:
It's a small restaurant, you might have walked by not knowing it was a restaurant. It also doesn't have a giant sign outside either making it even harder to find. It has a very modern feel to it. Nice ambiance and during dinner there's dim lighting. They have big glass windows so during the day sunlight can shine in. Their kitchen area is open and you can sit at the bar and watch the cooks prepare the food.

Out the door is not your typical Vietnamese restaurant. It's more upscale and has an American twist to it. It's definitely pricier than your average vietnamese cuisine too. However, everything I've eaten here has had lots of flavor with good balance.

Things I've tried:

Papaya Salad- 3.5 stars. good appetizer, refreshing. wasn't too salty and sour. Papayas were fresh and crunchy. Not outstanding from your average papaya salad.

Daikon Rice Cakes- 3 stars. pretty good, tasty, your average daikon rice cakes you can get from a dim sum place. Overpriced though for what it is.

Spring Rolls- 3 stars, average vietnamese spring rolls. overpriced again.

Now Why I'm giving them 4 stars- the chicken porridge. it had great flavor very rich and the porridge wasn't super thick almost soup like. It seemed like they made it using broken rice. It's a small portion however :(. It goes great with the fried chinese donuts too. EVERYONE SHOULD AT LEAST TRY THIS ONCE!

Dungeoness Crab Cellophane noodles- 4 stars. very tasty and decent sized pieces of crab, but small portion for the size you pay

Shaking Beef- 4 stars. Very flavorful dish as well. Beef was tender and juicy with a crisp exterior.

Slow Cooked Eggs- 4 stars. Eggs were cooked perfectly. Came with a good amount of beef.

They also have a unique tea selection to choose from.

Service has always been great.

Every time I've been there has been no wait or line out the door.

Their food is tasty. I would stick to dishes you can't order from a typical vietnamese restaurant (fresh spring rolls, daikon cake, imperial rolls, vietnamese crepe, rice rolls) because they're pretty pricey and you can get the same thing for less elsewhere. And also, for the price, you don't get that big of portions either.
author: Stephanie L.

description: 2.5" WIRE IN MY PAPAYA SALAD! Went for brunch today and chewed on something that I thought was a fish bone. Horrified to find a twisted wire come out of my mouth (See photo)! After finding the source (OTD kitchen veg boiler), the manager comped my dish, which I thought was NOT the adequet resolution. Considering we were only a party of three having brunch, I was surprised the manager didn't offer to comp the whole table. Clearly, OTD does not take customer safety seriously based on their meagar response. Very disappointed at their lack of customer service and at their inappropriate reaction.
author: cassy f.

description: How in hell could this restaurant get anything less than 4 stars? I'm reading these reviews and thinking "who are these people?" I come up to SF two or three times a year, and the two things i look forward to are Sushi Ran and Out the Door. OTD is exceptional--the best southeast asian fusion i've had in SF, new york, dc, and los angeles. The dungeness noodles, the lemongrass chicken rice plate, the daikon rice cakes, the prawns, and the papaya salad are awesome. I wish i lived next door to Out the Door!
author: Scott K.

description: Phenomenal service (quick and friendly). Recommend trying 3-4 appetizers as they are very filling
author: Michelle M.

description: The sister restaurant to The Slanted Door, OTD is a cozier version located in Pac Heights. They serve trendier, almost fusion-like Vietnamese food that is decent, but leaves you wanting more. Their brunch menu has more traditional rice plates as well as more typical brunch items with an Asian flair. I had the chicken porridge, which had great flavor and a nice crispy element with the fried shallots on top. It was a good-sized bowl of homey comfort food, and ended up being my favorite dish. My boyfriend had the five spice chicken plate, which came with a pretty generous portion of grilled chicken. The flavors of the marinade melded well with the charcoal flavor of the grill and I liked the addition of the pickled veggies, but the plate as a whole was nothing special. Overall, the meal was satisfying but none of the dishes were standouts.
author: Ashley T.

description:
Don't get take out from here!!! Food is nice when dining in, if you wanna spend $70 on some appetizers, but take out was a sham. I ordered the chicken clay pot for $20 and I got boiled chicken in a sauce that's it! We ordered the veggie dumplings which were small and insignificant. Tiny! 

The worst part was when I called to complain and the man on the phone was rude and didn't apologize, even though I was being very polite and trying to explain how they could make it better for customers by explaining that their items are small and don't come with rice etc. Sorry to rant I'm just so bummed about them...
author: Alexa C.

description:
The food here is pretty good, but I just can't justify upscale Vietnamese when prices are 2x + regular prices but the food isn't 2x + better.  

I came with 3 friends on a Monday night and the crowd was on the older side 35 year old +, mostly what seemed like locals. The wine menu was on point and the prices there were great.  We ate family style and shared:

Imperial rolls- veggie
Imperial rolls - meat - nothing spectacular- LIESSSS 7x7
Mung Bean Dumplings - MEH- would not recommend- bland
Stir Fried Lamb- this was quite flavorful
Dungeness Crab noodles- yum
Brussels Sprouts- weird asian way of cooking them, very bland
Bok Choy- decent
author: Skye W.

description: My favorite restaurant in my neighborhood. Every dish that I have tried, I have loved- from the chicken, noodles, tofu, eggplant etc. The only negative is that you have to make reservations well in advance because they are always booked!!
author: Shilps S.

description: I love OTD. Super fresh and delicious, flavorful food. Great service in a posh but laid back environment. A real gem.
author: David C.

description: The way they prepare Vietnamese food is innovative and delicious. They also have a great white wine selection. The quality of the vegetarian dishes is uneven, depending on when you go. But overall, a fun spot with good service.
author: Lindsay W.

description:
My rating is based not as much on the food but on the unhelpful service after eating there.  I was in SFO on business and at the restaurant for dinner last night.  Unfortunately, I left my credit card there.   Clearly my mistake.   I didn't realize it until I had already left town.   They have a policy only releasing the credit card in person with a photo ID.  That's is admittedly reasonable if you live in SFO, but unfortunate for me.  Of course they didn't tell me that this was their policy until after I spent the time an energy to have FedEx come pick up the card to overnight it back to me.  The management was rigid and unreasonable and unfriendly  in meeting me half way.  I offered to fax my ID to FaceTime or anything to show it is my card.  Their policy is their policy.  I can accept it.  The terrible attitude is surprising and disappointing. 

Bottom line:  Food is OK.  Service and attitude is crappy and uncharacteristic of the great city of San Francisco.
author: A G.

description: Had the chicken salad yesterday and it was by far, one of the best salads I've ever had. Top 3!! It was fresh, light, and delicious!
author: Sara D.

description:
Solid vietnamese fusion food. Good atmosphere, good food, great service. Pretty large wine and beer list. 

Mung Bean Dumplings, Jicama salad with grapefruit, Claypot chicken, fried chicken, prawns were all awesome.

Bok choy and asparagus were pretty standard, pork chop was flavorful but somehow moist but dry at the same time. 

Food was solid and a good place to go with friends. If I lived nearby it would be a good standby, though it's not the type of place I'd go out of my way to visit again.
author: Adam W.

description: I love the food here at Out The Door. I have always loved Vietnamese food. It is pricey but worth the money. I hope to return there.
author: Will D.

description: We came here for dinner on a Friday and shared the papaya salad and spring roll to start, both of which were pretty good. My crab and cellophane noodle main dish was just OK--95% noodles and 5% crab got a little boring to eat after a while. The guys in my party both ordered a generous portion of the fried chicken, which looked awesome.
author: Jia H.

description:
Sunday, 7:15PM.

Quickie:
+Attentive service
+Clean
+Nice layout
+Menu selection
*Hit/miss food quality

Constructive comment:
*Source your ingredients

And then...?
Promising joint, warrants one more chance. 

**********
Stuffed my face in:

1. Grapefruit salad
     +Sweet, savory, bitter...and it works.
2. Schrimp dumpling
     - tough wrap, dry middle
3. Scallops
     - Inconsistent texture, bland
4. Chicken claypot
     +Great flavor combination
5. Corn
     +Sweet/salty/smokey flavor
author: Chuck N.

description: Been coming here for more than three years. Consistently good, from food to service. Professional staff. Always like the rolls, shaking beef is a must, papaya salad, seafood dishes. Had a salmon last night that was great. Want to possibly explode an artery? Get the peanut butter chocolate dessert. Feels like a neighborhood spot, never had to wait too long.
author: Michael S.

description:
My experience was "Meh". 

1. Food was pretty good, but not great. The rice cake and noodles stood out as the best.
2. Service was awful at first and then better after the hostess heard me joke with my dining companion that the service was bad because he is a black man (it was a JOKE... I think).
3. Price is as expected for lower pac heights. 

I think this is perhaps one of those places that was great but has just been here a while and they are not as "on it" as they used to be.
author: Kate M.

description:
I am ashamed to admit I have never been to The Slanted Door, though it has been on my list for years.  Then again, I have not been back to SF in years.  Shame on me on all counts.

So two college buddies, a great friend from my camp counselor days and I decided to go to Out The Door for a more casual Sunday lunch.  Great idea... except this was a holiday weekend and they were doing a special brunch instead of the regular menu... or maybe they do that every Sunday.  

Yes, I was disappointed, as there were many dishes I wanted to try... but sometimes you just go with it.  We went with it.  Oh boy, did we.  The four of us can eat a lot of food... and we did.  

We started with the Crispy Imperial Roll, fried and a bit heavy, but of course delicious.  Wrapping them in lettuce gave me the false impression I was being healthy.  The Spring Rolls were light and tasty and so much better than I make myself at home.  Duh.  But they have inspired me to go a step... or two further.  Speaking of which, Charles Phan's cookbook looks amazing.

The Green Papaya Salad and The Shredded Chicken Salad were both so delicious and heavenly... Yes, I just used the word heavenly to describe the salads.  The layers of flavors and textures were so interesting and worked perfectly.  I could eat either one of these on a daily basis!

The Soft Scrambled Eggs With Grilled Atlantic Salmon, Beets, Potatoes and Arugula Salad in a Mustard Vinaigrette was really good, but my least favorite of the entrees.

The Slow Cooked Eggs With Slow Smoked Coffee Rubbed Brisket was insanely delicious.  Heavy and filling, but Mmm!

A Sausage dish I do not see on the menu was sent out to us... so tasty...

And my hot Vietnamese Coffee added another kick that my under-slept body needed.

But my highlight, aside from the salads, was the Lemongrass Pork Over Rice with a Fried Egg, Pickled Veggies and Spicy Soy Sauce.  It has inspired me to try to do something like it with the lemongrass I am growing in a pot in my backyard.  

Our server was fantastic... and her recommendations were right on.  My hot Vietnamese Coffee added another kick that my under slept body needed.

Everything was perfect... and this is a good lesson to learn... be open to what is around you.  We went in wanting lunch from the regular menu but got some killer food I would not have ordered or expected.  

So will I be back?  Hell yes!  For breakfast, lunch, brunch or dinner!  And will I run to The Slanted Door on my next SF visit?  Hell yesser!
author: Marc G.

description:
Delicious dining experience!

Love the spicy lamb and the crab and glass noodles was a nice delicate balance. Spareribs were a little too fatty.

Vanilla bean cheesecake - mmm perfecto!

Will def. bring my husband back.
author: Liz F.

description: Claimed gluten-free items are glutinous. My celiac partner was down in pain for three days because of false claims made about gluten free items -- and not just a small amount due to cross-contamination, but a full on attack. Having staff make claims about gluten free items is not just an issue about being trendy to some people, and I seriously hope that some effort is made to train the staff better.
author: dan c.

description: My hungrily ordered pancakes promptly, fluffily arrived at a reasonable price and brought with them a tithing of stimulating deliciousness I had not enjoyed in a long whole. A sampling of the chicken pho yielded surprising dividends of ecstasy.
author: David S.

description:
There was no signage so I was browsing block a little bit.
Food is good for sure but service was short.
Guy over the bar counter was so blunt and at the time of dessert, he just tossed the menu and only 1 menu for me and my friend.
(Never asked if appetizer and/or food was good either)
Not sure what was spinning on this one's head that night but it made me feel "I don't care why you are here or what you have"
Maybe it was because we did not order drink or we were sitting in the bar section as table were all booked but it was still very strange feeling of not being welcomed.
And the woman who was in charge of greeting at the door started to eat in the other side of bar and I think this was not well organized restaurant operation.
I know they close at 9:30PM and it was almost 9PM so they must have not had any more reservation for the night nor not expecting any other walk-in but it just looked like boring suburban diner near highway.
Interior is very modern and has clean open kitchen and again food is good but staffs need to get more training.
I strong recommend any mood swing people should not work if you are in a restaurant business unless you can pretend you are well functioning.
When we dine out, we expect more than just bland welcome atmosphere as we are willing to pay tips but there is no reason you can take it for granted.
And lastly, there was no one who was backing up that woman who was eating gracefully in the bar and no one who said good night or thank you when me and my friend were heading out.
OTD owner, I know you can make it better.
Please do so!
author: Scott Y.

description: Overpriced, pretty slow service, OK food. Came here for brunch, got the soi man roll, chicken pho and the five spice chicken over rice. Soi man roll was actually pretty good. Chicken pho was just OK, nothing spectacular and nothing compared to actual pho places. The five spice chicken was a little dry and the poached egg was hard and completely solid inside, instead of gooey and runny, like a poached egg should be. Our main dishes also came out at different times. You're definitely paying for the ambiance here, which is really nice, but the food and service are just meh.
author: Rhea K.

description: Best vietnamese food I've ever had and one of the best restaurants in San Francisco I've been to so far. The food is delicious and the service is great. We had the crispy springs rolls and dumplings for starters and beef for entre. We might have been lucky with our choices, but everything was super tasteful. We sat in the bar next to the open kitchen from where we could see the cooks work. Overall a really good experience!
author: Christina J.

description:
On mornings when you wake up with a bad case of the bottle flu from an evening of alcoholic indulgence, you won't find a better breakfast/brunch option in Pac Heights than Out The Door. 

I'm here at least once a week, and I'd guess that 95% of the time, a steamed pork bun and bowl of chicken porridge is my ordre régulier. Something about that oily bowl of rice, chicken, French bread crostini, and basil (doused in Sriracha, of course) is just what the doctor ordered when you're trying to cut through a Kilimanjaro sized hangover. Couple that with a moist, flavorful pork bun and a strong French press that yields at least three cups of powerful java, and you'll walk out those front doors in better shape than you walked in.

It's probably one of the more comfortable brunch spots for dining solo as well. You can walk up to the bar and enjoy your meal with other dissident eaters, or nab a stool at the communal table.
author: Ruggy J.

description: This place is amazing. The staff are so friendly and knowledgeable. I have a gluten sensitivity and our waitress knew everything I could eat. The only improvement is that they have a gluten free menu or at least have GF listed by the items on their menu that is gluten free.
author: Julie S.

description: Great food but avoid peak hours if possible. Right at opening and before they close would be ideal. Makes me chuckle because I can get the same type of meal at my favorite Vietnamese hole in the wall at a fraction of the cost. Awesome city stop and staff great with all customers, young and old. Most enjoyable.
author: Merle F.

description: I was an original (Mission location) Slanted Door die hard and was disillusioned by relocations to South Beach and the Ferry Building.  OTD has been a great way to continue enjoying Charles Phan's cuisine without braving the tourist / financial district crowds.  And sometimes we do take-out.  Food every bit as good (if not a bit pricey).
author: Paul M.

description:
The milk tea actually was better than I expected it to be. The tea flavor is there initially, but it's not full bodied enough to carry a satisfying finish. It's also a bit too floral for me and could use some more earthy and malty notes. I have to say that it's really not bad though. Just having a semblance of tea flavor already puts it miles ahead of other highly rated establishments like Tea Way, T-Pumps, and Boba Guys. 

What really hurt OTD was its food. I had the pork and shrimp wonton noodle soup, and everything was pretty bland. The broth, noodles, and wontons all didn't have any real discernible flavors. I might be a little biased since I've never been a huge fan of Charles Phan, but I really feel that it needed to have a lot more flavor for the price that it commands.
author: Nei N.

description:
Vegetarian/Vegans/Pescatarians don't even bother with their brunch. Very little to no options. Such a shame. 

They dinner menu is consistently yummy, if pricey. However, the shaking beef that my friends ordered was ridiculously over priced - its comical! $36 for 6 tiny cubes of beef!
author: Kimberly N.

description: This place is amazing ! Reasonably priced and great ambience ! Food is so unique and fresh. I am very impressed
author: Jessica S.

description:
Out the Door is a good place to grab dinner with friends. 

Their food is okay, but they have a decent wine list. 

I've always had a good experience here except for that one time our waiter came over with our chicken and then walked back to the kitchen without setting on our table. Lol.
author: Monica H.

description: Love the food ! Everything is so tasty and it looks great!. The service is wonderful. Nor the Manager was a gem and made sure everything was to our liking.  Thank you for the Champagne and Beignets, they didn't last long. If you haven't tried this place please go, you won't be disappointed.
author: Susie S.

description:
Came here for brunch on a weekend with a party of six.  This place can definitely get loud (I'm sure our group did not help with the noise level).  

We started with the beignets, lotus sticky rice, and spring rolls (summer rolls with shrimp and pork).  These were good but personally I can never get over paying so much for the same food you could get at any dim sum/Vietnamese restaurant for a fraction of the cost.  

For entrees, I tried the scrambled eggs with crab and 5 spice Vietnamese chicken over rice with egg and fish sauce.  Same feedback - food was good but nothing different than your typical Vietnamese restaurant.  You are definitely paying for the upscale atmosphere and Pac Heights location but hey, they take reservations for brunch!  

Waitstaff was super busy but overall attentive.
author: Andrea L.

description:
Wow was I disappointed. I hate writing bad reviews but this needs to be said.

This is not a Vietnamese restaurant. This is an Asian fusion restaurant. If you're looking for authentic Vietnamese do not go here.

The imperial spring rolls were crispy and tasty but the Pho was dreadful.

I had really high hopes for this place but it did not live up.
author: Daniel D.

description:
It was one of those lucky occasions where I didnt have to pay attention to the price of anything because I was being treated to my lunch :') the food here during lunch is soooooo good. 

Jicama grapefruit salad-so fresh
Spring rolls
Brussel sprouts

We ordered more items but cant recall right now. Anyway, fresh vietnamese food!! I really enjoyed it.
author: Lisa K.

description:
I know that The Slanted Door gets mixed reviews but I had a great experience there (it was also during an expensed work dinner which always helps); so I was excited to try Out The Door. Not to be confused with OTD on the Embarcadero - which is just a counter - this is actually a really cute restaurant good for a nice-ish dinner.

We had a reservation for 11 people at 8pm on a Saturday and were immediately seated at a long rectangular table towards the front. I remember liking the daikon rice cake from TSD so was excited to try it here and it did not disappoint. It's a very unique appetizer so I highly recommend that. For my entree I had the lemongrass tofu with shiitake mushrooms which was done quite well. 

This is definitely a Vietnamese FUSION restaurant so if you are looking for authentic Asian food this isn't the place for you. Prices are tad on the high side for Asian food but the service was good and so was the ambiance so I'd definitely come back. They are also very vegan/vegetarian/allergy friendly.
author: Sarah S.

description: The food is good as always but the service was not up to par today. Our food took forever while other diners got theirs - including people who sat after us. No contact from the staff until we began asking about our food. Then an apology. This place can and should do better. Update: then they comped a dish. So a good step.
author: Michael E.

description: If I was a vegetarian, I can see eating here.  There's quite a few choices. Last night I was almost a vegetarian.  I had the cabbage, jicama, & grapefruit salad.  It was a bit vinegary, but there is definitely a kick when you get down to the bottom.  The Brussel sprouts really went well with the onions from the lamb.  So, my friend insisted I taste a bite of the lamb.  Yes, it melts in your mouth.  Friend is so funny, a pile of chiles and onions were scrapped to one side.  Water is needed to calm the chili taste.  Service was great.  I loose count how many times our glasses were filled.  It is a bit noisy in there with the high ceiling.  As you walk towards the back, the whiff from the kitchen makes you more hungry before you start.  Other tables seems to do family style, everyone sharing.
author: Helen L.

description:
Hands down, best spring rolls in SF! I tried the veggie spring rolls and the crispy imperial rolls(Pork). The chicken Pho broth is a bit lighter than what I'm used to, not my favorite.
Their daikon rice cakes, shaking beef and jicama salad are all superb. It's almost more fun to sit at the bar and watch them cook.
author: Livia K.

description:
My BF & I went to OTD on early on Friday night & sat at the community table. There was a larger party at the end of the table & unfortunately, one of the women at the table fainted & fell off her stool. Fortunately, one of her companions was able to catch her so the fall wasn't too bad & she did not hit her head. It was scary. Within 10 seconds the waitstaff were helping to attend to her & had a doctor to evaluate her. I asked the waiter later how he knew the guy was a doctor & he said "oh, he's a regular, so we all know he's a doctor". No one was really was really sure what to do, but once we all came out of shock a few minutes later, they offered to re-seat us. It seemed rude to sit & eat right there while the paramedics came, etc., so we moved to the counter in the back. 
The staff handled this situation with the utmost compassion, professionalism & caring. They took care of all their guests & we had a wonderful dinner. 
Eat here, the food is amazing & the staff is even more amazing. Kudos to you & your team.
Love,
Mimi
author: Mimi O.

description: Really good spring rolls the best I've had, and the peanut sauce.
author: jo m.

description:
The poop: flies in the restaurant, the hostess had the door propped open because it was so hot, it's called air conditioning, people; the server was awkward and a little condescending; the reservation policy is bizarre.

The good stuff: great food especially the lamb and the glass noodles; take away food was well wrapped; the busser chased us down when we left our sunglasses at the table *what a great show of customer service*

The good stuff outweighed the poop, easily. Definitely recommend, definitely will be back.
author: James S.

description:
Ordered the chicken curry (lunch). It was a bit spicy, but the chicken was really tender and moist which made up for the spice. Loved it. 
Would definitely go back to try some of the other dishes.
(P.S:  I was not aware of this, but the chicken is not boneless)
author: Varun A.

description: This place is reliable. No frills Asian food but made with high quality ingredients which I appreciate--it's basically impossible to find Asian food prepared with organic veggies and meats, so OTD is unique. It's pricey for a reason.
author: Sandy G.

description:
If you plan on dining in, then OTD is definitely worth a try.

If you plan on doing take out, go somewhere else.

Eating here via dine in and via take out is two completely different experiences. Their portions here compared to other restaurantst that serve similar food are already much smaller, but when you do take out.... the portions are preposterous! Not only are the portions completely different from dine in to take out... the service is too... =/

I get it... if I eat there, there is more tip money to be made and the smiles and good service get you there. But for take out... please at least act like you're moving with haste and that I matter! I'm obviously taking out for lunch because of time contraints! I called in for a reason!

The food is pretty good but for the price, I can definitely get 3 times the portion elsewhere. There are pleeeeenty of places in the city that serve bomb ass vietnamese food. You're basically paying for the atmosphere and decor of the place, which I admit is nice. I'd only take somehere here if we weren't starving or had money to blow on ordering half the menu.
author: amelia g.

description: Outrageous priced bland pseudo Vietnamese food for people who don't know any better. Aside from that. Decent and friendly service and good drinks. The appetizers were super heavy and doughy. I tried the Dungeness crab noodle dish and it was basically 80 percent noodles you can pick up for under a buck with a few pieces of crab meat mixed in there. Bland bland bland. I had to steal my friends siracha dipping sauce to eat the fish.
author: Charles L.

description: My friends and I had the shrimp dumplings, and crispy imperial rolls for starters. Then for entree- the prawns, the salmon, and the bavette. And for dessert the ginger cake. All plates to die for!
author: Ingrid C.

description: Love to sit at the bar of this cute place. And there are no better fresh rolls anywhere in the city. The salads are crunchy and fresh: I can never decide - Grapefruit or Papaya??? All so delicious.
author: Ricarda R.

description:
Disappointing service. Actually worst in this fine city.  Arrived because a friend gave us a gift card.  Waitress didn't know anything about the $36 beer on the menu, or anything about the wine.  Put the check on table before we asked because she was leaving.  Not us.  When a fruit fly landed in my wine glass doing the backstroke I politely asked if she could strain it out.  She dumped and returned with a tiny taste left in my glass even though I ordered another full one.

If there were another Vietnamese restaurant within 2 miles from this place, OTD would not last.

Bummer because we were hoping this place would be awesome.

The only bright spot was Nrd. Or Nord.  The host.  He is awesome and a better restaurant will snatch him up soon.  He brought us in thank you Nrd, but your team isn't enough to bring us back.
author: Audrey G.

description: So I'm definitely, totally a fan of Out the Door. I know little to nothing about what to expect from Vietnamese food, perhaps because there isn't much to be in found in Tucson, Arizona. But I do know that I thoroughly enjoyed my entire meal here, whether it's "authentic" or not, it was damn delicious. The space is quite small, so definitely make a reservation! I love an open kitchen and this place has one but it's not intrusive which makes the small space work. We sat at the community table and had a blast. Their local wine on tap and beer.I believe that's about it (no liquor!). We enjoyed cava and white wine with our feast which included spring rolls, pan seared scallops, crab noodles, wok Louisiana prawn and the lacinto kale. We got to sample bites from other items ordered by our group- the imperial crispy rolls, fried chicken and sea bass crudo. Seriously, I everything was fricken delish. The prawns were probably my least favorite, but they were still flavorful. The scallops for divine and I'd for sure order those again and for sure  on my next visit I'm getting my own order of crispy imperial rolls. Four stars for the service. They literally forgot the dinner order for one of our guests and didn't notice or let us know that the dish was sold out until the rest of our table got their entrees. They didn't do much to make up for it. Luckily, the rest of us ordered way too much food, so we had plenty to share while our other guest waited. I'd definitely return on another visit to SF.
author: Isabella J.

description: We went there for brunch! the food was good and tasty! the Vietnamese coffee was excellent! I'll go back to try their lunch or dinner :)
author: A Cream Puff With Apricots D.

description:
I was so excited for dinner here. After many great meals at the Slanted Door, my man and I were psyched to try OTD, so close to home. We made reservations, got all gussied up, and were ready for a great date night. I even said, "This could become our new go-to neighborhood kinda-fancy place!"

Womp womp.

Interestingly, the two things that bothered me most about our experience are things that I hardly ever complain about at restaurants -- service and noise level. Whenever people complain about service I'm like, oh boo hoo, your waiter didn't compliment your earrings. He brought your food and cleaned up after you. Deal with it. And with noise, it's like, stop whining. You're at a restaurant, not in your living room. It's going to be a little loud. But OTD helped me reach a whole new level of understanding.

Of note, the service problem appeared to be based in the kitchen, not with our waitress, who was friendly and competent. But we didn't get our appetizer for about 30 minutes after being seated, and we didn't get our entrees until abut 55 minutes after being seated. Un. Acceptable. Furthermore, this didn't seem to be an issue to any of the staff, including our waitress, who never apologized for the delay or even acknowledged it. So maybe that wait time is standard here? Not okay with me, though.

I love the decor and industrial look of the space, but seriously, it was SO LOUD it was distracting. And unattractive. We were literally SHOUTING at each other. And so was everyone else in the restaurant. Every time my boyfriend said something I had to scream, "Eh? What?", like a damn hard-of-hearing grandma. Not a good look for date night. Some sound-dampening tiles would go a long way in this concrete box.

Oh, and the food? It was fine. Soup dumplings, asparagus, lamb. The wine on tap is fun. But overall, nothing special, didn't really feel worth the price, and not nearly as epic as the meals we've had at Slanted Door. And due to the aforementioned issues, we passed on dessert and hit up the frozen yogurt place on Fillmore instead just for some instant gratification and peace and quiet. Sad.

Anyway, I might go back again with a larger group, get more dishes to try, drink more wine so I could get boisterous, and expect to have to scream at each other to be heard. But we definitely won't be back for date night. Disappointing.
author: Megan D.

description:
I may be one of the oldest and best fans of the Slanted Door empire. I was one of the first diners at the little place on Valencia and have been a committed diner to this week. I eat lunch at OTD at least once a week and order out at least twice a week. Over the last 6 mos I have noticed a decline in the vietnamese theme of the food leaning more towards chinese food, smaller portions at lunch and shrinking actual plates at dinner and about a month a go...a diminished number of truly free range / organic meat options.  I have tolerated most of this and have kept coming in...
Two weeks ago I came in and ate dinner. I ordered three dishes. 
A few  nights ago I ordered the exact same three dishes to go and paid the exact same amount and got home with 1/3 the amount of food. I ate my dinner having to chew on that fact with each bite.
i was pissed and felt robbed.
NOT COOL....not cool at all.
author: Kate S.

description:
food is pretty good, a bit pricey but it's in the Fillmore/pac heights vicinity; what would you expect with the going rate for a property purchase or space lease?

Restaurant is pretty on the inside and I like how open it is..but if you want to have a conversation it's pretty hard, when people design space they don't often think about the sound acoustics 

boba is surprisingly good..wine list and tea decent
author: Whitne Y.

description:
Great food and cool, sleek ambiance. 

What we got:

--Crispy imperial rolls: amazing. perfectly crisped.
--Fried Chicken: while I loved the sriracha aioli sauce, I wasn't super blown away by the chicken itself. If you're a fried chicken lover like me, you probably won't be either.
--Shaking Beef: WOW! 5 stars all the way. Super tender, perfectly cooked and juice, this was my favorite. It's definitely pricey for what it is ($36..), but worth trying.
--Chocolate Peanut Butter Pie: absolutely delicious. cannot wait to come back and get this pie!

Overall, pricey and not mind-blowingingly amazing, but solid, high quality, tasty food in a trendy setting. I'd definitely come back for the right occasion.
author: Rachel L.

description: Wow. We had 3 different soups off the lunch menu and it was all brilliant. Especially good was the Beef Pho with an aged beef. Yum yum yum!
author: Kevin R.

description:
The food is good, albeit as others note, expensive.  This review is for the inexplicably bad non-service awhile ago.

In a full service place, I expect everyone to tend their primary station first.  I sat at the small bar intending on an early lunch.  Two people left as I arrived so I was the only one at the bar.  No acknowledgement at all from bartender, not even eye contact.

The btender  still ignoring me takes a check to a table -- even though there was a server.


Still ignoring me, she seats walk-ins at a table -- even though there was a hostess.

Finally, she takes a phone order, continuing to ignore me.  After 5 minutes of this I got wiser and bailed.

I had been in there with that bartender several times.  I was polite and tipped 25-30% so there was no basis for her ignoring me.
author: Steve S.

description: Ok food. It definitely isn't authentic Vietnamese food by any means. Good food non the less.
author: Steven B.

description:
The food here is great, divining in is fabulous, but getting to-go here at this particular restaurant is frustrating. The food is 5 stars but the to-go service is so bad here it's knocked two stars off for me.
 I normally go to the OTD at the ferry building, but I was craving their yummy chicken cabbage salad so I got some here today because it's closer to my house. When I went up to the to-go counter today the cashier walked away from me even though I was ready to order. She then proceeded to gossip with her co-workers for five minutes while I waited at the counter. Her manager even tapped her on the shoulder to show herthat I was waiting to order, she kept talking. Eventually she mosied on over and I had to repeat my name and what I wanted about three times over. Maybe she was having an off day but it really rubbed me the wrong way.
author: mackenzie e.

description:
After all this time my better half finally got me to this wonderful little brother to Slanted Door.

I delighted in every ingredient - broth, vermicelli noodles, sixes, thinly sliced beef, etc. - in my beef Pho accompanied with broccoli and shiitake in a red-pepper spiced sauce. Mmmm, mm, m.

Fine eating on a fine day at a lovely, casual restaurant.
author: Jay D.

description: Elegant restaurant with nice service but the flavors are just not as awesome as I expect.   The prices steep.   I prefer Le Soleil on Clement and it's less money for richer dishes.    OTD cold spring roll dipping sauce is lousy.   Their chive dumplings are seriously huge but just stuffed with chives and greens- maybe one shrimp in there.  The cabbage slaw with grapefruit was a 10 though.  I'd go back for just that.
author: Pauline C.

description: They have delicious pho ONLY at lunch time! They also serve bubble tea which is always a treat. Dinner time is much fancier including the prices. I live one block away from OTD and do quite a lot of Togos, which always come well prepared.
author: Travel H.

description: The food is amazing! French toast was out of this world and everything is very fresh!
author: Tobey H.

description: Used to be so great but increasing hard to love. Ordered take-out the other day - two spring rolls and a papaya salad. The online menu shows the spring rolls and papaya salad as $10 each - so $30 right? When I go to pick it up I'm given a non-itemized bill for $39+. What's up? They have no idea but obviously their prices have changed and they didn't update it online - but that's a 30% increase and obviously very misleading. Throw in a tip and $45 for two spring rolls and a small salad is not feeling like it is worth the trip. I have a photo of the online menu but don't know how to post it.
author: roger m.

description:
I'm lucky to say that live within a few blocks of Out the Door, which makes it very easy for me to dine there whether it's for their tasty dinner or awesome brunch. 

They have an open kitchen, which is a fun addition to your meal. If seated at the bar...you have a front row experience to how your meal is prepared. The show is great and the service is pretty fabulous too. 

Must haves - 
* pan fried shrimp and chive dumplings, spicy soy dipping sauce (appetizer)
* spring rolls, shrimp, pork shoulder, mint, aioli, spicy peanut sauce (roll)
* crispy imperial rolls, shrimp, pork, mint, peanuts, red leaf lettuce (roll)
* dungeness crab, cellophane noodles, garlic, green onion, sesame oil (entree - FAVORITE!!)
 * niman ranch lemongrass pork chop, crispy sunchokes & cauliflower, spicy soy (entree)
 * shaking beef, grass-fed estancia ranch cubed filet mignon, watercress, red onions, lime sauce (entree)
* and ANYTHING for brunch! 

Two things to note...beer and wine only, but they have a great selection. And they tend to book up fast. Would recommend making a reservation or you'll probably have to wait (1+ hours) during peak times. 

Overall...I find myself eating here a few times a month. If that doesn't say how much I love it, I don't know what does.
author: Dru M.

description:
Excellent food but too loud.

I went here for dinner with a friend on her recommendation; everything we had (green papaya salad, shanghai soup dumplings, crispy vegetarian rolls, shaking beef, and rum cake) was great. The soup dumplings were especially good, so good we ordered a second plate!

However, the place was just way too loud. At times we literally had to yell to each other. Perhaps this is fueled by the rather long tables that spread parties out.

Still, for the great food, I would definitely return.
author: DJ S.

description: Best spring rolls in the city! 3 of us went to dinner and ordered so many things and I loved EVERYTHING!!! It was pricey and not great ambiance, but it was darn good food.
author: Leah B.

description: Even without reservations you can get in and enjoy a nice meal. Walked in and had a great dinner, good wines but nothing that makes you consider it a wine bar. If I were a snob I'd give them four stars for the lack of desirable alcoholic beverages. However the ambiance and food cooked to perfection with an amazing Manager at the counter makes it 5 stars. Delicious!
author: Joseph H.

description:
You know what grosses me out? 

When I see back of house staff with loose, long hair that should be tied back (PER HEALTH CODES) preparing food for guests. 

That grosses me out. 

Your hair is very pretty, but you need to have it in a ponytail or something.
author: Crystal T.

description:
3.5 stars.

This is a more upscale Vietnamese restaurant. While it's supposedly more casual than the chef's original restaurant, it's still a lot classier and cleaner than the average pho place you might go to.

The spring rolls didn't really surprise, but their fish sauce dip for them tasted decent and more authentic, unlike the weird stuff you get at the cheaper places. The vermicelli that came with it was well cooked and well separated as well. The daikon cakes were also pretty decent.

As for the crab with cellophane noodles...I liked the taste of it, and it was even better after I reheated it the next day. However, it lacked depth -- it was literally just crab and noodles with a little bit of cilantro.

I didn't see pho on the menu this time. Maybe next time?
author: Alice C.

description:
This place is right in my neighborhood and I LOVE IT. The last time I was there, the waitress called me out on being there all the time..oops. I can't help going back - it's one of the best places to eat around Fillmore.

Brunch is the best. It's a bit of a secret - most people don't notice this place does brunch but it's seriously really good. The best way to eat brunch here is to order a bunch of items and share (egg items, thick french toast, crispy spring rolls, etc.) It's super affordable and the vietnamese fusion element adds a fun, creative twist to the usual slurry of mundane brunch items.

I am also guilty of coming here way too often for boba milk tea to-go. It's 5 bucks but really good so I keep coming back to feed my addiction. Like I said, I can't help it..
author: Amanda C.

description: Love everything about the food. The little guy who's the hostess is a twerp. Unaccomodating.
author: Jon D.

description:
I'm so excited, I finally get to write a one star review!

We walked into this place for lunch and found it essentially empty. The decor is stylish and hip/industrial with a row of about 20 tables, with only one table actually seating customers when we arrived. We stood there for a while as the host, a couple of feet away, was talking to a co-worker and ignored us. He eventually worked his way over to us and asked us if we had a reservation. Maybe it was because the restaurant was almost completely empty, or maybe it was because he was so rude about it, but we couldn't help but laugh. 

It was like an episode of portlandia (believe it or not, the portlandia theme song was playing overhead). He had so much attitude for no reason, I felt like he either wanted to garner a bad review for the place or we had walked onto to some hidden camera show. There is no way the food is good enough to warrant this kind of douchebaggery. Go to Bun Mee around the corner for your vietnamese fix.

I'll give them this though, the name is pretty apt, because shortly after entering, we went right 'Out the Door.'

Boom.
author: Baron C.

description:
Date & Time:  Wednesday September 30, 2009 @ 7pm Opening Day
Company:  Michael
Crowd:  Extraordinary Mr. Charles Phan, Packed w/ Neighborhood Fans in Small Groups & Couples; Gentlemen in Thomas Pink Shirts & Ladies in Margaret O'Leary Cashmere & Riding Outfits
Music:  Mix of Al Green & House Music
Atmosphere:  Social
Decor:  Sleek, Modern Space.  Communal Table, Dual Counter-Seating on TB Barstools in Brushed Aluminum & Bench Seating w/ Marble Tables for Deux & Quatre
Service:  Young Attractive Professional in Head to Toe OTD Noir Attire
Imbibe:  Beer(One in Particular Priced @ $27, Which We Skipped) & Vietnamese Coffee
Devour:   Shrimp Spring Rolls, Rock-Shrimp & Pineapple Soup, Sardines, Pork Chop, Quiche & Shredded Pork, Coconut Water Tapioca
Total:  $88.98
author: Genevieve Y.

description:
I forgot this place is right in my neighborhood! God damn, it's so good. 

Green Papaya Salad -- yes
BBQ Spareribs -- hells yes
Fried chicken w/ siracha butter and pickles - YES + 10 for the pickles
Shaking Beef -- yes! 

The green beans were just okay, and the vietnamese coffee was way too sweet and just lacking (then again, we ordered it at 8pm; it might be better earlier in the day). 

But everything else was stellar. The staff was really great and knowledgeable about the menu. We sat and the chef's counter and were able to watch everything being made. 

The shaking beef here was much better than at the flagship Slanted Door, and came with a really interesting sweet-salty-sour black pepper vinegar sauce

The only con is that it is pretty overpriced... 36$ for 6 chunks of beef w/ some onions? eek. Every once in a while, I'm totally willing to pay that though.
author: Laura J.

description:
I liked everything I had, but not enough to remember what it was for next time. Except the avocado panna cotta - I would eat that dessert all day every day. 

Decent/quiet location
author: Ashley W.

description: The Slanted Door cannot be beat and this is an easy reservation, superb service, and less expensive rendition of Slanted Door. You will find many Slanted Door favorites on the menu. I have suggested we go back soon!
author: Dorothy R.

description:
This is my new favorite place for lunch.  The food is so fresh, tasty and consistent.  My mother and I go here every other Tuesday after our nail appointment...yes ladies who lunch, very cliche I know, but I feel so lucky to spend this time with my Mom...where we can relax, talk and eat healthy yummy food.   

The staff is friendly and while the service is on the slow side it is only due to the fact they cook everything fresh.  It is totally worth the wait.  If you are in a rush I would recommend ordering to go as that is originally why this location was started thus the name Out the Door.  

Enjoy!
author: Cheryl R.

description:
Fancy Vietnamese fusion place with a nice upscale vibe and friendly service. I came here for brunch and tried the chicken porridge and fried chicken. The porridge was delicious, with very traditional flavors. The fried chicken was also pretty good, but wish there was something besides the pickled vegetables to balance it out.  

Overall, nice place and good food. I will definitely be back to try their dinner service.
author: Vivian H.

description:
Always amazing food. Consistent service, delicious product. Great place to bring out of towners, friends or weekday dinner. 

Brunch is particularly fabulous. Chicken Pho is the best option during brunch. 

I will always come back here.
author: Lisa T.

description:
Great service.  
Interesting menu. Food was pretty good.

They had open tables for brunch and seated us instantly.
author: Chad M.

description: Very well conceptualized place. The brunch options are versatile and interesting. I found the eggs a bit greasy though, and when I asked for a salad I got stacked lettuce with spring roll dipping sauce. I think they still have to figure out the fusion of the menu and solidify their recipes, however it was a satisfying meal and I would possibly come back. Great alternative to super crowded brunch places in the area.
author: Tecla E.

description:
I took an out-of-town friend here for Saturday brunch. 

Beignets with Vietnamese Coffee: These were too dense for my liking, definitely still edible, but the inside didn't have the airy, custardy taste that make choux pastries pop. The Vietnamese coffee was quite sweet, available hot or cold. The cold one we ordered probably had as much ice as liquid though. 

strawberries and creme french toast: A generous portion compared to most brunch places for the same price. The lemon creme, strawberries+mint combo was a nice touch. I wasn't impressed by the bread itself though.

Eggs in a hole - this item was my favorite by far, perhaps because I loved the brioche bread. It reminded me of this Danish bread i always get at Asian bakeries. The bread was perfectly fried, very toasty around the edges. The egg itself was cooked gorgeously and not overly seasoned. The bacon was good quality too. 

My friend got the bahn mi to-go. For a $12 sandwich, it definitely wasn't mind-blowing. In fact, she said it was average even among $3 sandwiches. Of the bites I've tried of it, I would have to say I agree. They are also super skimpy on the pate. For a lot of the Vietnamese savories on the menu, it seems like you would be better served going to Little Saigon in Tenderloin. Cheap and Delish.
author: Alice L.

description: Went here for lunch on a weekday, parking was kind of difficult.  I was surprised how busy it was so I decided to order to go.  I went for the lemongrass pork over rice with a fried egg and pickled vegetables. It was AMAZING. The pickled vegetables alone were worth the drive out there. Everyone else I was with ordered the chicken rice porridge and I didn't try  it but they were all very happy. One person I was with even said, "This is the best chicken ive ever had i my life". If you haven't been, go.
author: Kyle R.

description:
Came here many times for different dishes.
Today I have chicken porridge and it's delicious!! Service is great and everything look clean
author: Katie E.

description:
FRESH TARO BOBA ! 

Not many places use fresh taro these days, so I was happy to find it here. Only thing is that it looks pre-made and is kept in the fridge, rather than being freshly made to order.
author: bonnie y.

description:
My boyfriend and I have been here twice, so the review is encompassing those two trips.  On one trip, we had reservations and had to wait, but got to enjoy a drink at the bar.  The other time we walked in off the street and were seated right away.  The reservation night was a Friday night, and I think the walk-in was during a weeknight.  Makes sense.  Anyway, we sat at the same table in both occasions, and in both instances felt like we were a little too close to the table next to us.  I like my space, especially when I'm on a date.

Onto the food!  For appetizers, we have had the following:
- Spring rolls, shrimp, pork shoulder, mint, spicy peanut sauce
- Hue dumplings, mung bean, scallion oil, spicy soy

To be honest, the dumplings were less than memorable, but Greg absolutely LOVES the spring rolls.  I have to admit, they are incredibly delicious, especially since the peanut sauce they serve it with is warm.

Mains:
- Shaking beef, grass-fed estancia ranch cubed filet mignon, watercress, red onions, lime sauce (obviously)
- Mary's organic chicken claypot, caramel sauce, ginger, chilies
- Prather ranch rotisserie pork loin, five spice, spring onions, crispy fingerling potatoes

Sides:
- Jasmine rice
- Hodo soy beanery yuba, kabocha squash, black trumpet mushrooms, glass noodles

The shaking beef and claypot chicken are the usual favorites, especially if you've been to The Slanted Door.  Is the Shaking Beef dish overpriced at $36?  Probably.  Would I order it again when I end up back at Out the Door? Probably.  Between that and the claypot chicken, they are solid choices to share.  On both occasions we shared a bottle of wine to go with dinner, so we're usually pretty stuffed by the time dinner is over.  Service wise, there isn't anything out of the ordinary that we got at OTD, but sometimes no recollection is better than a memorable bad experience.  It isn't a place we frequent very often, but when we have dropped in, it's been consistently delicious.
author: Lisa I.

description:
Waking up in a strange bed next to my wife, It took a minute for my throbbing head to remember we were visiting San Francisco. Soon are awesome host (who was kind enough to not only put us up, but gave up their bed for us) laid out some options on where to grab some breakfast nearby. One option grabbed our interest when Breakfast and Vietnamese was mentioned in the same sentence. 
Out The Door it was then, as our host mentioned " You can get scrabbled eggs and bacon anytime at home." 

After a short walk we entered a door with the initials in small letters that read OTD, I would have never found this place on my own. 
Inside was very modern and slick. We sat up at the bar to watch the magic happen. 

We decided to share some of the appetizers to start off. We tried the Beignets, Steamed Pork Buns, and the best (and first for me) home made Cherrie Pop-tart I have ever had. Each selection was amazing on its own. 
Wife and I both ordered the Chicken Pho which was damn tasty, but when I tried our friend's Chicken Porridge I instantly wished I had that instead. 
A very good and different breakfast that for sure scrubbed away that shameful hangover pretty quick. 
Next time in this city I really hope we end up back here for round 2!
author: Noel J.

description:
Just the best. Consistent food and service. My favorites include the green papaya salad, the imperial rolls, fresh spring rolls, chicken clay pot, and pork chop. Can't get enough of the broken rice either.

Every time i visit I enjoy it more and leave nothing on the plate. Charles Phan created an excellent Vietnamese restaurant that's the perfect date spot!
author: Pilar P.

description:
Tasty food but inconsistent portions. 

I now understand why they cut the imperial rolls we ordered into 3 pieces--if they hadn't we probably would have finished them off in one go.  

My pan braised black cod was flaky, melt in your mouth goodness topped with perfectly crisp skin. I just wish there had been more of it. 

My friend fared better with the pork chop in terms of serving size; the meat itself was juicy and well-flavored. 

Just be prepared to drop some $$$ if you walk in here with a big appetite.
author: Lulu C.

description: Mediocre would be an insult to merely mediocre restaurants. No better than a hole in the wall Vietnamese in little Saigon and needless attitude. Told no seat at the bar when there was. Papaya salad  salty and very heavy with dressing. I spent ten minutes trying to get check. I told the server before finalizing this review - she just said fine - no apology. Go to roam around the corner for great food and warm service.
author: clark f.

description: Was in SF this past weekend and this was my last and favorite meal before heading back to NY. Hostess went out of her way to seat our group comfortably and we had excellent service throughout the entire meal. The vegetarian crispy imperial rolls were delicious (I have craved these since trying them 3 years ago!) and I was very happy with my soft scrambled eggs with crispy battered ling cod. Cooked perfectly. My chef husband says he wish he ordered it too, although he enjoyed his beef pho. Overall, great experience. Wish we could come back sooner!
author: Angie R.

description:
We are huge fans of the ENTIRE menu at OTD. We also want to mention Valerie Klein, the manager, who deserves special mention for her attention , care, and humor in dealing with customers! 
Marti  and Zoe
author: Marti M.

description:
The good was good and deserves at least 4 stars but BEWARE of the noise. It was difficult to have a conversation with friends over dinner. 

I would highly recommend the Friend Chicken and the Wok fried prawns!
author: Vishal B.

description:
If you want authentic Vietnamese food, this isn't the place to you.  The food is a modern take on Vietnamese cuisine and I enjoyed it!  We ordered:

spring rolls - good but nothing amazing
papaya salad - YUM, so fresh!
brussel sprouts - my new fave veggie 
fried chicken - yummy sriracha sauce! and very juicy chicken
shaking beef - my fave dish, meat so tender and saucy
crab with noodles could use more seasoning
braised pork - also yum because it was saucy 

Overall we had a great dining experience.  The food was delish, and cheaper than Slanted Door and more casual, especially since we had 2 kiddos with us.

P.s. I would give this place 3.5 stars :)
author: Kristina G.

description: The food was not my issue, although my entree was too salty, and the server graciously offered to remove it from the bill.  When we were seated, we were told we only had our table for one hour and fifteen minutes.  We thought that was fine and agreed.  After we had our entree, we were offered coffee and dessert.  Just as we had taken our first sip, the host abruptly told us we had to get up immediately and offered to put our coffee in a to go cup.  My question is:  Why weren't we told earlier or why was there no coordination with the service staff?  A simple gentle reminder would have left us with a very pleasant dining experience.  Instead, we felt like cattle being shoved out of the boxcar.  Is this what dining has become?  If so, Out the Door gets no more of my dining dollars.
author: Susan L.

description:
The quality of food was outstanding.  We ate calamari, spring rolls, pork chops, lamb stir fry, and crab w noodles. Everything was so damn good. My wife had the peach cobbler w blueberry ice cream which was also incredibly good and quickly demolished.  

They also do carry out which might be the best way to get the food since they quickly filled every seat in the restaurant.
author: Matthew C.

description:
The only reason this place doesn't have a 4 or higher is because of the wait staff, how long it takes for them to take orders etc. I have had issues with one waiter in particular...slow and always makes mistakes. 

Fresh and delicious 5 quality. Their spring rolls are so delectable, I can eat them all day! Five spiced chicken is moist and flavorful, can't go wrong with it. Stop by during their lunch hours because many of their items are featured on the dinner menu but with a lower price. The atmosphere reflects the food, bright and vibrant. It can be a little cozy with the seating arrangement, but definitely worth a try!
author: Misha Z.

description:
Love this place! We've dined-in here once and have also gotten take out a few times. We've tried the soup (it changes often), the crispy vegetarian rolls, and usually a noodle vegetarian entree. We've never been disappointed with anything. 

It is becoming one of our go-to diner take-out places.
author: Carlynn A.

description:
(Updated on this review after receiving the credit card statement)

Was originally giving it a 4-star but found out on the credit card statement, instead of what I put was 17% tip, they added it to more than 25%.Totally unprofessional especially for such an established eatery. Will not go back even the food was good as if they could steal money from customers that way, who knows what else they could do. 

=====================

(See pics)

Solid 4 stars for brunch.

A place without a sign but everyone knows about this place.

Relatively speaking I like this one because it feels more relaxing for brunch. It's spacious and not way too much busy that you have to eat fast. In fact, service paced slowly so that you can enjoy every bite.

The beignets and Vietnamese coffee combo was a great starter, both are my favorites. The coffee was good strong and the ball style beignets were absolutely freshly deep fried.

They offered half-order imperial rolls that I truly appreciated. The rolls were properly fried and not too heavy.

As I was asking about the wines I found that they serve wines on tap. They realized they did not give me the wine menu when I first sat down. The beaker style wine container is interesting. I opted for the Broc Cellars Carignane and it was a good and not heavy wine matching the slow cooked eggs with Niman ranch brisket and good crisp potatoes. The eggs were fantastic and the beef was delicious.

It does sound like a lot of food for a Sunday brunch but hey, the food was just too good to not finish it all!

Service was great and friendly. Nice and clean decoration.
author: T L.

description: A bit overpriced, but very good for a fusion Vietnamese meal with high quality, fresh ingredients assembled in a truly professional manner.  LOVE the flavorful broth in the Chicken Pho soup, fresh Chicken Salad with a slightly sweet / zesty dressing, and the Grilled 5-Spice Chicken with the noodles, greens, fish sauce, and fried spring rolls.  SO tasty.  The bill will run around $50-$60 for around two appetizers, two entrees and maybe one drink, but hey, that's life in SF.  Very worth it for the occasional splurge.
author: Peggy A.

description: Wonderful food and ambience. Had the fresh spring rolls, the short ribs and the cellophane noodles with crab. Tessier Grenache wine was perfect. We chose this place randomly and would return without question. Sit at the bar to avoid waiting for a table.
author: Mason O.

description: Came in without a reservation with my wife. One of the best wine selections I've seen in this city. They carry true, rebel natural wine. That, plus really well made Vietnamese food makes this place much more than just your average vietnamese place. This is a statement, and this city could use more places like this.
author: Nicolas D.

description:
I ordered the chicken porridge (after all it's on the 7x7 100 eats before you die list)  and my bf loves the beef pho.  I've had the beef pho at their other locations but never here.  Repeat never here.  Why?  Because this time they were out of it!  The last time we were there, we were told we were past the time that they serve it.  Why it is so difficult to get this dish?!?  

As for the porridge.  It's good, but not that great.  (Given I'm completely biased since I grew up with chinese porridge).  It has a really great chicken flavor but I found it almost too concentrated.  Loved the crunchy toppings which contrast the texture.  The broth was just too rich (I couldn't finish the dish).  I don't know..maybe it's just me.  Btw I agree with the crap shoot service.  Either great or crazy slow.
author: Tiffany C.

description: This place is just a rip off. The food  is good but no better than Vietnamese places that charge less than half. $20 for clay pot chicken? The equivalent of one chicken thigh cut up with some onion , fish sauce and sugar. Cost them like $2 to make. Give me a break.  Our bill was $90 for three people. No drinks and no dessert. We just had 3 entrees and papaya salad and spring rolls. This meal would $40 elsewhere and just as good with larger portions. I work too hard for my money to waste it on a pretentious place like this. Rip off alert!
author: Jeff T.

description:
I can't stay away from the cellophane crab noodles. The green papaya salad is amaze. Love the soups and spring rolls. But I will have too.  It pains me to write this review but I was treated so poorly and coldly that I must speak up.

I frequent this restaurant  and always have my service dog with me. Usually ordering to go.  The last time I was in to pick something up, I was discriminated against and asked that my dog not be near the `other guests'.  This is not only illegal but it's downright insensitive and alienating.  My dog goes where I go and this is only the second restaurant in the entire city that has taken issue with him.  The Globe being the other.  The bartender started with the cold shoulder, somehow silently signaled the manager without making any eye contact or making an effort to greet me and then she came over and it was all over.  I explained to her that it was the restaurants responsibility to be aware of the laws and train her staff on them since clearly she was not and had not.

I am positive that since I am in the minority that this won't effect their business much unless people think twice about giving their money to a restaurant that discriminates and humiliates people with disabilities.  Ever heard of the ADA?  I hope at least a someone in a wheelchair can get in and is not asked to move to the very front door of the restaurant.
author: emily b.

description: This place has awesome Vietnames food. It took a while for me to find this place because it didn't looked like a restaurant. When I was inside it's was crowded with people and I love the vibe. I had couple of dishes and it was worth every penny cuz I thought it was a over priced Vietnames food at first impression. Grilled chicken just unforgettable it just taste amazing. They also had wine collection and my fav drink vietnames coffee. Great place great food but they should put a big sign outside to let people see it easily.
author: Jagan B.

description:
My fiancé and I order from out the door a couple times a week. We love the options at this place, I know that the reviews tend to be shaky because of the price, but I think the options and the flavors are superb. 

I would also recommend this place in the afternoons or brunch, or taking a casual meeting. The decor and set up of high tables is a nice touch.
author: Kaego R.

description:
Was walking to church when I noticed the sign OTD. I was curious and looked it up on Yelp. I thought this may be an option to try after church with my mom and gf.  When church ended, I had decided on 2 restaurants to eat lunch. My first option had an hour wait, so OTD was my next choice. I am glad that my first option was not available because it allowed us to have an excellent experience at OTD.
For starters, we shared 3 different steamed buns: chicken, bbq pork, and vegetarian. All 3 were excellent with tasty filling and texture.
Main dishes: Banh Cuon, fresh steamed rice creeps with ground pork, onions, mushrooms, and Vietnamese ham. It was a very delicate and delicious dish.
Chicken Pho had flavorful broth.
Lemongrass pork over rice with a fried egg was one of my favorites.
There were many other dishes we wanted to try and will save those for our future visits.
Lastly, Whitney and Valerie gave excellent  service and made us feel very comfortable.
author: Marlon L.

description: Had a great brunch here, wish they had the palate teasing cocktails that their big sister restaurant has. Not such the fuss and crowd, which was nice. Pork belly hash was outstanding, omelette was good- but needs some flare. Perhaps a great sauce? Seemed a tad dry. Typical modern and clinical ambience of many sf joints.
author: Bree M.

description:
It's easy to write this review after writing one for Slanted Door. Let's just say the food quality at this place is just as good as their mothership. It's also close to my work and where I live, walking distance and all.

I've only been here for brunch on Saturdays so I got porridge and some spring rolls, and then some pho which was the perfect trio for the first meal of my day.

The prices are extremely reasonable and the atmosphere is very down to earth. The food is of similar quality (in my opinion) and much less crowded for mealtime. Of course, it lacks in the ambiance of Slanted Door but I didn't choose this place for the ambiance. I chose it for the food and the convenience.

Thank you for opening one in my 'hood.
author: Julia P.

description:
This was my second time here, and I wasn't sure how to rate it, but I can say it's a solid 4 stars.  

The service is good, the wine is on tap (awesome!) and the restaurant is really cute. 

Food to try:
Cellophane crab noodles
Crispy imperial roll
Salted squid and calamari with jalapeño and pineapple
Kale

The kale was probably the least exciting of all the dishes... Nevertheless, it was a great meal and I'm not sure why I don't come back more!
author: Taylor L.

description: I worked here as a grill cook on an externship from Le Cordon Bleu & then worked as an employee after the 3 month externship was up, total of 8 months working there. The food is great, as well as the staff. The kitchen cleanliness is great, it's also a pretty big kitchen. I got lucky with that one knowing that most kitchens in the city are suuuuper tiny. Our food was very fresh, nothing reheated & served. The restaurant can and pretty much always is packed with people and has a line out of the door. I learned a lot working here, and got very close with all the people I worked with. I miss OTD always. I always worked lunch & brunch, so a little after I left OTD I came for dinner with my boyfriend, everybody was welcoming me back, it was so nice to see everybody again. All the food was extremely flavorful, it was all great. I had the chicken clay pot and he had the crab cellophane noodles, I haven't tried either dishes before and loved both. Then kitchen sent complimentary ribs and they were so tender they fell apart into your mouth, the flavor was also perfect. (Thanks guys ) we also got a complimentary slice of chocolate peanut butter pie, I've tried that before and it was amazing like always. The peanut crumble on top of the slice itself is my personal favorite part about that dessert. When I read reviews on here of this place I see a lot of complaint about the noise level being annoying & that's not something we can really do anything about, it's the public. The place can get very loud during a rush but what good restaurant isn't loud with people chattering and pots and pans banging around? I'll definitely be back for brunch soon to eat, I miss it! I got lucky to be a part of OTD as my first job in the kitchen. Miss you guys.
author: Alicia L.

description:
Small portions, but outstanding.

Get the prawns. Dear lord, get the Prawns.
author: Bryy M.

description:
My boyfriend and I live in the neighborhood and going here has been our favorite weeknight treat for the past couple of years.  We love the food enough to go regularly.  Our favorites are the veggie crispy imperial roll, the tofu, the yuba noodle dish, and their various seasonal vegetables are always nice.  The dining area is always pleasant and cozy with a glass of wine on those chilly SF nights.  

I was diagnosed with gluten intolerance a few months ago and sadly assumed they wouldn't be able to accomodate such a limited diet (I'm also vegetarian).  We stopped visiting.

Finally, a few days ago, we decided to give it a whirl and see if there was anything gluten-free on the menu.  I am SO glad we did!  We checked with the hostess and she assured me there was plenty on the menu that could be prepared gluten-free.  Then, she actually came to our table with a menu and marked everything that I could have.  She was very sweet and never made me feel like a burden (as I've learned can easily happen when attempting to dine out GF).  The chef was also extremely knowledgeable and went out of his way to give me a special GF sauce for my spring roll.  I nearly cried tears of gratitude after receiving such wonderful customer service.  I'm so excited to be putting OTD back on the list of places I can go!
author: Emily H.

description:
I used to be a HUGE fan of all of the "Door" restaurants (Slanted Door and all the Out the Doors).  I've probably dined at the restaurants, including the original (and since re-located) Slanted Door in the Mission District, a total of 200 times.  It was always my go-to restaurant when visitors were in town, or when there was a special occasion.  I also own and use the restaurant's cookbook.

But my last visit to Out the Door made me question my loyalty to this chain of restaurants.  The prices are so, so high, and portion sizes so small.  The quality is still very good, but not that much better (and in some cases not better at all) than many other Vietnamese restaurants in the SF Bay Area.  I spent $25+ on food that would have cost me $10 at my local Mom n' Pop Vietnamese restaurant, and it was not of a higher caliber.

So, I guess I won't be returning to these restaurants anytime soon.
author: Jane D.

description:
OVERALL PROS: 
- Very sexy spot. Love the decor, the long open room.
- Good service. We were all at least 10-15 minutes late and they held our table, no questions asked. Our server was prompt and friendly.
- Must-haves: chicken claypot, porkchops, dungeness crab noodles.

OVERALL CONS:
- Way way way overpriced, and you get really small servings.
- Do not order: pork meatballs, warm chocolate cake 

Onto the dishes...

* Crispy imperial rolls, shrimp, pork, mint, peanuts, red leaf lettuce - The rolls had a great crisp. The sauce was a little weak and light, and too sour - more options would've been nice. I honestly would've enjoyed the rolls by themselves; the lettuce and noodles weren't really necessary.

* Grilled pork meatballs, red leaf lettuce, vermicelli, pickled daikon, pineapple-anchovy sauce - I found the pork rubbery and oily, the sauce too tangy and sour. Our server had even specifically recommended this dish, but it wasn't worth it. Plus the veggie sides didn't really go with the pork. Overall when you made a lettuce wrap all the ingredients just didn't go well together.

* Dungeness crab, cellophane noodles, green onion, sesame oil - Although the cellophane noodles (vermicelli) were a little overcooked (way too soft, broke apart too easily), I loved the flavor of this dish and found myself getting seconds and thirds. The crab meat was sparse but great and the dish was light, not too oily

* Seared day boat scallops, sautéed spinach, crispy shallots, spicy pineapple coconut sauce - The scallops were done well, slightly rare on the inside and more seared on the outside. The spinach went really well, but I was disappointed by the sauce which was way more heavy on the pineapple (and more sour than sweet).
