Also there was something like only six scallops for a ridiculous price (over $20).

* Mary's organic chicken claypot, caramel sauce, chilies, fresh ginger  - Delicious! The sauce was strong & flavorful (probably mostly soy sauce, but hey can't go wrong with that). The meat was tender yet firm. And the dish came out steaming. I found myself spooning the extra sauce onto my rice just so I could have more of it. Only problem was there was SO LITTLE meat!!

* Grilled niman ranch country pork chop, crispy fingerling potatoes, spicy soy - These pork chops were absolutely delicious. Spiced just right. Seared on the outside and soft and tender meat on the inside. And the crispy fingerling potato halves - a perfect complement!

* Thai basil ice cream with orange pizelle - The basil flavor was really unique & we enjoyed that a lot. The pizelle was a great touch, added a bit of sweetness & crunch. However the texture of the ice cream was much more like a sorbet & way too light, not creamy enough.

* Warm chocolate cake with candied peanuts - Very disappointing, I'm sure the worst warm chocolate cake I've ever ordered at a restaurant. It was dry - but they try to trick you into thinking it's moist by drizzling the whole thing with what's probably a cheap Hersheys chocolate syrup. Not exactly warm, & no hard outer shell to crack into!!

We were recommended the Papaya Salad and I regret not getting it. It looked amazing and unlike any papaya salad I've ever had. Also we were going to get the pho but changed our minds when our neighbors all got it - didn't look that appealing, and the noodles didn't look like the best quality.
author: Ziyan C.

description:
I came here for lunch with my mother and my aunt. It's very loud, even on Sunday and it was too crowded for my tastes. I could barely carry a conversation. They could use some sound dampening panels because the interior looked like it was made of concrete. Very reflective of sound. Service was quick, courteous, and professional. I was disappointed to find our bowls and glasses had chips broken off of them which in one case made for a sharp edge.

The food was otherwise very tasty and it sat well with my delicate and overly sensitive stomach. Everything was served to look wonderful. I would say the recipes used here gives Vietnamese food a good name. 

Take care of a few non-food items and I will give this place more stars.
author: Boris S.

description: I've been here a couple of times but the service is so uneven, haphazard, uncohesive - servers are not attentive, they forget stuff. I ordered wine and it took 20 minutes to arrive (the ran out of certain wine but failed to tell me and had to ask where my wine was after 20 mins, so ordered another wine)  Foodwise, it's ok, not stellar for what you pay. Some dishes are good like their rice porridge, full of flavor.  The five spice chicken, fried chicken, papaya salad kinda bland and needs more kick.
author: Mr. C.

description:
I've gone a handful of times and may go again at some point. They have a healthy number of vegetarian options, but I usually have the tofu, lemongrass, shiitake mushrooms and roasted chili dish. The first time it was great, on other occasions it was less exciting (perhaps less spicy?). I've also had the fried vegetarian spring rolls, their dipping sauce wasn't very flavorful... but fried anything tends to be pretty tasty. The interior of the restaurant is nice, very modern looking and service has always been good. 

An okay place, but not going to be in my regular rotation.
author: Jeremy S.

description: Ok Vietnamese food but there are much better around. Tries the classic spring rolls and they were below average, the green papaya salad was ok and I had a crab & asparagus soup that was good.
author: Petter B.

description: Great ambiance, great pick of different apps and entries, good for sharing, easy date night spot!
author: Kate M.

description:
I've been here a couple times, usually to grab food to go.  It's been a nice place to go on Fillmore, as long as you don't get bothered by the relatively high prices for not-perfectly-authentic Vietnamese food.

The Chicken Porridge is on the 7x7 2012 Big Eat list.  It's good but maybe nothing to rave home about.  At least not to an authentic Chinese/Vietnamese/Asian family.

The cellophane noodles with either dungeness crab or yuba (tofu skins) are also tasty, but once again, nothing special.  I just don't get excited about things that are easy to cook/prepare.

I have a usual item that I'll get to go from here: vermicelli noodles with chicken + imperial roll (with fish-sauce based dipping sauce).  I think it's only available during the lunch period.  It's light but satisfying.

The one thing to AVOID would be the "crispy salt & pepper squid" on the appetizer menu.  I dunno what happened when I ordered it last time, but it seemed like they didn't deep-fry the squid enough.  The squids just had a strong taste of flour, which was so overwhelming that I could barely taste the salt and pepper.
author: Jeanne L.

description: Been going to OTD since it opened ,walking distance from my place . Food quality has declined slightly in the last 6 months . Last night My wife and I had a early 5:30 dinner Res. .We walk in ,there are a total of four people in the whole place . The Hostess wants to sit us at a table that already has three people at it. I ask for a separate table for two which there are some set up. She tells us she will check with the drama I'd expect from a ten year old .Then tells us thats the only table she can seat us at. At that point we leave and dine elsewhere . I don't know if there is new ownership running the place or simply a really bad hire. Either way , take a pass on Out The Door. Too many great places to eat to tolerate bad attitude and declining food quality. Regards,John E
author: John E.

description: We were home sick one weekend and when you need quick comfort food nearby the chicken pho and rare steak pho did the trick!  Hubs picked it up and also ordered the imperial rolls - delish!  It may have been more pricey then your typical Leavenworth joint but sure worth the convenience.  And not bad for take out too!
author: Meredith K.

description:
Delicious! Black magic with the fried chicken being so moist.

Also, this is not the average Thai/Chinese joint. Where you get large quantities of decent to pretty good food. This is fancy delicious food in smaller quantities. This would not be my go to for lunch, but certainly is fine for something different once a month or so.
author: Heather R.

description:
I had the pleasure of dining here for two different occasions with friends; brunch and dinner. While I don't mind hole in the wall places, these days I prefer the blend of a good space, decor, service, and food. OTD manages to captivate me with the simple, modern decor, impeccable service, flavorful food, and open clean space. 

Once again, three seating options. A communal table, individual tables, or counter seating (by the kitchen or by the bar). The perk of sitting by the bar is the free wine samplings. OTD offers a wide selection of wine and beer so you have the opportunity to experiment while waiting for your food to arrive. 

For brunch, I had the chicken porridge as it is #56 on 7X7's The Big Eat 2011-100 Things to Try  Before You Die. Nice rich consistency and not watery like certain porridge. The chicken tasted fresh and good. I would love to have this on a foggy SF day as it warms the soul so this may be my next winter cooking project.

For dinner, we shared the jicama salad, shrimp in clay pot, and jasmine rice. The shrimp was slightly spicy and the best part was the shrimp head, an excellent source of protein. I recommend the jicama salad as it is light and a perfect appetizer.
author: Sophie C.

description:
Second time in 2 weeks! Food is so lovely and taste is excellent. Wait staff and manager Nord are all super approachable. 

A new fav!
author: nancy m.

description:
Jicama Salad- flavorful, Joyous and Exciting!

Rice Cake... Bla. comfort food at best. mostly flavorful and filling. would not order again.

Pork and Rice dish with egg, pickled carrot & cucumber- just o.k. 

The atmosphere and staff are lovely. The food needs to step it up to make it exceptional and worthy of price.
author: SF U.

description:
Overall excellent, if a little pricey. The beef pho broth is extraordinarily good, even when compared to what you can find in Vietnam or Little Saigon in the OC. The crispy imperial rolls are also extremely goodl-- especially when soaked in the delicious fish sauce that comes with them.

My only complaint is that they regularly overcook the beignets served for breakfast. Consistency is extremely important for a restaurant of this price range.

The service is usually quite good, but it's also on the cold and dour side...
author: Jacqueline A.

description: A stone's throw from the famed Chinatown this place could seem ridiculously overpriced but if you're looking for quality contemporary Asian cuisine in a comfortable modern setting with good service, this place is it.  You have a large variety of dishes - from small bao snacks to pho, sirloin and wontons, not to mention you get eat many countries in one sitting
author: Barndi K.

description:
As a cousin of Slanted Door, this neighborhood restaurant did not disappoint much like eating at The Slanted Door at SF Ferry Building.  Easier to get reservation and eat but boo...no bay view but...as always, the food is on spot, service impeccable/friendly/attentive.  Brought my daughter here (12 yrs old) not bad.  The vibe is mix of family, date, single, young, old...everybody.  Very comfortable.

Menu:
- Pan Seared Shrimp and Chive Dumplings, cilantro, thai chili-tamari sauce
- Crispy Imperial Rolls, shrimp, pork, min, peanuts, red leaf lettuce = THE BEST ALL THE TIME!
- Dungeness Crab, cellophane noodles, green oinion, sesame oil = THE BEST BEST BEST!
- Pan roasted day boat scallops, rau ram, tahi chili beurre blanc
- Shaking beef, grass-fed estancia ranch cubed filet mignon, watercress, red onions, lime sauce
- Valrhona chocolate pot de creme for dessert.

***Quality and taste = ALL Excellent***
author: Grace D.

description:
The food was so overseasoned and bad, we walked "Out the Door." Seriously, the only good thing about it was the fresh rolls. They were decent. Aside from that, our experience was unpleasant. The restaurant is a long box with concrete floors, hard walls, and hard ceilings. This might be trendy, but it makes for terrible acoustics. Even half-full, the place was roaring. We tried to go on another occasion when it was busy, and we again walked Out the Door, because it was unbearably loud.

Ordered the snow peas, and the lamb stir fry. Asked for low sodium. Peas were small portions for the price, overseasoned but edible, lamb was tough and overcooked. Sent the lamb back and asked for the chicken claypot. I can honestly say, it's the saltiest thing I've ever tried to eat. I started to feel sick after only a few bites. 

Prices are high, and I was pretty unhappy at this point. Feeling, hungry, sick, and ripped off. I just wanted to pay and leave, never to return. My girlfriend took a stand with management, and they didn't charge for the uneaten food, so at least it wasn't a total loss.
author: Brian C.

description:
we made reservations for a thursday evening and glad it did b/c the place was filled. the ambiance and the service was great. i like that the kitchen is open and you can watch the chefs cook. i thoroughly enjoyed my time there but just did not think the prices of the plates was worth it.. sooo i'm not coming back and going "out the door" 

shaking beef - this dish is good. but at almost $40, it's not THAT good. you can go to any asian/viet restaurant and get a similar shaking beef at a fraction of the cost and get a bigger portion. it's just absurd. and to think, yelp suggested i get this item. have you guys never tried shaking beef before?? don't get me wrong i've paid $$$$ for my meals before but only when i think the food demands that cost.

tartare - love sashimi so i love tartare. the crackers were good too.
eggplant - bland and boring. really disappointing
erin's cobbler - it was okay but nothing to rave about
author: Jen S.

description: This is my regular brunch spot, but I have a love hate relationship with Out the Door. How can the food and decor be so lovely while the service is so bad? They are consistently slow and disorganized. Coffee arrived after beignets, entrees all arrived at different times, simple requests for condiments were ignored by 3 people. The problem is the service flaws are not just occasional, they happen every single time. I'm still giving 4 stars for the great food and the fact that you can actually get a table here without waiting an hour. But seriously OTD, get your shit together! Also rice porridge with a poached egg is the cure all for anything that ails you.
author: Sarah J.

description:
My sister lives nearby, so we went for brunch. You can make reservations on Open Table, which is great.

The brunch menu is not your typical benedict fare. I couldn't make up my mind, so I made a snap decision and ordered the French Toast... 

HOLY SH*T! It was the BEST FRENCH TOAST OF MY LIFE. I'm not even exaggerating. I mean, it was life alteringly good. Brioche, Peach compote, Marscapone. The inside was creamy and sweet. It was an enormous serving, so there was enough to share the deliciousness with your friends at the table, but also enough so you don't have to guard it with your life as if it were your first meal in a century.

My brother-in-law thinks the french pressed coffee is really good. We also had Crispy Imperial Rolls and BBQ Steamed Buns - both good.

I will certainly be adding this place to my standard rotation of eateries when I'm in SF. Oh that French Toast. I was some right now. I'm not kidding. It's that good.
author: Abbey M.

description:
I give them a solid 3.5 stars. I just can't give them a full 4 because of the high prices for what I'm getting. I've been here several times now and the food is good. Papaya salad is yummy and refreshing, my favorite was the crispy noodles with seafood on top and they got rid of it!!! 
I went this past week and had to figure out what to order in place of my favorite noodle dish. The kind waiter recommended the Pork with pickled radish one and it was Delicious! It just bothered me that my mom makes a similar dish and I know it shouldn't cost the amount it did. No Asian food should cost as much and out the door charges, crazy! Anyway, the food is good and my friends like coming here so I go and eat and enjoy.
author: Karen T.

description:
The one time I came in, I wish I walked "Out the Door." Putting aside the fact that the menu is very limited and one page, the prices themselves are enough to scare one off. But I didn't let that discriminate me. I stayed and decided to give it a chance while the 2 other people I were with also browsed through their menu.

While the cooking was decent, I definitely won't be eating here again. The portions are too small for what I paid. I'd rather take my wallet elsewhere.
author: Shilo B.

description:
This was my 2nd trip to Out the Door and it was just as good as the first.

Managed to get in right away for brunch at 1:30pm on Sat.
Food here has been consistently delicious; I got the eggs in the hole and my friend got the 7x7 famous chicken porridge, both were wonderful.

Food left me feeling satisfied but not uncomfortably full. We got to watch the chefs making the food and it was quite a fun process.

Go here at least once!
author: Rachel R.

description: For me, this is way better than the super popular Slanted Door.  The Crab on cellophane noodles is one of my favorite dishes in SF.  Green papaya salad, Shaking Beef and Soups are good too.  Bulk wine.
author: Neal M.

description: The food is terrific - and I mean everything. Plus the service is wonderful. OTD is a home away from home as we go there so much. Big kudos go to Valerie for always being warm, friendly and ensuring there is superior service always. The restaurant deserves its success and stellar reputation!!!
author: Jackie S.

description: I have been a OTD customer for years and go at least once a month. No more. The service Friday was inconsiderate - and bad.  The bar was crowded at 8:30 PM ... but two tables ( one of them for two people) were empty. I was told they were taken but I would be seated there if no one came.  I was seated (despite my objections) at the bar across from the hot oven with the chef barking out orders for nearly an hour of a $40 meal (entre and wine). I had to ask for the server and water and just about everything else. When I left 45 minutes later (eat and run out), no one was at the tables. No follow through to assess whether I was comfortable at the very spot I said I did not want to be seated. Bad Attitude. Bad Service.
author: Susan H.

description:
My last yelp review was probably 5+ years ago but I felt compelled to log in and write Out the Door a 5-star review. I have been here for lunch and dinner. The first time was lunch, with my mom who was visiting from overseas. We had expected this to be another Asian fushion-y place that tend to over-season everything, but my mom was pleasantly surprised by their chicken porridge. 

Second time we came for the chicken porridge again, but they didn't have it on the dinner menu so we tried other dishes instead. We LOVED just about everything we ordered-- the green papaya salad was very refreshing, the pork loin dish was so creative and sophisticated, and the peach cobbler we had was great even we thought we couldn't make room for dessert.

The best part of our 5-star experiences was definitely the SERVICE. The servers were so nice and sincere in their service which made my mom felt comfortable and at home. We came here at least twice a week in the remaining month of my mom's visit to SF (hey... whatever makes the mom happy).


Decor/ambiance: chic, saw many people on dates, chair is a bit hard on the butt, yes at times loud when busy

Food: green papaya salad, chicken porridge, imperial rolls, cappuccino

Price: pricey but well worth the fine dining. Appropriate for any big city.

Parking: usually I found street parking within 2 blocks.


Just want to say thanks to Out the Door for being so wonderful. My mom loves you.
author: Mendo C.

description:
nice place. surely it is loud and not to easy to have a conversation. prawns were yummy...
and it is probably a $$$ location.
author: Ali E.

description:
Really enjoyed the hip vibe and decor. Food was great shredded chicken salad was exceptional, spring rolls fresh and excellent breakfast items unique and flavorful. Service was average but good quality made up for that.

By the way I ordered green tea and not sure of the brand but the tea pot presentation and the flavor was very, very good!
author: Mike V.

description:
* 2 weeks later * 

Like I said, another brunch visit was in order.

The storm last Sunday created the perfect weather to have a bowl of porridge. I was surprised how well made this was and at a Vietnamese fusion resto of all places! Thick, hearty rice (no watery soup here) with fried slivers of garlic, chopped cilantro and green onions, shredded chicken and a slight hint of fish sauce. It was even topped off with fried chinese donuts. Even at $8, I can't really complain, just the fact that I can get this hot bowl of comfort without having to trek to Chinatown AND in a nice ambiance to boot -- WIN all around.

Both my gfs ordered egg dishes, slow cooked egg with Niman ranch beef and crab scramble. Both of which were decent, both portions not large enough for incredibly hungry people. We supplemented our meal with steamed chicken buns and vanilla beignets. The buns were as good as last time but SKIP the beignets. These are more like corn fritters and had an eggy taste, not exactly representative of the more airy and light texture of a traditional beignet.

Service was pleasant but it was definitely more fun sitting at the bar than at the table.

OTD, keep up the good work on brunch and I'll keep coming back.
author: Janice C.

description:
super duper good!  

place is always busy- really typical lower pac heights crowd. 

love being able to just grab a seat at the counter or order a glass of wine while waiting for a spot (the santa barbara pinot noir is fantastic) 

I cant think of anything specific i didn't like.... so here are the faves! 

+ crispy imperial rolls - make sure to add the noodles and wrap them in the lettuce! 
+ spring rolls 
+ calamari
+ corn and shrimp soup - sooo delicious and not heavy
+shaking beef
+ lamb stir fry
+ scallops 
+ i love the corn w bacon side dish too

I only have gotten dessert here once because we're usually too full... but the peach cobbler with blueberry ice cream was just amazing. 

only reason it isnt 5 stars is because service is inconsistent
author: Shanna N.

description:
short form: about the only close to inedible meal I've had in SF for many years.   insanely salty.  only finished it to be polite to the person who I was talking to at lunch.  

and pricey.  many, many places in SF with much better Vietnamese food for half the price on the evidence of this one meal...   standard Groovy SF 2015 atmosphere...
author: Joe D.

description: One of my favorite weekend breakfast places. We always start with the beignets and vietnamese coffee set. I am a creature of habit and will either order the chicken pho or the chicken porridge and Imperial rolls, hold the peanuts. So, I love to go with someone who will order other items that I get to taste.
author: Ina D.

description:
Love the fact that Out The Door has a location in Pac Heights. The menu  has an authentic Vietnamese flavor but is still modern. The imperial rolls and the vanilla beignets are a must. I had the wonton noodle soup, which was good but my friend's chicken and rice dish was better. We went for lunch, and the place was really packed. I recommend getting a reservation just to be safe.

~A
author: Alex C.

description: We simply love OTD and go there every weekend for brunch. We have the El Segundo pale ale, spring rolls and the pho. I always have the chicken pho and my fiancé has the beef pho. We have had pho in other Vietnamese restaurants but OTD is hands down the best we've had.
author: Kyoko T.

description:
The chicken pho here has incredible broth. Almost as good as when I make it at home! =P Could use less noodles and more broth. Portion is just right, but will seem small to those of you used to the Tenderloin places that serve their pho in cauldrons. No one needs to eat that much pho in one sitting. 

Also tried the egg rolls. They were crispy and delicious. Served with a side of rice noodles, lettuce, fish sauce, and mint leaves. 

I came here for brunch. There's no wait during brunch, the ambiance is nice, and the food is so comforting. I'll definitely be back to try their banh mi, too!
author: Julie N.

description: Did not care to try the food after the sour attitude of the hostess at the front. I walked right out after asking for the manager only to find out that she WAS the manager- what pathetic restaurant management. From other Yelp reviews it seems other customers also have issues with the service here. OTD will never have my business again.
author: Catherine C.

description:
The food keeps me coming back to this place.

Pluses: Tasty food.  Great service.  Casual atmosphere.
Minuses: Pricier than you would expect (casual feel, upscale prices).  Parking.  Could be noisy... hard for big groups to hear one another.

Must order:
+ Chicken clay pot.  Savory, spicy, and sweet all at the same time.  The sauce is amazing.  Goes great on rice.  Couldn't stop thinking about it.  Had to come back the next day to have it again!
+ Dungeness crab cellophane noodle.  Great dish to share.  The cellophane noodles could get pretty heavy if you're eating this on your own.
+ Desserts.  They were all awesome.  
The Cheesecake was spectacular - rich but light at the same time.  
Pot de creme was excellent too - again, rich and decadent but you don't feel bad eating it because it's not heavy.  Very deceiving, really...  

Can skip:
- Shaking beef.  Normally a staple at Vietnamese places, but the beef was dry.  The portion is small.  It is the most expensive item on the menu and certainly not worth the $36.

The waiters were attentive, nice, and very knowledgeable about the menu. 
Wine list: Great variety.  More European than Californian selections.
author: Thomas L.

description:
This is right up the street (literally) from Ginger Broty's house. He and I decided to have dinner like civil siblings, and since Filmore is safer than the TL (whats up Leavenworth!) we met in his neck of the woods. As we were walking towards Filmore we saw this place. I had no idea what it was, and GB said he had always wanted to try it. So we went inside. 

I ordered the daikon rice cakes, the bok choy, and some brown rice. GB ordered the fried vegeterian rolls, spiced broccoli and some brown rice. All of it was delicious. 

I didn't know it was vietnamese food at the time, but I remarked to GB that whatever type of asian cuisine it was, it was what proper *whatever asian cuisine it is* should taste like. Perfectly sauced and spiced. Yum.
author: Emily D.

description:
I heart Slanted Door and OTD for sentimental reasons..

But I'll admit...I was excited to try this OTD location bc I had heard about their wines on draft...

Rolled in there Friday night..love the warm and neighborhoody vibe of the space..While I waited for my friends I ordered a glass of the Bespoke red on draft...a syrah blend..it was excellent..

The service was extremely friendly..from the hostess to the bartender. 
I noticed that the menu was a bit pricy than the other OTD location..and lacked some of the yummy noodle soup dishes..

The three of us were famished and ordered a bunch of dishes to share...Some of the highlights were the chili tofu and the claypot chicken. The sea bass was just okay. 

So why the three stars? One of our dining mates is a vegetarian..and that same evening the two of us who had the meat and seafood dishes had a violent episode of food poisoning :( I am hope it was just a fluke...but don't dare to try my luck anytime soon...
author: Mimi T.

description: This is one my favorite spots. Always busy but a good amount of bar seating and a great menu - the imperial rolls and the spare ribs are my favorites. I often take guests here as they have enough choice for most people and the service is always solid. ~$50 per person for appetizers, dinner and drinks.
author: Ash R.

description: I came here at 11:30 to get a table and the guy said the only thing that was available was the bar...but what I thought was weird is that there were about 5 tables open but he said they were all reserved so I left and decided to then call and ask if there were any tables for 11:45 and he said there was a table available....interesting! LOL
author: Star B.

description: Nice food but reasonably expensive and the noisiest restaurant I have ever dined in!
author: Lani I.

description:
I don't know why it is, but whenever we're in SF, we end up eating only Asian food; whether it's Chinese, Vietnamese, Japanese or Thai, (and Indian on occasion) it's the go to cuisine.  Maybe because it's so much more prevalent there, or I just go crazy as soon as I'm transplanted back into an urban setting...

It was heartbreaking when the Westfield location closed down...yes, it was inside a mall...yes it was located adjacent to the Food Court...yes it's soooo touristy....BUT WE DIDN'T CARE!!! It was totally convenient for us, (The Ferry Terminal is cool, but sometimes, you don't want to trek all the way to The Slanted Door near the whipping winds and cold damp waterfront...) the environment is always casual and easy going...and you can go to Bearded Papas out in the Food Court for a Cream Puff afterwards!!!! It's the simple things that are the bestl!!!

But enough griping, until they finish the higher end restaurant on the upper floor, we don't have much choice, but since we had never been to the location on Bush Street, we decided that we would venture out of our tourist bubble...(hovel...whatever...)

Located in Pacific Heights, Out The Door is the third venue of the OTD brands and is a tribute the original Slanted Door on Valencia Street.  The nearest intersection is Fillmore, a chic, trendy street that houses some of the on-point boutique stores in the city, on a hill no less....

The building and architectural interior is modern minimalism, a clear departure from your classic, slightly patronizing, Asian-esque interiors that's been bastardized and conceived in every iteration-to the point of comical.  Most of Charles Phan's restaurant departs from this tired approach, focussing on the essence of design with simple clean line and little adornment...I will say tho, the bent sheet metal banquette is a little cold....

Menu Roundup:

Drinks:           Blenheim Ginger Ale
                        Lychee Infused Iced Tea
Appetizers:   Crispy Imperial Rolls
                        Lotus Sticky Rice
Mains:            Mary's Organic Claypot Chicken
                        Banh Mi

It's always a tradition that we order the Blenheim Ginger Ale at Out The Door - the biting sharpness of ginger effervescence provides the liquid balance to the heavy, addictive, flavor saturated dishes we love!

Crispy Imperial Rolls (Cha Gio) with Rice Vermicelli Noodles, Mint and Peanuts
It's always good to start off a Southeast Asian meal with some rolls...and to treat ourselves, we got the fried version: Crispy Imperial Rolls with Shrimp and Pork! It's a ceremonial process, you take the Lettuce Leaf, place some Vermicelli Noodles and the roll on top wrap it up and dip it into the Fish Sauce and let the flavors fill your mouth with abundance...The fresh leafy vegetable crunch contrasts with crunch of the fried roll beautifully, along with the savory Pork and Shrimp with the tangy Fish Sauce, it's a scrumptious appetizer that will please any appetite.

As we had just posted out review for Kirin Restaurant last week, the Dim Sum was still fresh in our minds, so when we saw it on the menu, it had to be ordered.  Definitely distinct, the Sticky Rice soaks up the fragrance of the Lotus leaf, and with an all vegetable cast, it had a lightness to it that you normally don't get, and then with the Crispy Shallots and scallions on top, it added a Southeast Asian flair.

What I really adored about this Out The Door location is the proximity and view to the open kitchen; it's a portal into the creative collaboration of divine ingredients transformed by way of heat, caramelization and the knife...

And watching the Claypot arrive onto the counter from the oven, lid on, with steam spewing from the tiny hole screaming to be let out of its confinement just adds to the dramatic entrance as it makes its way to the table, it's contents revealed, fragrance and all.

This chicken dish is a rice lover's must have:  Baked Chicken in a Claypot Casserole with Minced Thai Chiles, Ginger in a Caramel Sauce, just a touch salty so as to require a mouthful of rice to compensate and sate the palate.  It's a slow moving catch-22, eat some chicken, need some rice, need more chicken, need more rice to eat more chicken...and so on and so on..it's a culinary Sisyphus...but without the labor...and the hell...(maybe not the best analogy).. Anyways, it's a delicious dish, despite my last description...

Another dish that is one of my favorites: the Banh Mi.  A culinary evolution between French and Vietnamese.  Lemongrass marinated Pork with Pate with all the Southeast Vegetable & Herbs, Shallot Mayonnaise and Soy...It's light, it's savory, it's so good!!!!

Now that we've eaten here, I can't imagine coming to SF without having my first meal off the plane at Out The Door on Bush Street.  And now that I know they even serve Breakfast, I can make plans to here at any time of the day!  


Ratings (Out of Five Stars)

Food:           4.5
Ambience:   3.5 
Service:       3.5
author: Alan M.

description:
This Vietnamese fusion restaurant was a change of pace for me in terms of decor and ambiance here in San Francisco. The interior is very modern, L.A.-like, which given that I'm from L.A., felt very welcoming. A lot of the restaurants here in S.F. seem to be more the homey, hole-in-the wall like but this restaurant is not the case. 

Though they got the decor, ambiance, and service right (I think), the food is what brings down the rating for me. My friends and I got the pork over rice, the sticky rice over sweet potatos and coconut milk, the imperial rolls (basically the fried spring rolls/appetizer), the chicken clay pot, and the glass noodle with crab meat... (can't remember the exact names of the dishes). I have to say the sticky rice over sweet potatoes and the clay pot was great. The pork over rice with the over easy egg was also very good (albeit very greasy and a bit too cancer-inducing burnt/crunchy). The glass noodle dish was really disappointing. 

The portions were very small for the price. The chicken clay pot is probably the best dish out of the ones we ordered, but when the server opened the clay pot it looked as though it was half empty, not sure why the portions are so little. 

Anyhoo, I'd go here again with friends if they insist... it's just - be warned - some of the food here is a hit or miss. Oh, and pricey. You're definitely paying a premium for the ambiance.
author: Elizabeth P.

description:
If you want to sit an an environment that is so incredibly loud
and if you want to sit on very hard cold seats. This is the 
restaurant for you. Otherwise expect to go deaf while trying
to eat and expect for your bum to go to sleep while you wait a
very long time for your food.
author: Louise A.

description: Got their banh mi to-go once: "lemongrass pork, pate, shallot mayonnaise, cucumber, pickled carrots, cilantro, soy" This is ridic overpriced but the meat is tasty, with a very nice barbecued flavor. In terms of flavor alone, this meat might be my favorite among other shops. Only comes with carrots, a thin slice of cucumber, and cilantro. Pate works well with the flavors. Sparse on meat though, only one layer loosely folded over itself.  Bread was the biggest letdown, not crunchy at all. The exterior was not soft but more like a shell that lost it's crispness, possibly due to sitting in a box for a bit. Toasting it in a toaster oven regained the crisp but it was drier overall of course. You get a small salad with your order, but I'd much rather just buy two different Bun Mee sandwiches instead for the price.  $13.41
author: Linus W.

description: My brunch experience here was OK, but I probably won't be heading back here anytime soon. I guess I expected more from the sister restaurant of Slanted Door, which I love. There really weren't a whole lot of breakfast type options for a brunch menu. I ended up getting the beef pho, as there wasn't anything healthy offered that wasn't seafood on the breakfast side of things. Disappointing! The service also wasn't that great. Our server was cold and almost a little rude at times. So sorry for taking up your table and tipping you. We put two cards in the payment book and before I could even tell him how to split it, he picked it up off the table and just turned and walked away when I was trying to talk to him. With so many brunch options, I wouldn't recommend this place.
author: Amanda R.

description:
The food here was good but nothing to really write home about.  A group of us came here after watching a movie at a theater nearby.  The service was good, our waitress was very attentive and offered some good an honest suggestions from the menu. Our group ordered the the fried spring rolls, shrimp and vegetarian spring rolls, fried chicken, scallop dish, and the crab and cellophane noodles.  I don't eat chicken but my husband said it was pretty good. 

Unfortunately I didn't feel that way about the crab and cellophane noodles or the vegetarian spring roll.  My mother is Vietnamese and I've grown up with great Vietnamese food on the dinner table nearly every night.  While I did not expect this to be authentic, I did expect to experience a lot of great flavors as this is the essence of Vietnamese cooking.   There were a lot of noodles and very little crab meet, and the flavors were just mediocre.  I was expecting something much more robust and I have to say it was on the blander side and somewhat dry.  

Our friends agreed with my husband about the chicken and liked the scallops as well.  The restaurant also have some pretty good beers available which I enjoyed. And their creme brulee was pretty amazing.  Other than that, I felt that the food and experience were average and a bit overpriced.
author: Virginia H.

description:
I went here for lunch with a friend on a Friday afternoon.  We had a reservation and were seated immediately.  We received our water right after we were seated, which I appreciated.  Our waitress was really friendly and never rushed us.  

After reviewing the menu, we decided on the following:
* Spring Rolls
* Chicken Claypot
* Dungeness Crab Cellophane Noodles
* (+ 2 Iced Teas)

The Spring Rolls were fresh and delicious with plenty of shrimp and a nice serving of peanut sauce on the side.  (I hate when places don't give you enough sauce, but this place wasn't like that.)  The Crab Noodles were nice, but I didn't think the dish had that much crab considering the cost.  My *favorite* dish was the chicken claypot.  The chicken was tender and the sauce was out of this world (and there was a lot of extra sauce for your rice).  I *heart* that dish and would highly recommend it if you go.

So why am I giving it only 3 stars?  Well...the prices.

I think the price point is too high.  These were relatively small portions and we had no alcohol and the tab (including the tip) came to $60.  I might expect to pay that for dinner, but not at lunch with no wine or cocktails ordered.

I'll be back, but I'll probably try the brunch menu where I could just order one dish and save a little $.
author: Kimberly B.

description:
This place is sexy. Sensual, minimalist decor is just my style. I especially love the open kitchen. A sure sign of no BS.

And thankfully, the food is just as slammin' as its looks! Yes, you can have your cake and eat it, too!

We ordered a slew of delicious delights. I was too busy catching up w/ long lost friends so left the ordering to the ones w/ experience. Everything that came to the table was hot & flavorful, and thoroughly satisfying.
author: Lans S.

description: Decent contemporary casual south east asian. Crab noodles and wonton soups were stand outs. The southern most table is brutal for brunch because youre blinded by the sun the whole time.
author: Mike L.

description:
OTD = Overpriced Trendy Dishes.

The price point for this restaurant is clearly $$$ and not $$.  The food is upscale Vietnamese, offering a modern take on Viet cheap eat rice dishes, pho, and banh mi sandwiches... at double or near triple the cost.

The decor and ambiance is attractive and modern; and the service was friendly and attentive.  And the food is good, but not at these prices when the cheaper alternative actually tastes way better. You're paying to eat in a nice Pac Heights, hipster friendly restaurant, and if you're okay with that, then OTD may be perfect for you.

Brunch dish run-down of what I ate:

Daikon Rice Cake ($9): Two fried cakes in tangy soy sauce (think taro/turnip dimsum cakes).

Banh Cuoun ($12): Four rice noodle wraps served with fish sauce dipping sauce on a bed of lettuce and bean sprouts, topped with fried dried onions.

Smoked Ham & Pate Banh Mi ($13): Not worth it. Could not taste the pate, high bread-to-filling ratio, not enough picked carrots (no picked daikon), with a fried egg, cilantro, and cucumber slices inside. Saigon sandwich this ain't. Comes with a side micro salad with julienned match-stick apple pieces.

Five-Spiced Grilled Chicken over Broken Rice ($14): Chicken was tasty, but the end pieces were dry. Comes with a poached egg on top, picked carrot shreds, and paper-thin pickled daikon slices. Broken rice just means small grained.

Beignets ($4): Four ping-pong sized beignets with powered sugar.  Good; think freshly fried donuts, but not worth the $1/piece price tag.

To reiterate: the food definitely did not taste bad here, but I don't think I will make a return trip of my own accord any time soon.
author: Mercutio k.

description:
Came here for brunch at 10:45 on a Sunday morning. We had reservations, but would have been immediately seated--plenty of tables in the spacious dining room. Girlfriend and I shared some vegetarian bun, beignets with Vietnamese Coffee, sticky rice with caramelized sweet potatoes, and the baked eggs. Everything was delicious, and extremely filling. Service was less than sterling, but not bad. Little bit too expensive to be a regular brunch spot, but it was a nice treat!

I know it's not authentic, but I do wish they had a vegetarian pho option.
author: Allison S.

description:
Make sure to double check your bill. Especially after the swipe! They swiped our credit card for $160 on a $50 check. We tried to wave them down politely and respectfully for quite some time. Some of the staff eventually noticed us, but they just stared at us and waved back... 

When someone finally came by, and we showed them the gross inconsistency, they said "oh they must've charged you for another party's". Well, duh. They came back with the correct charges for us to sign with a nonchalant "here you go". No apologies for their mistake. 

Food was good though. The service was also good until they realized they got all they could from us.

So just make sure to check your charges! Cause they don't! Or at the very least, they can be careless.
author: Katherine W.

description:
Being a student who frequents Fillmore Street, I was really excited when a friend told me there was pho here! I have had Vietnamese food a lot and I guess I have been spoiled by living near San Jose for most of my life. My party of three got here along with the usual noon lunch rush. I arrived here wanting one thing only: good food with good company. 

Beef Pho: really mediocre for me. The soup was really bland and even after adding two limes...it had pretty much no flavor :[ also very $$$ for pho.

Vietnamese Iced Coffee: REALLY SMALL - incredibly diluted by melting ice, and not enough condensed milk added. and my party was disappointed that they didn't allow the coffee to drip in front of you...it came pre-mixed. 

Imperial Roll + Spring roll: yummy!

Disclaimer: I know this place is not meant to be 100% authentic, and that it's kind of unfair to rate it like an authentic place. The decor is very nice as well but it wasn't enough to save it for me. Everything was just too expensive for Vietnamese food (we paid $80 total for lunch...). The only reason there are two stars is because the Imperial roll is DELICIOUS!! If you come here you must try it.
author: Vienna L.

description:
Out the Door is unique in that it has all the convenience of being located on Fillmore, without actually being located ON Fillmore. We came by here on a Sunday night, found parking in seconds, and seamlessly enjoyed good food, with no wait. Not too shabby!  

Food was pretty awesome but the service could have been better. I ordered the cod which was really yummy. Steamed in banana leaves, it was tender and fresh. (Plus it felt like unwrapping up an edible present!). I also had a taste of the fresh spring rolls which were great too.  

The atmosphere was nice - classy, dimly lit, but still fresh. Definitely a beautiful space with great interior design. (Don't worry though, if you don't feel like getting dressed up you can pass by without the fance no problem). 

I recommend it; don't get stuck on Fillmore, sneak around the corner for one-way dining!
author: Zoey S.

description: Went here with a group of friends for a birthday. The ambiance is simple and cool. I had heard complaints about the noise level, but we had no trouble holding a conversation. I had the Shanghai Soup dumplings (so good!), the soup (simple but flavorful), the crispy vegetarian rolls (crispy = super deep fried, fyi) and the chocolate peanut butter cream pie (yum!). Everything was delicious, and my friends' entrees looked great as well. The service was friendly and attentive. We all thought it was a good value for the experience.
author: Sara M.

description: When I need my slanted door fix without the hoopla I like this spot.  I've been for lunch and I have been for dinner and both times have been fantastic.  For lunch we did experience a pretty long wait but before we could even complaint the chef sent over some crispy imperial rolls and made everything better.  We had a vermicelli with beef dish as well as a lemongrass chicken and a side of green beans.  Everything was super flavorful and of course delicious.  I saw a lot of people ordering the soup which is what I will get the next time I drop in for lunch this winter.  Great addition to Pac Heights and I look forward to going back many times.
author: Kirsten M.

description: Even at 3:30pm on a weekday, out the door was packed and ran out of many items on their menu (boo!). I ordered the meatball sandwich and it was good, but not worth $9. I can't comment unfortunately on the other items since everything else I wanted to order was sold out (for reals!). The soups seemed like the most popular item - I will have to come back and try one of these next time. I personally think the quality of the food is a bit lower compared to the restaurant, but I prefer to eat at Slanted Door instead of standing against those higher tables to eat my meal. The atmosphere at the restaurant is A+ in my books. It all depends on the purpose of your visit to the Ferry Building!
author: Corrina S.

description: Because of a Vietnamese girlfriend, I've eaten at about 20 Vietnamese restaurants in The City.  This one just wasn't very good.  And since it's a "fancy" version of a Vietnamese restaurant, prices were rather high, too.  Not that we didn't expect that.  No harm, no foul, just not a very memorable meal or experience in general.
author: Mitori H.

description:
I was craving some upgraded honestly Vietnamese or Thai food. and I happened to drive past Out the Door so I decided this was the spot.  I ordered the Wild Prawns with Rice, the Five Spice Chicken Noodle bowl and spring fresh rolls.  The spring role were the best. The pork was the most flavorful I have ever tasted in a spring roll, but I was wanting mint or basil to bump up the freshness.  The peanut hoisin sauce was nice, I added samba because I like some heat.  The Five Spice Chicken was dry and over charred, very disappointing.  It didn't even taste like five spice.  The prawns were overcooked and mealy also over charred.  The sauce was good and the rice was delicious and aromatic.  I usually love all of their restaurants, but I think they are getting a bit lazy in the kitchen.

I will keep going back but the chef needs to check on what's leaving the kitchen.
author: Carey C.

description:
So here we go, as a Food critic person I notice everything. Venue is great and wonderful, the venue looks very clean and maintained. The worker that greets customers and seats people in is very nice but at the same time stated to us that we were not able to sit on the tables because of reservations
 Two ladies came in and stated to him that they wouldn't like to seat in the stools but rather have a table and the worker walked them in and have them seated in a table. I felt really bad because I didn't get that option but it's okay I'm fine with seating at a stool. We ordered our food and I really can say the food is good. The only thing I would say is the customer service is not so good. We ordered limes and soy sauce and the lady did not show up with our items at all. I understand that a restaurant can be busy but the customer service part of a restaurant is important because lucky to us this place is busy. I will definitely be writing an article about this restaurant on our next newspaper episode.
author: Jose R.

description: I had eaten at the Slanted Door a few times before discovering that Out The Door was (sort of) walking distance from my house! Since then, I have been a half dozen times, and haven't been disappointed yet. The staff is friendly and the food is delicious. I highly highly recommend the Daikon Rice Cakes, the Brussel Sprouts, and the Crab Noodles. Only cons - beer and wine only, and reservations on a weekend are kind of a must (if you don't want to wait for an hour). But that's pretty standard in SF.
author: Jessie B.

description:
Had to try this restaurant, as I've always been a fan of Slanted Door.  

Ambiance:  Nothing to write home about.  Clean, fairly contemporary, but nothing that makes you go, "WoW".  

Service:  The service here is excellent.  Food orders were discussed and explained in detail, orders taken and the food delivered in the proper order.

Food:
Chicken Soup:  Somewhat forgettable...a simple chicken broth with some white meat chicken, cilantro and other spices.  I regularly prepare the same with Campbell Classic Chicken Noodle Soup, Cilantro and some garlic and onion flakes.

Tomato Soup:  Excellent.  Very complex flavors and very flavorful, with plenty of fish.  I'm really not a tomato soup fan, but this was good....

Crab with Cellophane Noodles:  My favorite dish!  Nice, wok fried noodles, prepared perfectly with a good amount of fresh crab and spices.  Yummy!!

Lemongrass Chicken:  Not so good (to me).  Although there was a lot of good flavor, I'm not a fan of thigh chicken meat, and would have rather had chunks of breast meat instead.  Again, this is just my preference.  Other than that, the dish tasted good.

Price:  Overpriced.  For the location and ambiance, I think they are currently getting away with the high price of their main courses due to the "Slanted Door" spin.  I hope it can sustain....
author: Brian K.

description: OTD has many allergy friendly options and never disappoints.  The Pinot on tap is always good and the salt and pepper squid is awesome.  My wife and I come here as often as possible and they are always consistent with food quality and service.  This is one of my favorite restaurants in a city full of great ones.
author: Karlito S.

description:
great food.  Best shaky beef so far.  Trout with fennel was well prepared.  Imperial rolls were perfect starters.

Not a family friendly place as it states on restaurant profile.  Address is wrong too.  It was actually next door.  Parking is hard to find in this area.

Flavors are well thought out.  Nothing new here.  Good solid food.  Too expensive for Vietnamese though.
author: danny L.

description: God this place is good. Great buns, best spring roll I've ever had. The shredded chicken salad is terrific. Next time I'm trying the pho. It looked so great.
author: Jordan M.

description:
It was my second time going to "Out the Door" this passed Sunday. 
I went there with 2 of my girl friends after having a great experience there previously when I was on a double date with my BF and my friends. 

I am not vegetarian, but their vegitarian options are great. I really like their Yuba dish! Their Hong Kong milk tea is delicious, but we decided to drink after our dinner around 9 so all of us were up late that night. hahaha 

I really like pho so one thing I'd love to have is pho there, but overall I like "Out the Door" and will return there for sure!
author: Sayaha A.

description:
Found this place just roaming the neighborhood. Nice ambiance (though you can't tell it's Vietnamese or Asian anywhere) and the food was flavorful (got the chicken pot and jicama salad). However, the service was kind of slow and not very friendly and my $20 chicken pot came out half full...seriously looked like someone had eaten half of it and I got the remaining (they should probably get a smaller bowl or add more chicken). Also, I wouldn't recommend getting the lychee iced tea. It sounded delicious but my friend and I couldn't taste any hint of lychee. 

If you do end up coming here, sit at the kitchen counter - nice to see all the bustle. However, there are tons of restaurants along Fillmore so don't just settle.
author: Karen H.

description:
At Out the Door we had:

-spring rolls, shrimp, pork shoulder, mint, spicy peanut sauce

-louisiana blue crab, cellophane noodles, green onion, sesame oil

-mary's organic chicken claypot, caramel sauce, ginger, chilies

-fried chicken, toasted garlic, pickled vegetables, sriracha butter

-Four Barrel french press coffee

The crab noodle dish was raved about...but ours was overwhelmingly peppery. I tasted more pepper than crab. But their spring rolls were yummy! Portions lean towards small.

Overall, food's pretty good (especially their spring rolls, peanut sauce, and sriracha butter!!!) but too overpriced (therefore overrated in my opinion). I'm not inclined to dine there again.
author: Hana K.

description:
This place has a very nice atmosphere but the food doesn't match the ambiance and is overpriced for what you get.  Out the Door is supposed to be inexpensive, simple food, great for a casual dinner, not this place, the prices are basically regular restaurant prices. 

I was initially excited that we are getting some SOMA and Mission food coming to the area, but this place can go back to where they came from.

We started with the rice cakes, which I didn't like at all; the sauce had no real flavor and the texture of the cakes felt really mushy.  We then ordered the black cod and the lamb leg, as the waiter described it, and brussels sprouts.  The cod was nice, it was in a broth so it was very tender but again, not flavorful, and definitely not anything special.  The lamb looked like something from a carving station instead of the leg we thought we were getting, if I wasn't as hungry and on our wait to a wine tasting party I would have sent it back, for $22 I expect something of much higher quality.


In all, we spend $90 on two glasses of wine, an appetizer, two entrees and a side dish and felt like we totally overpaid for what we got.
author: Inga W.

description: Out the Door, yes, I walked right out the door after I was rudely treated by the hostess and the bar girl.  I have never felt inclined to slam a place, but I am not interested in going back to try the food.  Hope your experience is better than mine.
author: Veronica D.

description:
I have been to the Slanted Door and as much as I enjoyed it, the chaos of trying to get a seat and the noise was too much.
So I was thrilled when OTD opened up in my neighborhood.

I went with a friend and the two of us were famished and pretty much ordered one of everything on the menu.(It's not good when the waiter can't fit all of your ordered plates down on your table....)
Oink, oink!

I LOVE their steamed buns. And at first, paying $3 for one seemed sort of silly, seeing that you could go to Chinatown or Clement Street and pay $1.50 for a bun. BUT..these were delicious. And hearty and full of meaty insides, which is often not the case with the cheaper ones. We ordered spring rolls (awesome) and the fried egg rolls (YUM) and the beef satay as well (tasty and tender).

I had the papaya salad which was fantastic in its tangy flavors, and he ordered some noodles which he said were delicious as well (although it sounded more like.. "slurp..mmm..slurpy slurp..mmm..nom nom nom..."

I haven't tried their breakfast which is my next adventure at OTD, but I think this is a great place for a nice low key lunch or dinner with friends if you are looking for lots of good, fresh flavors and quality food. 

The service was excellent, and the staff super friendly. It is a little off of the beaten path on Bush St, so you can't see it from the main drag of Fillmore and its other restaurants, but that makes it nicer to have the less hectic atmosphere. 

Wonderful addition to Pac Heights and I can't wait to recommend it for my book club brunch!
author: Kathy K.

description:
All I can say about Out the Door is that is has good fresh squeezed orange juice.  Also, the baguette was warm and delicious.  

I ordered the baked eggs, which wasn't very good.  Perhaps I didn't order the best item on the menu.  It was healthy tasting for sure...kale, tomatoes, two eggs, and some chevre all in a baking dish, served with a warm baguette.  The eggs were over cooked, which didn't help the situation.  I wouldn't recommend this place for brunch, unless you have a big group and no reservation, as this place doesn't get very busy.  

I've had their take out for dinner before, it was OK.  It was pricey, but I guess it's expected for Pac Heights area.  I just feel like mediocre Vietnamese shouldn't cost $15-17 for some stir fried noodles.  That's just me!
author: Wendy S.

description:
Had a wonderful lunch here today. I was bummed when they closed down the location at the SF Centre. I've been to the Slanted Door at the Ferry buliding which had a great view and vibe, and I didn't realize they had a location in the Pacific Heights area- a lot smaller but the food was still really good.

We had the jicama and grapefruit salad ( which I never tried but was sooo good) and the crispy rice crepe for starters which was so delicious!

For the main course, we had chicken claypot ( which was sweet and savory),  grilled lassen trout with figs , and the dungeness crab cellophane noodles ( pretty heavy if you ate it  all by yourself) 

For dessert we had the coconut lime sorbet ( light and lemony) and the milk chocolate malt layer cake which I devoured.. it tasted like a cake wrapped in a snickers bar?

Great and attentive service. 

Definitely going to come back here, now I that I know they had a location here.

A must visit!
author: Marilen B.

description:
This review is primarily for the Spring Rolls.

Stopped in mid to late afternoon strictly for those darn spring rolls. Another 7x7 top 100 food that is....how shall we say....good, but less than awe-inspiring.

I'll go easy on the service since we stopped in at a bit of an odd time, 4:45 or so on a Sunday.  We seated ourself at the long community table and were not offered service.  I had to approach the bar to order.  Fair enough, given the time of day.  From that point on, service was friendly and prompt.

Ordered only the spring rolls this time around.  Not bad...but not great.  They had obviously been prepared quite a while in advance, so perhaps they would be even tastier and fresher earlier in the day.  As it stands, they were good, but did not stand apart from other spring rolls I have enjoyed.  They were well packed, with all the ingredients complimenting each other well.  The peanut sauce worked well too.

But...when you see a food on the 7x7 top 100 list, you expect a little more. There was no "wow" here, just nods of the head.  

Food: 3.5
Valude: 3
Ambiance: 3.5
Service: 3
author: Ethan R.

description: Talk about quality food, Out The Door has made a very big impression on me. Instead, it should be called "Out of this World" since that's how the food is. My girlfriend used to work their and from the sound of it, I just had to go. I never knew is would be such an elegant place with a comfortable environment. Food is a little pricey but well worth it since everything basically melts in your mouth. Finding it you would probably have a hard time seeing how they don't advertise their business with a huge sign on the roof, so be on the lookout and make sure you stop by.
author: Luis H.

description: Oh my God I love the food here. All of it.  Repeatedly had dinners here during my vacation, which is saying alot since not alot of meals to be had on a week long vacation.  When it's full inside, it does get quite loud which is annoying.  But the food was worth it!  Highly recommend.
author: Annie M.

description: Waited like 5 minutes on a Wednesday night. Got spots at the counter. Service and food was on point and can't wait to go back. The rolls are like summer rolls or hardly fried vit style spring rolls. I ordered the crispy crab/shrimp/etc roll which was very good but for $10 I wasnt crazy about it. I'll get summer roll next time. For the entree, I ordered the Neiman ranch pork chop.... AMAZING! It was so good and I will order it again.
author: PK R.

description: If you want amazing and CLEAN Pho this is the place to go! A hidden gem for sure. You can barely even notice it from the street. Service is always amazing and the food is equally as amazing. Their chicken bun is perfect. Salads are amazing. There is not a dish here that isnt yummy!
author: Sydnee T.

description:
I can't believe that this place was booked up for all other reservations except 5:30 tonight - granted it was Friday, but it was definitely nothing to write home about, nor would i ever recommend it to any of my friends.

The service & ambiance was good, but the food is stuff you can find at any Chinese or Vietnamese restaurant in town for about half the price and double the portions!  It tasted fine, but again, sooo not worth it.  Total disappointment... won't be returning.
author: Jennifer D.

description:
Okay so this place is supposed to Asian right? Meh. 

I only had two things, so I shall comment on those and the atmosphere.  

The interior is really nice. It's a great place to grab a bite for lunch, except two things. 1. We got there around noon, and as the place began to fill-up, we were screaming at each other by the end of the lunch. 
2. The service is meh. As in, waiter looked like he was writing the script of his dreams in his head the entire time. 

I had the lychee iced tea, which was ....ok. Just lychee flavored ice tea. It definitely was not OMG. Meh. 

Being a noodle-soup aficionado, I had the chicken pho. It was okay, BUT the one thing that really screwed with my head was THE BROTH WAS NOT HOT. The soup HAS TO BE BORDERLINE BURN MY TONGUE. However, the broth was LUKEWARM. UNACCEPTABLE. HEAT IT UP. 

That's all. The rest of the party had the five-spice chicken, which they liked a lot. I will be back to try more things as the menu looked interesting, but please

HEAT IT UP HEAT IT UP.
author: Christina L.

description: OTD is our favorite restaurant in the 'hood where two wildly differing palettes can be satisfied beyond expectation. The stand-bys never fail to please (grapefruit jicama salad, veggie spring rolls, crispy imperial rolls) and the Chicken-Pho is positively RIGHTEOUS!! The hostess Valerie is a gem and very adept at handling demanding patrons.  Prefer OTD to Slanted Door because I prefer not to scream at my dinner guests (noise-level off-the-chart).
author: Juliet C.

description: Nice place for brunch. Got the Hue-style rice cake on banana leaf. Excellent taste and authentic memories. Imperial rolls too were made to perfection with mint, lettuce and a great Vietnamese sweet-n-sour sauce. The crab soft scrambled eggs was a nice add-on, but not too filling. I would suggest sticking closer to the Vietnamese side of things here as that is the roots of this place. Although I swore never to go back to the Slanted Door once they left the Mission ten or so year ago-- and I've stuck to that promise until now-- I do have to say, this was a good decompression back into the world of Charles Phan and I look forward to a return soon.
author: Brian J.

description:
Went there for brunch and the food was super amazing! Got the pork-should hash while the lady got beef pho. Tried a sip of the pho broth and it wasnt the standard $6 pho watered down broth, this stuff had some flavor! I moved onto my delicious looking plate and damn...I ate there over 3 hours ago and I am still in disbelief as to how awesome the pork was. The shoestring fries it comes served on where great too! Lastly, I had to order some bignets because well, they're high class doughnuts. Already stuffed I had to try when while still warm and dizzam! Light and fluffy and good stuff overall!! 

Service was good too. I'll be back here for brunch and most likely try out their dinner menu soon..
author: Matt G.

description: Went for dinner, ordered vegetarian spring rolls, daikon cakes, scallops, and bok choy. Found the food to be very delicious and the dishes all paired well with each other. Great sauces and presentation on the dishes. Loved the trendy yet relaxed atmosphere, service was friendly. Great selection of hot teas too.
author: WhatsEating U.

description: Is it good?  Not really.  Is it bad?  Not really.  We've been to the old OTD in Westfield and really like the shrimp and pork spring roll and we ordered that here as well.  That is probably the best dish.  We also ordered the calamari which was good, stir fried lamb which was average, cellophane noodles with crab (nothing special) and fried chicken which was very average as well.  I feel the food is a bit over priced given the quantity and the amount we paid.  I think I would just stick with the spring roll if I were to come back.  The waiter, maybe I was a bit sensitive felt as if he had some attitude towards my wife which I did not care for.  Anyway as I said if I came back I would just order the spring rolls.
author: Pierre L.

description:
I like Out the Door. The restaurant itself is bright and open. Sitting at the bar adjacent to the kitchen is an enjoyable experience. The food is very good. 

The problem I have with Out the Door is this:. I've ordered pho here a couple of times and it was great, delicious, made with quality ingredients. However, it comes in a small bowl and inside of 2.5 hours, I'm hungry after eating it. Not mildly hungry, but starving and having to venture out to find something else to eat. 

For $12 I kind of expect that my hunger will be satisfied and won't want to have to buy a second lunch.
author: Horace A.

description:
Ladies and Gentlemen, Out the Door is  basically the Slanted Door's more mellow and approachable cousin.  I checked out the Bush Street location during a morning jaunt down Fillmore Street.  Being a fan of the Slanted Door, I figured that I'd give it a shot.  

The first pleasant departure from the "Slanted Door experience" was the fact that we could just walk in and get a table.  Try and pull that move at the Ferry Building--not gonna happen, unless maybe there was a kitchen fire or a bomb scare.  Upon cozying up to the uber-clean bar for snack service, I chose some belly warming chicken porridge.  I could hear the angels singing in the background, approving my choice.  I love congee or jook and this did not disappoint.  It hit the spot and the gorgeous sauteed shallots were perfect with the broth and chicken.  Nice work again Mr. Phan.  The menu was simple with lots of comfort food choices--right up my alley.

Amazingly enough, the staff was nice and even warmed up a bit after taking my order.  The service was attentive without being obtrusive.

I will definitely shimmy my ass back to OTD when I am back in the 'hood.
author: Rosanne D.

description:
I love being back in San Francisco for the variety of food, and this was just another one of those places that I had to hit to finish up the 7x7 big eat list!

I came here with fellow Yelper, Olivia Tanquilut, for a super late lunch (~2:00 PM) and surprisingly there were quite a number of people still in there. I HAVE TO SAY, I felt a bit out of place as the only Asian in a Vietnamese (should be called Asian Fusion restaurant)...HMMMM..

The place has a trendy, modern vibe which is all the craze right now with new restaurants, but I don't see that as much of a reason to mark up the prices on their rather simple foods.

(MEH!) Chicken Porridge with Chinese Donuts [$9.00]: Olivia and I had them split a single order into separate bowls for us and it was pretty filling. It was good, but for $9!? Honestly, I could find that on Irving (not even going to bother comparing it with Chinatown) for half the price with the quality still intact.

(MEH!) Five Spice Chicken Vermicelli *comes w/ imperial rolls* [$14.00]: Looked impressive, but that was not the five spice chicken I had in mind! (I tend to compare stuff like this to the normal Vietnamese restaurants I frequent like PPQ, Loi's, and Kevin's) The chicken was a bit bland by itself so I dumped all my fish sauce all over since it was in dire need of it.

If you have money to spare and really enjoy the Americanized ambiance with your food, by all means ignore my review. For those trying to scrape up money to eat at the other pricey restaurants on the list, TAKE MY WORD FOR IT! Stare at my pictures and pretend you're eating porridge/vermicelli from Irving and call it a day.
author: Stephanie Y.

description:
I'm always in here for the Pho or the Wonton Soup... at 8:30ish in the morning. Oh man, there is nothing like a hot bowl of Vietnamese soup early on a chilly SF morning. 

Service is fantastic, as always.
author: Evie D.

description: I don't know what happened OTD.  I have to say the service has gone way down hill.  Why did we have 3 servers and one main server who didn't really do anything.  Additionally why was there someone working with a broken arm? Sorry buddy-you can't work when you have a broken arm.  I think i have actually had better service at fast food joints.  Largest complaint is my friend was served her entree a good 10 minutes before my food came-chicken jook(chinese porridge) by the way.  I ordered a fried egg and good thing that came with her food but my porridge no where to be seen.  I have experience working in a restaurant and I do understand things get backed up. However, I never received any type of acknowledgement for the fact my food was so much later to the table until I asked about it. The porridge was luke warm and I did get a new egg.  I did not want to ruin my lunch date so could not complain as this really unfortunate dining experience happened but it really was a REAL mess. OTD seriously. Get your act together.  If you are going to over  charge people  for subpar Vietnamese food step it up and least pretend you care.
author: Rosie L.

description:
This location is much better than the OTD in Embarcadero, although it is more of a restaurant rather than a fast casual. The food overall tasted decent. We came during their brunch hours so we were only able to order from their brunch menu. I thought the marinade on the lemongrass pork was a bit too salty. The pho and payaya salad were good. My two favorites were the steamed buns and the beignets! The beignets were different from the beignets I've had at Cafe Du Monde but they were different and unique in a very buttery and tasty way. 
Service was very slow. Our waitress didn't bother to refill our drinks or even check up on us. She was sitting near us rolling silverware towards the end of our meal and still didn't bother to get us more water or anything!
I liked the two ladies working behind the line though (OTD had an open kitchen at the bar area). They were nice and friendly although they were busy making orders. 
I think I'll give this place another visit if I'm in the area. I thought the restaurant was cute and had a nice ambiance to it.
author: Twitney L.

description:
We went out to dinner last night at OTD and were blown away by the service and food.  They were really on the top of their game last night!  We called at 7:45pm and were able to secure a reservation for 4 by 8:30pm.  My water glass never emptied, everyone  was super attentive -- it was great.  Usually we go for lunch, and dinner was good.  

What should you order? The rice cake appetizer and spring rolls
Main Course? Fried chicken was delicious.

Again, service was exceptional.
author: Mel E.

description:
Let me start off by saying that I have been to 'The Slanted Door' and loved it, and to the other 'Out the Door' location on Market in the Westfield and also loved it.

As I live in the neighborhood, I was excited to discover this location up the street from me and to try it.

The decor is sleek, with great lighting. The food was pretty good-- or at least started out that way. However my friend had the shaking beef and was not a fan, neither was I. For 36$ it should be a melt in your mouth fillet, but instead had a lot of fat and was overcooked on the outside-- chewy almost.

The biggest problem here was our waitress, 'Whithney' she completely forgot 2 dishes our group ordered. When we brought this to her attention she quietly said sorry and asked what they were. Her reaction was almost vacant -- like we were the furthest thing from her minds. And she continued to set the dessert menus on our table. No offer to bring the dishes or a dessert or for anything complimentary. Pretty much no remorse. Bizarre to say the least. Especially when this place is just way too expensive for what it is. Yes it's sleek, yes it's pac heights, but our bill came to $120 for 3 people and we BARELY got anything in my opinion -- but really shitty service.

I may come back at one point, I may not.... I'd frankly rather go to SPQR, Delfina, Jackson Fillmore Trattoria, or any number of great restaurants in this neighborhood where I feel the value of what I am paying for and that the service level matches it.

This place says is called 'Out The Door' but is really just another 'Slanted Door' without the impeccable service level.
author: Sara H.

description: I went here a couple of month ago and really enjoyed the food. They make amazing clay pot chicken! There were some other great tasting items including the fresh lettuce wraps. However, I wish the portions were a little more substantial as the plates added up quick. I was also impressed with the fact they featured some delicious keg wines. Almost a five star, but not quite...
author: Robert W.

description:
The food here is excellent, but this 5 star review is for the Saturday morning brunch staff. They are fantastic, always friendly, helpful and generally are the reason we come back and have made OTD part of our usual Saturday routine. 

One of the reasons that this is even more impressive is that we have a two year old.  There aren't a lot of places with the quality of food of OTD that are actively friendly when you walk in with a small human, but the Saturday brunch staff at OTD is and it is so great.

They almost automatically bring kid friendly water, crayons, etc. They are always open to making kid-friendly food options of their menu (within reason of course I'm sure...though we haven't gotten a no or even a weird look yet on any of our requests such as small noodles and broth instead of full size Pho). 

Anyway, I'm going on a little long. So, I'll end with a sincere thank you very much. We really appreciate it.
author: Michelle I.

description: This is one of the BEST lunch spots in SF! Every time I come here the food is fresh, the atmosphere is pleasant, the price is very reasonable, and the flavors are delicious. You can't go wrong with the menu. It's all fabulous. Hot tip: book a table as it can get busy!
author: Sarah H.

description:
For some reason I really love upscale Vietnamese and Pan-Asian restaurants so I was already inclined to like Out the Door. 

The inside is very trendy with an open kitchen so that you can watch the chefs if you're sitting at the bar or as you're walking by to your table. It's a cool, rather unusual feel. 

My date and I split two appetizers, a dessert, a bottle of wine, and each ordered an entree. The portions were small enough that we both came away at the perfect level of full. Beware that just an entree will not fill you up unless you are not at all hungry. Since the prices are pretty high this knocks off a star from what would otherwise get 5 stars in my book.

We ordered:
+ Spring Rolls with Shrimp, Pork Shoulder, Mint, and a Peanut Sauce they claimed was spicy...it was not spicy by any means. These were good though certainly not anything spectacular. They were your basic spring rolls but with the addition of a small amount of pork shoulder. ($10)

+ Ahi Tuna Tartare with Sesame Crackers. The tuna was cut into larger chunks than tuna tartare often is, which I really liked. It made it seem more fresh somehow. I would get this again for sure. ($14)

+ Banana Leaf-Wrapped Petrole Sole with Mushrooms and a Cilantro sauce. This was SO GOOD. The portion was really small, but the fish was wonderfully moist and the hedgehog mushrooms underneath were fantastic. Mmm. ($24)

+ Fried Chicken with Sriracha Butter on the side. My date ordered this on the waiter's recommendation. It was really good, though a funny dish to have at a Vietnamese restaurant, in my opinion. 

+ Vietnamese Coffee-Cocoa Tres Leches. Tasty, but not particularly special. ($8)

In addition to the bottle of wine, we also ordered a St Peter's Organic English Ale that was served in a wine glass. It was really good, though for $10, I would say that this 4.5% alcohol beer was overpriced.

Overall, good impression. Though the price point will make OTD an infrequent destination.
author: Talia G.

description: Excellent service and just as good as the Slanted door. Everything is done with just the right amount of spice and added complimentary surprise. We think they serve the best squid in California (pineapple, five spice, garlic and jalapeño). The crispy imperial spring rolls are also so good. The table next to us didn't wrap them in the lettuce or add the noodles. They missed out. Then we had the tender cubes of filet mignon sautéed with red onions and a soy vinaigrette served with a pepper and lime juice dipping sauce (Shaken beef) which is amazing. We wish we could have sampled more-but we will be back. I would have given 5 stars but I missed the yummy cocktails that you get at the Slanted Door and it was a little too loud in the restaurant.  For the food-five stars.
author: Carol M.

description: I sat at the bar for a late lunch of beef pho.  The restaurant is small but really modern and fresh looking.  The service was fast and the food presentation was great.  The pho was very good, but not the best I've had.  For me, the broth wasn't flavorful enough.  For the price and convenience, however, it was well worth it. Also, there was a great crowd! I could see this scene slowing things down during peak times though.
author: Caroline F.

description:
The food is your typical Americanized Vietnamese food. Well prepared, tasty and fresh, if a bit too salty.   Four stars.  My party and I have usually been able to walk in (even on a weekend night) and get a table within 15-20 minutes.

What makes this place five stars is the service and the people. I've been here several times and each time my  ex +1 and I had sat at the bar, we've had such a great time watching the sous chefs do their magic at the wok and oven. They all seem to really enjoy what they do and their enthusiasm is infectious. They even shared with us some beignets they were making for their family (staff) dinner at the end of the night which we really appreciated. It was such an unexpected, sweet gesture and we felt like part of their family :)
author: Jenaynay W.

description:
Sure, this place doesn't fly like a traditional Vietnamese place, only because they aren't. Their pho has no MSG. That alone makes it worth trying. I'm a big fan of their chicken cabbage salad because it reminds me of how my mom makes it. I've tried other things like the spring roll and that's pretty good.

Quick tip, parking is plenty when coming here on a weekday lunch.
