author: Johanna P.

description:
Based on the hype about this place, I was expecting a modern fusion take on Vietnamese food. Instead, all it was was standard Vietnamese fare in a western setting. And it wasn't even exceptionally good Vietnamese food.

Just to be clear, the food isn't bad, neither is the service. But the overall experience was just disappointing as it seems like a restaurant with an identity crisis, and so you're never quite sure what you're suppose to expect.
author: Paul N.

description: I was looking forward to this dinner. The food was actually great, well prepared and flavorful. Springs rolls were some of the best I have had. Unfortunately the rest of the dining out experience I had was not as good, The resturant was very loud, not great for first dates. The service was very poor, the staff seemed very new and untrained. I will of-course blame that on poor management of the front of the house. The Host was also poorly trained and even rude. We felt very rushed during the course of the meal. The other thing that I felt was a missed opportunity was the drink menu. In a town becoming famous for cocktails the limit their alcohol to wine. They could have had Sake cocktails, Soju cocktails, wine cocktail, Beer. This is an Asian resturant why serve just wine? Wine is historically a poor match to Asian food. Besides think of the creative cocktails that could be created, hence a lost opportunity.
author: Garden Lover S.

description:
Banh cuon, pork and wonton noodle soup, lotus sticky rice

So delicious! All of the Vietnamese dishes (they have some that are not) seem pretty authentic and on the lighter side for restaurant food. 

Service is great and there was no wait! (Sunday lunchtime)

Wish the prices were a bit cheaper but not to unreasonable for the location, ambiance, and quality
author: Victoria K.

description: The food is delicious and I love the mood of the restaurant. Definitely need to make a reservation. This is a great place for a special occasion lunch or dinner.
author: Grace R.

description: Nice place for fusion dishes.  The modern layout is nice and clean.  The non alcoholic drink menu does demand a second look and is better then the alcoholic menu IMO.  The food is best ordered and shared for parties of 3 or more.  The fried chicken is different in a good way.  Be careful of the sauce that comes with it for those who can't handle heat.  The pork chop is amazing.  Nothing is bad on the menu.
author: Vivek D.

description:
Never disappoints ...  fabulous every time.

Chix clay pot
Imperial rolls
Need I say more.
author: Jesse L.

description: Lunch at Out the Door was disappointing.  OTD is a strange mix of chrome, marble, hard benches, and food served on Asian plates that my Gung-Gung and Po-Po used to have.  One server brought me water and asked if I was ready to order.  I wasn't.  She literally turned and took two steps when another person asked me if I was ready to order.  Um, hello, it's two o'clock in the afternoon and there is no shortage of tables.  What's the rush?  The crispy egg noodles w/ prawns, scallops, squid, carrots, broccoli, and shitake mushrooms sounded just right for my craving.  I thought I ordered a nice plate of pan fried gin mein.  Nope.  I swear the noodles were like those Chung King "noodles" in a can.  Do you remember those?  Yuck.  I guess OTD deep fries their egg noodles.  I thought I'd be good and order some green leafy vegetables too.  The menu offered pea sprouts with garlic, rice wine, & crispy shallots.  I love pea sprouts, so I asked for those too.  Yeesh.  Whoever cooked those must've flipped the order from the pan onto the plate, because the wet, soggy shallots were all on the bottom.  The shoots themselves were really tough.  I just left them sitting on the table.  No one bothered to check on me the whole time I was eating.  Come on, the place was nearly empty!  I would've given my experience at OTD one star, but at least my server took off the initiative to not charge me for the pea shoots.
author: Lorianne L.

description:
Four of went to "Out the Door" and it was an amazing experience. 

Service 

The service was amazing! We were shown to our table immediately and our waitress was Jeriel. She was attentive, knew when and how to ask if we needed anything but most of all she is funny and willing to offer honest opinions about the menu. I would ask for her as your waitress. 

Food 

The food was "off the proverbial hook." We had the daikon rice cake, spring rolls, Dungeness crab, fried chicken, and stir-fried Anderson Ranch sirloin. Three words: have the lamb! The food was really, really well presented and prepared. 

Atmosphere 

This is a nice smallish restaurant with a really cool bar in a really nice location. The prices are reasonable, the atmosphere really pleasant and there is plenty of street parking. Another great characteristic is that it is right around the corner to a few "happening spots" on Fillmore Street. 

We all decided that we will l definitely return
author: Chocoolate I.

description:
Great food and restaurant.

This is suppose to be the "casual" version of Slanted Door.  A bit more pricey than most casual restaurant.  Food is excellent, service was fine - nothing over the top.

The venue is very noisy due to the open kitchen.

Good experience overall!
author: Jorge C.

description: Great first visit! I loved the Pho and will definitely return.
author: Michael B.

description: Came here for brunch on a Sunday morning and was sat right away. It's a delicious blend of 'traditional' brunch and Vietnamese. Great vegetarian options. We will definitely be coming back here again!
author: Katie L.

description:
As I sat there staring hungrily at our waiter, it dawned on me that Out The Door does not take its name literally. 

My companion and I were hankering for some pho as we sauntered through Lower Pac Heights. Starving, we Yelped the closest Vietnamese restaurant; Out The Door popped up. The airy decor is lovely and I adore the fact that you can sit at the counter to watch the chefs whip up your meal. That's about all the pros I can say.

It took upwards of 10 minutes to waive down our waiter after staring unblinkingly at him. Not even bothering to ask for our drink orders, he seemed already put out when I asked to place our food orders. He excused himself for a few minutes before coming back and finally writing it down.

Our pho tai (beef) and pho ga (chicken) arrived about fifteen minutes later in much smaller bowls than I had ever seen pho served (especially at $10 per order). And the taste... I've never tasted pho like that. Bland yet over-salted; slices of meat that were speckled with an equal amount of fat; and lacking the rich complexity of a soup simmered overnight. It wasn't the worst thing I've ever put in my mouth but it deserves to be stripped it of its "pho" label. 

More so, they do not have condiments at the table. They only gave one small dish containing Sriracha and Hoisin sauce and a spring of basil between my companion and I. The waiter never came back to check how things were so I had to waive at him to ask for more Sriracha as he walked by... but he kept walking. He may have been busy grabbing an order or dropping off a check but simple etiquette, especially to paying customers, is not that difficult -- in fact, it's your job.

I noticed most customers during this Sunday afternoon did not have heavily Vietnamese dishes. I saw a slew of salads and eggs on the surrounding tables. Nary another bowl of pho in the place. Perhaps I should have drunk in the sight before I fed my appetite. 

If you want Americanized overpriced brunch, Out The Door will hit the spot. But if you want a more authentic meal that is double the proportions at half the price, you should probably amble on over to the Tenderloin (may I suggest Ha Nam Ninh). Your taste buds and wallet will thank you.
author: Cindy T.

description:
Determined to finish the 7x7 list before 2011 is over, I ended up at OTD on a Friday night.  Very fitting to the name, the line was just OTD, well barely.  Filled with anticipation for the chicken porridge, I finally got a seat at the bar after 25 minutes.  Upon sitting down, I immediately noticed the familiar kitchen setup to the likes of chinese fast food joints, with the woks and the long swiveling faucets.  The cook at the wok section just finished a dish of calamari, which was sent back after a taste by the head chef, I was somewhat impressed by the standards.

The waitress was very attentive and informed me that the Chicken Porridge is only available for lunch.  I should have checked with my fellow Yelpers before going.  Disappointed and yet hungry, I opted for the spare ribs starter and the claypot caramel chicken.  My expectation was Vietnamese fusion.  Unfortunately, the only thing that was fused together was the higher price and the not so authentic food.  

The ribs were tasty and tender but not very meaty, the taste of hoisin sauce was unevenly lathered on, covered with scallion sprinkles.  The claypot caramel organic chicken was underwhelming.  The sauce was thin and the taste was nothing special.  A good caramel chicken in claypot can easily be found in any good old vietnamese restaurant for 1/2 the price and double the size.  As a side, I had the corn with Japanese mushroom.  The mushroom provided a nice smokey flavor, and each kernel was knifed off of a cob, fresh?

In short, overpriced vietnamese food cooked in a chic decor.  The food is nothing special, and not very innovative.  However, I must go back to try the chicken porridge at lunch time to check it off the 7x7 list...........
author: Raymond W.

description: Still my favorite restaurant several years later. Although I no longer live in SF, I make a reservation every time I'm in town. I love the food, and the service is always top notch. It's just a great dining experience!
author: Kyla L.

description:
Taking away three of our five stars!!! We used to love you guys so much. And used to think you were one of the best places on Fillmore Street! I am revising my review (not in haste by the way) My wife and I just had yet another sub standard delivery from you guys. That's it for us.. it cost way too much money to get food delivered as it is, and to have complete (important parts) of our orders either wrong, incomplete, or missing isn't going to keep you a five star rating with me. Even when we request things in our notes sometimes it's like nobody even reads the notes? But besides that you are changing things as well. My wife's chicken salad was so tiny compared to how it's always been! (For years it was a generous salad) then my dish just now was missing the fried egg on top the rice. My pork was dry, and the soy style sauce was completely different and so full of jalapeño or something? My throat's still on fire and lips feel swollen! Ridiculous changes and leaving the egg out is not cool, I was expecting that egg in my meal.
'Out The Door' is dropping the ball on what was always a 'fine oiled machine' we are very, very disappointed in you.
author: Kirk M.

description:
love how the place is designed - the furniture, the bar. Love the wine on tap. it's clean and slick.

i would go back get a glass of wine on tap and spring rolls ! haha!
author: Jippers C.

description:
Cute. Tasty. Cool decor and vibe.

went here with a few girlfriends and the food was very good. my favorite part of the meal however was this $6 Barbera on the wine menu, which i proceeded to order 3 glasses of. heavenly, light and cheap!

my only pointer is the staff is totally aloof. not enough for you to dislike them, but in a weird preppy hipster way. we would mostly ask for things twice, but they were just so "cool" in response, you couldnt really get mad

the bill was around 100 bucks for drinks and food for our little caravan of 3. pac heights CAN deliver!
author: Carolina S.

description: The best pho! Chicken pho is amazing! The broth is a real meat broth no msg. Chicken salad is light and delicious! They use organic ingredients. We always leave here satisfied and happy.
author: S H.

description:
My favorite place for spring rolls EVER. 

This delightful gem has fresh ingredients and tasty food. I've enjoyed everything I've eaten here.  The spring rolls are to die for.  The lychee tea is tasty, but only has a hint of lychee in it.  I highly suggest for lunch or a fun casual dinner.
author: Michaela S.

description:
Everybody knows about The Slanted Door, and usually it's booked solid, so it can be tough to get into. What was a surprise to me was finding out that there are three different restaurants affiliated with it called "Out the Door", which are much smaller and apparently oriented towards take outs for the neighborhoods they're in.

To be honest, my experience here was just OK. While the decor and atmosphere were nice, the food wasn't anything life changing, and the service was average. Both our dishes were WAY over-salted, and frankly overpriced for the quality of the food. The spicy sliced lamb that I ordered was cooked just right (medium-rare), but it was hardly spicy - I cook with Chinese red peppers all the time, and it only takes a couple to make a dish rip-roarin' hot; this dish had easily three times as many red peppers (and jalapenos!) on it and I'd call it mild spicy at best (hint to the chef: if you want to make it spicy, crack the peppers open and let the seeds simmer in the oil for a couple moments before you mix in the food).

The wait staff was friendly and courteous, but slow and didn't really pay attention to us. I found myself waving down our waitress several times while she was talking with other staff about whatever, and she seemed oblivious to us. Their conversations looked work related, not idle chit-chat (thankfully), but seriously, at least every couple of minutes look up at your seats to see if people need something... we ended up getting other servers twice to get what we needed. It shouldn't have to be that way. However, kudos to our waitress for being friendly and letting me have a taster of a $12 glass of pinot before I ordered it - many places won't do that.

On the plus side, the location is good, especially for anyone that's going to be in and around the Fillmore and wants to stop in for a bite to eat. Don't take someone here on a big date, there are much better places to go for the money you'll fork out. But if you're looking for something to fill you up that's not bad, give it a try. Just be sure to ask them to lay off on the salt.
author: Gregg G.

description:
Wanted to try this place after rave reviews from some people at work. 

Vibe was good, and so was the food

Ordered the dungeness crab noodles, fresh spring rolls with spicy peanut sauce and chicken claypot

Staff are super friendly, wine list is excellent. Hard to find street parking though.
author: Chary E.

description:
The food was delicious and service was excellent. I went with 6 other people. The two stars it doesn't get is because of the post-meal. After dessert was cleared off and the check arrived, we became sort of non-existent. Mostly I'm upset that our leftovers disappeared. We specifically asked to have the food wrapped up. It never came. When we asked about it, we were told they didn't know we wanted it wrapped up-- oops, sorry. It's not that they didn't know, they just forgot, or the server failed to communicate it to the busser, or the busser failed to understand. I was really looking forward to those leftovers! 

On a good note, the food was very flavorful, even with a nice variety of vegan options. I'd go back, but I was pretty upset about my leftovers-- enough for probably 3 meals!
author: D R.

description: I have previously had dined at the old OTD in the Westfield on Market, but not at this location.  OTD never disappoints.  I had a wonderful lunch here - everything tasted great, was fresh, and came pretty quick.  Good service.  Great atmosphere.
author: D B.

description: AWSOME food! Friendly staff and an open kitchen. You can sit at the bar and watch the show. Fresh and clean!
author: J L.

description:
The restaurant is called Out The Door and that is exactly where I should have stayed. After a long day of work and class, my friend and I were both feeling under the weather and decided that a hot bowl of pho was exactly what we needed to feel better. Using my ever so handy Yelp app on my phone, I found a couple of vietnamese places in the hood and decided to check out OTD because of the mostly favorable reviews and close proximity to my apartment.

As a vegetarian, I am used to being persecuted because of my "lifestyle" -- even in 2010, so many restaurants are vegephobic. Still, the lack of effort from the OTD staff was alarming to me when I asked for what I thought was a simple request. Ideally, vegetarian pho would be made with vegetable broth, but I'm a realist and I eat at many hole-in-the-wall non-english-speaking vietnamese restaurants and I know that the majority of those places probably bring me pho prepared with beef or chicken stock -- and you know what, I'm ok with that. I'm all about compromise: you take out the meat, I'll deal with the beef broth.

HOWEVER, unlike Fergie, OTD refused to meet me half way, which left me more than a little disgruntled. If your food is prepared fresh, there is no reason why it can't be prepared without meat, yet I was told that the staff "didn't have time" for my request. RUDE.

So I was subjected to trying to form a meal out of the various vegetable sides, none of which refreshed my struggling immune system like a hot bowl of pho would have. In addition, it was unnecessarily expensive and portioned so small that I shed a single tear, not unlike the tv commercials where the native american guy sees all the litter in the woods.
author: Wayne F.

description:
Came here on a sunday - promised a 15min wait, then a 25min wait... turned out to be an hour and 45min.  Major points off the hostess, who had a terrible attitude and was completely non-communicative.

The food itself was good (though still pretty pricey for what you get).  I had the slow-poached eggs, nicely cooked with well-flavored pieces of beef.  We were given a complimentary side of sticky mango rice for our wait (which makes this experience a little better than it would've been otherwise), also good.  The vietnamese coffee was delicious, probably because of the condensed milk.

I still need to go back again to try the chicken porridge (7x7 list) but generally not an extremely positive experience that was neutral at best.
author: Judy L.

description:
Good food but WAY overpriced. We had dinner here consisting of the following:

papaya salad (sort of smallish portion)
1 glass of wine
1 bottle of beer
imperial roll appetizer
black cod entrée
caramelized prawn entrée
a small bowl of brown rice 
total with tip = $102.00  USD!

Most of you reading this will not know me, but let me tell you I am not a cheap person nor am I swayed by cheap or thrifty dining.  I will gladly pay big bucks for a meal that is worth it on some level.  OTD fell short on many levels.

My black cod entrée was definitely delicious, but NOT worth the $24 and the rest of the meal was tasty enough yet grossly overpriced.  

The menu is your run of the mill SF Vietnamese-ish menu, not too creative to warrant the high prices nor the relatively long wait for your main dish after the apps come out.  

Dont get me wrong, the food tasted good but there was not enough of it and you leave feeling kind of...raped.
author: Nilu r.

description:
Slanted Door is one of my top 5 favorite SF restaurants, and I've been lazy about not visiting OTD since it opened up in Pac Heights. A few weeks ago I checked it out on a whim and was impressed. For all aspiring chefs, I defintely recommend a spot at the bar where you can watch them whip up all the dishes. It took some serious restraint to not hop over the counter and eat all of the spring rolls waiting to be served.

As for the food, there's a lot of overlap between SD and OTD. It's an opportunity to have some of your favorites but not break the bank on a full-on crazy meal. The spring rolls and papaya salad are the exact same as downtown, just as delicious. 

Service was friendly and like I said, sitting at the bar was relaxed and fun. I've been wanting to go back for their mid-afternoon snack menu and hopefully will do so soon.
author: Jonathan G.

description:
Thanks to a great family friend treating us to lunch, my boyfriend and I had the pleasure of dining at OTD today. My deal with vietnamese style cuisine is that if I'm paying more than $6 bucks for a pho soup, I expect some kind of wow factor in the food, or the service and decor to be top notch.

The restaurant is very chic and modern looking, but casual enough that the family with children at the table next to us were not out of place. The food was standard but good. There were a lot of items on the menu that looked appetizing, but we stuck to soups (perhaps due to the rain outside).  I enjoyed my shrimp and pork wonton soup, and would recommend it.

The reason I probably won't come back to OTD was because of the service. Nobody came to greet us when we entered, so we started walking towards an empty table. That's when we were helped. We had several different waiters, and none of them were friendly or personable.  We had to stop someone to order an extra lemonade because the first waiter left before we finished ordering. Overall, the waitstaff seemed hungover, careless in their attitude, like we were bothering them, and too out of it to take their job seriously.

This place has potential, but I just don't see the appeal of paying a higher price for Vietnamese staples unless the atmosphere and vibe are going to be more than decent.
author: Roxane W.

description:
Don't get me wrong - the food at OTD is more than decent and you have to appreciate how hard the kitchen staff works. But that's where it stops - because the management at OTD cares not a whit about your opinions, real level of satisfaction, what you will tell others about the place and whether you will ever return in this or the next lifetime.

Specifically: after multiple visits to the restaurant, both as a couple and with friends, my wife and I got tired of never finding a wine on the list that wasn't acid, bitter and generally more of a pricey virtual vinegar than a nice culinary compliment. Each time we've politely asked for at least one selection that might please a less aggressive palette.  Each time we've been told "the chef has chosen these wines to pair with the food and that is that."

Personally, unless "chef" is paying for the meal out of his own pocket, I get very tired of hearing "what chef wants."

So last night we brought our own which was fine - until the bill showed up with a hefty $25 corkage fee. By way of reference, according to "Corkage for Dummies" (www.foodandwine.com/articles/corkage-for-dummies_"...corkage fees seem lowest in San Francisco and Los Angeles... on average, $10 to $12". 

I asked to see the manager who was entirely and immediately dismissive. I asked him if he viewed the surcharge as reasonable and the answer was "that's our policy."  I pressed a bit saying "don't you think this is a bit greedy?"  Again, stone wall indifference.

Perhaps that attitude is rooted in the arrogance of present popularity.  If so, as the novelty of the concept wears out, a bit of empathy and warmth might creep out to replace all that icy indifference.

Here's the deal.  I've been there, I've done that and I'm not getting ripped off again.  As my wife said, as we exited, "we are so out the door."  Permanently.
author: Jef L.

description:
4 stars are for the food, but it is definitely a bit pricey for what it is.  You basically pay close to Slanted Door prices, but it doesn't have the Slanted Door magic/ambiance.

Part of this is expectations: the "Out the Door" in the Ferry Building (the original one that is literally a to go stand at the back of the regular Slanted Door restaurant) has quick, relatively healthy options priced appropriately.  Honestly, I think Pac Heights could have used that style of an Out the Door more than this one, but I am not complaining whenever new food options open up.
author: Mike G.

description:
Yum!  Great wine on tap, yes on tap and great wine.  Seems like an oxy-moron but its true!

Great food, cool and friendly staff.

Go here.....
author: Alexis B.

description:
Ordered food via Postmastes (awesome service) from OTD today.  Love Postmates, awesome service.  Ordered the Crispy Imperial Rolls and the Grapefruit Jicama salad.  Start munching on my salad, and as usual quite enjoyable.  A few bites into the salad something catches my eye.  It was a green, spotted, antenna headed bug crawling it's way through.  My friends, a BUG.  

So I call Postmates, and they agreed - YUCK, and said they would call OTD to get me a refund.  The manager at OTD says they won't provide a refund.  They said they would put my name on the "IOU" chalkboard for a credit in the amount I spent (what all do they do to have an IOU chalkboard?!).  I had a live BUG in my salad: what interest in the short term do I have in going back to the restaurant?  

My rating is for two reasons.  CRAPPY customer service by management - a $20 credit and they could have had a satisfied customer.  Second - a bug in my salad, gross.  

Restaurant not worth the hype - other great places to go in the area.
author: Kristen B.

description:
Papaya salad for DAYS... no for a lifetime if possible.

Could I love this place anymore? Recommended to me by my lovely San Franciscan friend, I loved every single dish my table had ordered. Not to mention the awesome guava juice we got too.

If you didn't get it already, my favorite was the papaya salad, oh man does that chef know how Vietnamese cuisine or what... Also the spring rolls were great! Portions were smaller than my preference, but keep in mind this is by no means a whole in the wall. We had ordered the cellophane noodles with the dungeoness crab because it was on the "100 Things to Try Before You Die" and it did NOT disappoint. Dad, no disrespect but the chef at this joint outdid you...

The atmosphere was very relaxed, definitely a place for casual lunch dates. It had a very nice minimalist design which I appreciate. Less is more. Simplicity is very aesthetically pleasing. Moreover, there is a lining of benches against the wall (NOT COMFY) and just a row of seating along with some bar stool seats near the entrance.

The service was GREAT. Friendly, speedy service, and great suggestions as to what to order. 

Thank you. Come again.
author: Jimmy H.

description:
I really like the Slanted Door -- when someone else is paying -- and I enjoy the food at the Out the Door in the Ferry Building, so I was excited to try the Out The Door in Pac Heights.  I've had the Chicken Porridge a couple of times after it was included n the 7x7 list of 100 things to eat in SF, but I hadn't eaten a full meal there until about two weeks ago.  

I went in with my wife for a quick dinner, and I was just surprised that the menu looked like a smaller, pared-down version of the Slanted Door menu.  The prices were the same, but there were just less options.  We had the spring rolls, shirmp fritters, and the claypot chicken to share.  All the food was good, but not great.  The Vietnamese Iced Coffee my wife got was not that good either.  However, they were still Slanted Door prices without the Slanted Door ambiance.  What I like about the Ferry Building Out the Door is the other types of Vietnamese-inspired foods -- buns, soups, salads -- that are cheaper than Slanted Door, but I don't see what's so special about this location.  

I will probably go back in the future for the porridge or other breakfast / lunch items, but not for dinner.
author: Pilan C.

description:
Apps:
Consommé with dungeness crab - crabby, salty and tasty. 
Vegetarian Spring Rolls - fresh, tasty for what they are, and best smothered in peanut sauce.

Mains
Shaking Beef - overpriced at $36 for maybe 6-7 chunks of filet, overcooked at medium to med. well. 
Guisti farm fried brussel sprouts - not shabby, but nothing to write home about. I was expecting a litlte more crispness and caramelization given the friedness. 

Service: Ok. Good plate clearing sensibility, but little secondary follow-through on empty wine glasses that sat empty for 20 mins. Don't you want a higher check total so you can get a larger tip? No? This is something that has always amazed me about restaurant service in SF in general...total laissez faire approach from servers who can't be bothered to engage with their tables except when absolutely necessary. 

Perhaps the cushy minimum wage mollifies their urgency to attend to their tables? Ahdunno...but, for the two years that I served, I busted ass and hustled to bring home as much bacon as I could, which meant engaging my tables, establishing a rapport and making sure wine glasses stayed full. 

End rant :).
author: Jaime S.

description:
When I was 5 years old, my mother threatened me into joining the "Clean Plate Club" by telling me that "every uneaten grain of rice on your plate is a pock mark on your husband's face." She planted the seed of what later became a deep-rooted fear of all things white and starchy. I was the laughing stock of my Chinese family, but I stuck to my guns, believing whole-heartedly that I would show them all when I finally introduced my smooth-complexioned betrothed and invited them to a wedding that featured nary a grain.

Then came the unfortunate confluence of 2 life-changing events:
1. The release of 7x7 Magazine's 2010 list of "100 Things to Eat+Drink Before You Die"
2. My move to Fillmore Street, in close proximity of both Out the Door on Bush and my parents house

I had visited Out the Door for dinner before, and had left overwhelmed with conflicted feelings that resembled a dialogue a little like this:

- Wine on tap (including a $4 a glass sauvignon blanc) = Good
- Said tapped wine is served out of beaker-like containers that make me feel smart (well, at least somewhat scientific) = Even Better
- Pricey, average-tasting shaking beef = Bad
- Walking distance of my apartment and easy to get a seat = Good
- Never able to get a table and always find myself relegated to the bar = Bad
- No hooks for purses underneath said bar to which I am always relegated = Very Bad

Conflicted.

But my mother wanted to go for brunch, and what my mother wanteth, she getteth. After taking a seat (at the bar. BAD.) I looked at the menu and saw...*it*. I had memorized that list like a college freshman memorizes the words to High School Musical (in secret, burdened by a curious mix of shame, thrill and nostalgia). Number 55 on the 7x7 list "Chicken porridge for breakfast at the Bush Street Out the Door." 

It was breakfast. I was at the Bush Street Out the Door. And, most importantly, the opportunity was presented to show *her,* the woman responsible for a 2-decade long acrimonious relationship with a carbohydrate, that I. Did. Not. Care. (Either I Did Not Care or I was SO DESPERATE to work my way through the list that I was fully prepared to gamble my husband's complexion for bragging rights).

I leapt. I ordered. I tasted. I slurped. I gobbled.
It was salty, mushy, savory goodness in a bowl.
I was warmed.
I left nothing.

And so I will eat rice, provided that it is served to me in a large mushy bowl at this Bush Street location. Because I know for sure, that no grains shall remain, and my husband shall be blemish free.

Suck it, mom.
author: Amanda F.

description:
Some time ago I went to Out the Door for lunch and found it to be a poor value.  This time I went for dinner.  It's still not a great value.  And despite being a sibling of the Slanted Door I found that it doesn't have the vibe of its parent.  The food also isn't quite so good as the Slanted Door although the pricing remains high.

I started with the green papaya salad.  It was good.  Quite good if pricey.

Next salt and pepper calamari.  There was plenty of salt and pepper on the plate.  Also chili peppers.  The calamari were nicely breaded, not at all greasy, but some of the seafood was chewy, a bit tough.

Finally, stir fried lamb with onions and again chili peppers.  The spicing in this dish was very similar to that of the calamari.  A bit too much for me, although probably not for you.  The lamb was tender but hard to taste above the spices.  I just wished there was less spice and more lamb.  

An hour after eating I had heartburn.  The part of that due to the spiciness of the food probably won't be a problem for you.  The part of that due to the priciness of the food will probably affect you as much as it did me.
author: David D.

description:
Went down to get some clothes for a party and the guy recommended me this place. So I went down here and... here I am!

It's a nice place, I liked the look of the interior; very modern. So I sat on the bar and that's when I ordered the crepe starter, spring roll and some noodle thing with prawns. The crepe was actually really big for a starter, but I did enjoy it and finished it. So was the spring roll, another okay meal to have for a starter.

The let-down, sadly, was the noodle. I thought it would be with soup and all, but instead, it was a bowl of dry noodles, some veggies and the prawns. I decided not to eat all of it and waste money because it was like... eating a salad. Salad=starter for me. StarterEntrée.

Just ask if it has soup before ordering!!! But it was good (other meals)
author: Bryan S.

description: Pricey but good Vietnamese cuisine. Acoustics make the place noisy so don't plan to come here for an intimate evening unless the intimacy entails yelling.
author: Trang H.

description: So a friend had recommended it.  I was running errands and called for take out.  My choice was the Chicken Pho with spring rolls.  I must say everything was so fresh and delicious.  There were a lot of fragrant ingredients for the pho.  The spring rolls were great as well.  The inside of the restaurant had a sleek hip atmosphere with marble tables.  The kitchen was open and it reminded me of Momofuku noodle bar in NYC but a bit more aesthetic.  Would go there again.
author: A K.

description:
I have been in SF a year now and this is the best food I have had in the city. I know, I know, everyone says SF has great food.  Well, here's what's working against me: I am vegetarian, I don't like paying $17 for a vegetarian meal that I know cost $0.46, and I am from Portland and our food is just plain better. (Sorry SF, you have better weather!) I didn't even realize I liked this place that much until friends from out of town came and this was the only place I was willing to take them to, as I knew everywhere else I have been would have been a disappointment. 

Given those considerations, this is the best food I have had: Decently price, fresh, flavorful ingredients, healthy concoctions, a variety of options, clean, great ambiance, and good service.
author: Sarah S.

description:
Started out with some questionable hostess experience but I soon forgot all about it when the DAIKON RICE CAKES touched my lips. I am from Taiwan and basically grew up with these things and the OTD rice cakes brought me back, all the way back... 

We also had the yellow tail appetitzer, which was pleasant but a bit pricey for 4 very thin pieces of sashimi.. at $14!! 

The scallops should marry the fish sauce, they were a perfect match!! what a refreshing combination :)

Crab cellophane noodles was a bit rich, but flavorful. 

One thing i loved about the place is the sensible serving of the food. We left happily stuffed, but no where near the usual american food coma state. If the servers/hostess were nicer, OTD would've received 5 stars from me. Too bad.
author: Emily T.

description:
I've had several items from their menu.  Porridge, spring rolls, all of their sandwiches.

Food: 4 stars. Flavors are refined and delicious.
Value:  2 stars.  Expensive considering portion size and quality.
author: Juan R.

description: One of my favorite restaurants in the city and much easier to get into then slanted door (also cheaper)!
author: Jessica K.

description: Perfect portionings with still the quaint free of mom's homemade love. I prefer quality versus quantity. Our server was also very sweet
author: Sunnie H.

description: Love that the location is so close to where I live.  Walked in for party of two and sat at counter, no wait.  Got the Papaya salad to start, delicious.  In between our salad and entrees we waited for about 20 mins. Backed up due to call in orders and a few woks our server explained to us.  Comped our dessert which was nice of them for the long wait.  For our entrees we got the shaken beef, which was amazing and seared scallops which was okay, rubbery and not too much flavor. Was still a little hungry so we ordered another app, the calamari, which was grilled then supposed to be crisp. Ate a few, good flavoring but not crispy at all.  The GM , wish I got her name, then came around asking how everything was and she noticed the calamari, immediately said that's not how it supposed to be cooked. She then took it back and offered us a new calamari which was a lot better. I thank her for that attention to detail, made our experience a lot better. Our dessert we chose the cheese cake, which was very good, I'm not a sweet tooth kind of guy, so I didn't each much, but the few bites I had were very good! All in all trying to get dinner at a nice place on a Saturday without reservations after a Giants game is tough, so we really appreciated the accommodations. Will be back, maybe for lunch though, where demand is less.
author: Vance O.

description: Good food but extremely loud. So loud that one wants to leave before finishing dinner. They should consider covering the concrete walls with something that can dampen the noise.
author: Claudio B.

description:
Had the crispy imperial rolls, chicken porridge, and grilled lemongrass pork. Cripsy imperial rolls were your traditional imperial rolls from a Vietnamese restaurant. Chicken porridge was bland and had a few thin strips of chicken. Grilled lemongrass pork was forgetful. 

To top it all off, I waited 40 minutes for the take-out order. Was told it would take 15 mins. So I come back in 15 minutes after a quick trip to Walgreens around the corner. They tell me it would take another 5 minutes. Those extra 5 minutes actually take another 25 minutes. I sat around and saw 3 other take-out orders go out before mine.

I am now a believer that there is no such thing as fancy Vietnamese food. Just roll through your neighborhood Vietnamese place and get the same food at a fraction of the price.
author: Eric L.

description: Yummy. Went there for a Saturday brunch and it did not disappoint. There were 3 of us. One meat-lover, one Pescatarian, and an Omnivore. We were not disappointed. It was a very nice meal with a cool atmosphere and amazing waitstaff. We will make this one of our places to visit when we return to San Fran.
author: Chi Z.

description: Nice surprise. Dishes were bursting with flavor and the service was prompt and intuitive
author: Richard W.

description:
Came here to try the Chicken Rice Porridge that is on the 7 x7 list.  The Porridge came with a side of rau ram, fried shallots, black pepper and chinese donut.  Mix everything together in the porridge and it is PERFECT!  It's a bit pricy for porridge, but since it was on The List I had to order it.  My kids LOVED the chinese donut, we had to ask for more.  Normally chinese donut is very oily tasting, but this one was chewy and bready and had a perfect crisp to it.  The porridge was the perfect consistency and flavor and had a generous amount of chicken in it.

We also ordered the Vietnamese Crepe (Banh Xeo), Beef Pho and also Daikon Rice Cake.  The Banh Xeo was served with a side of lettuce, mint leaves and fish sauce.  The Banh Xeo was very crispy and had a generous amount of bean sprouts, pork and shrimp.  We were very surprised at how much we liked it.  Daikon Rice Cake tasted good too, thought that the spicy soy dressing that they serve it was going to be spicy BUT it didnt seem to bother my kids.  The Pho at this location taste like it does at Westfield Centre.  No complaint's, it's just perfect the way we like it.

Will definitely come back, there are so many things on the menu that we want to try.
author: Tammy N.

description: The food here is good, really good actually. However the service I got today, picking up a to go order was aweful! I paid for my food and waited for the staff to finish putting it together. I waited near the hostess stand to keep out of the way of the staff. After a while, I politely asked the hostess if my order was ready. The hostess' attitude was sh*t and she was not nice at all!!  She was definitely having a bad day...maybe because she was working on a holiday or maybe because she was upset about having to serve people in a restaurant. Who knows? She was crabby and full of attitude.  She is the hostess with the shaved part of her hair...please avoid her...boo!!! Anyway, when I asked her about my food she rolled her eyes with a sour look in her face and said, "I don't know I'm not the one manning the to go orders."  Wow...what a gem! Good hire with this one OTD!! If you're going to serve food that is really tasty and delicious you should also have people that work in your restaurant that have skills in just being nice. Not too much to ask for...just be nice. I mean you're working in the customer service industry, isn't being nice kind of a pre-requisite? I left with a sour taste in my mouth from her bad attitude. But I was looking forward to getting home and eating the yummy food.
author: Richard G.

description:
Dear Out the Door,

I am moving out of your brunch zone. Would you kindly open a branch in Noe Valley or the Mission? I promise to keep you in business by ordering copious amounts of soft scrambled eggs, papaya salad, and clay pot deliciousness.

Pretty please with soy drizzle on top?

-Jessica
author: Jessica H.

description:
great food 
great atmosfire 
soooooooo loud
author: Erik C.

description:
A very sweet spot.
I came here with my father on a Sunday afternoon. A perfect brunch/lunch hangout for a lazy Sunday. The sun was out, the air was crisp, and we were in the mood for something light. My father and I sat at the bar overlooking the kitchen and sizzling pots. 
I ordered the fresh vegetarian spring rolls and jasmine tea to begin. A large man from Texas, he needed an explanation on what pho was and how to eat it. I convinced him to try the chicken pho. He has been fighting a cold for a few weeks so the waitress was kind enough to suggest using the Sriracha sauce. The sauce will clear out any nose! The soup was herbal, soothing, and had my father moaning. I ordered the green papaya salad. It was fresh, crisp, sweet. I loved the fried onions as an accent. 

The crowd is a mix of hip working professionals and families. Since it is smaller than its mother restaurant, I suggest keeping the parties to a maximum of four. A great spot for catching up with a friend or a casual date. Also, there is a standing bar section where the hip crowd congregates for wine. 

Healing food, tea, wine. It is all a treat.
author: Maureen S.

description:
outstanding.
spring rolls were great as was decor, vibe and service.
author: Scott L.

description: Clean and nice atmosphere but expensive American Vietnamese food.  Not sure if I would go back because it's not authentic Vietnamese cuisine.
author: Mary L.

description:
Went here for brunch on Saturday, and had a delicious meal! My least favorite was the papaya salad, which was a bit bland (I'm used to the spicier Thai green papaya salad). The summer rolls were great, especially since they added shitake mushrooms. 
I ordered the vegetarian banh -mi, which may be the most unique and delicious version of the sandwich I've ever had. It comes on a homemade french roll, with asparagus, avocado, shitake mushrooms, pickled daikon & carrots, and a perfectly light mayonnaise based spread. For ~$12(I think) it's definitely the most expensive banh-mi sandwich I've had, but totally worth it!
My friend got the shrimp vermicelli, and I only had a bite but the shrimp were spiced and cooked perfectly.
The service was friendly and fast. The decor was very modern, but if you're wearing a short/dress/skirt don't sit on the bench! It's a metal bench, and pretty cold!
author: Ariana L.

description:
Attempting to fancify Vietnamese food is sort of a crime against nature in my opinion.  Vietnamese should be eaten in a dingy, cramped hole in the wall perhaps with chopsticks that look suspiciously like they haven't been washed in a while.  That's where the good stuff is.  So it just felt a bit odd eating Vietnamese in a clean, chic restaurant that takes reservations.  I would have been okay with it had the food blown my mind.  Or even been pretty decent.  But it just wasn't all that great.  Probably the best thing I had was the crispy imperial rolls.  But what the hell were you supposed to do with the lettuce and noodles on the side . . . I guess wrap the already wrapped rolls with the lettuce and noodles?  It was a bit puzzling.  The chicken porridge was sort of a bore, but let's face it, it's porridge and is pretty much boring by definition.

What really upset me was their Vietnamese coffee.  Usually Vietnamese coffee packs a punch, and one delicious sip will send you into a tizzy of caffeine induced mania.  Whatever they gave me was like watered down Starbucks with cream.  As a person with a passion for Vietnamese coffee, this utter desecration of it was pretty devastating.

The service was attentive enough, but our server had the emotion level of a cyborg.  I began making horrifyingly bad jokes in an attempt to provoke ANY kind of reaction out of him.  Fail. . . he didn't even have the decency to roll his eyes.
author: Jenny R.

description:
I want to open the front door
And tip the whole happy restaurant into 
My mouth. 
It's that good
author: Salamander X.

description: Best green papaya salad i've had so far in my life! Also had the beef, which was very tender. Also had the chicken somethin or another, that was good too. The shrimp was yummy too. Hell , everything I had was very tasty. I'd go back again. Only thing is that during the lunch rush during the Xmas season there might be a wait.  we were seated very quickly though.
author: Kenson K.

description: Cool vibe. Great food. Great service. 'Nuff said.
author: Allison B.

description:
Let me be the 1,325,439th person on Yelp to really wish they had half stars because my dining experience here was definitely a 3.5.

The highlights: 
The staff was surprisingly friendly and accommodating to my toddler son (crayons, coloring paper, high chair, plastic cup with straw). Considering OTD is a sibling of Slanted Door, I was expecting a lot more pretension than we got here. Pleasantly surprised.

Vietnamese coffee and beignets. We would have been happy (and richer) if we'd just stuck with this simple combo for brunch.

Chicken porridge. I only ordered it to check one off my 7x7 Things to Eat list but quickly found myself slurping the last bits of warm gooey rice and crispy onions.

The lowlights:
Price. $62 for brunch for two. I don't mind paying that when mimosas or bloodys are involved but alas we indulged in coffee and hot tea alone. 

Chicken porridge: Despite my praise above, one of the pieces of chicken in my porridge had a large piece of tough fat attached to it. I never feel very ladylike when I have to pull a chewed piece of meat out of my mouth and not-so-gracefully put it in my napkin.
author: Christina K.

description:
Nice to be able to walk here, so I've been here a couple times for breakfast/brunch. I like the long bar overlooking the kitchen. 

Beignets were pretty nice, with an egg custard filling. The famed chicken porridge was nice and thick, topped with chinese doughnuts and fried shallots. Perfect for a local jook fix.

I also liked the soft scramble with dungeness crab, eggs were perfectly cooked and the baguette was really good, freshly toasted.

We were able to get a side of the housemade chicken liver pate, which had an interesting mix of flavors. Pretty nice on the toasted baguette.

The slow cooked eggs and brisket is really good comfort food, with a generous portion of beef. The chef has the immersion circulator cooking the eggs on the counter.

I like this Out the Door better than the Westfield one.
author: Derrick V.

description:
**NOT gluten-free friendly**
(must be able to order creatively to eat here. They are *very good* about making custom dishes to eat!  Breakfast items sans the usual suspects are what you'd be limited to.)

Very tasty, and the staff was very, very nice, but if you are gluten-intolerant, this is *not* really the place to go.  The only thing on the menu besides the shrimp/pork spring rolls that I could eat was the Dungeness crab, and even that dish had to be modified so I could eat it.

I had the 'Dungeness crab, cellophane noodles, green onion, sesame oil'.  This dish is made with soy sauce, so if you are gluten-intolerant, make *sure* you order it *without* the soy sauce, and let the staff know of your allergy!  They screwed it up once (they set it down in front of me and went, "...wait, this is wrong..."), but the 2nd time was a charm.
author: Missy W.

description:
I am SO desperate for a new restaurant in this area that went back to OTD again today, only two days after having an entirely mediocre lunch there. 

Different order, same result. 

Vegetarian steamed bun was pretty tasty, but the pho was pretty neutral. Harmless. Toned-down. Boring. And the noodles were wide and too soft. 

Even so, I will be back. I must be missing something. The salads, I think.
author: Bowen D.

description:
This review is for their brunch. 

I really want to say '5 stars' but I'm not going to. There are about 10 other things I want to try so I will wait until I try some of those and will then update my review (though I find it hard to believe that those things won't be delicious, too). 

Where to start? Okay, we'll start with being seated at the kitchen counter since there weren't any more tables available when we came in. What luck! Now I can't imagine sitting any other place - can actually have a better conversation with the person you're with because you're closer to them. Also watching the food being cooked is like eye candy. Also, extremely ideal if you're sharing all of the dishes. 

Now we'll touch on the service. Keep in mind it was a busy Sunday morning. I was starving when we first came in yet we didn't know exactly what we wanted yet. We started with the steamed rice cakes with pork and shrimp and some o.j. while we looked at the rest of the menu. Then when she came back, we only had figured out one more thing that we wanted and put in an order for that...while still looking at the menu. She came back a bit later and we could finally place our final order. She could not have been more sweet and patient with us. 

Now to the food. 

The steamed rice cakes with pork and shrimp were great and unique. The imperial roll (which my boyfriend insisted upon) made me a fan of imperial rolls! Keep in mind, he knows I'm not a huge fan of fried food and he told the waitress I wasn't going to want them - so she suggested that he get a half-order. This ended up being a problem since I ended up being a fan (what's not to love about making a roll out of lettuce, mint, vermicelli noodles and a fried roll with all sorts of goodness in it and dipping it into a sweet and salty sauce???). We also got the soft scrambled eggs with crab and the baguette. Eggs were cooked perfectly. Baguette was the perfect texture. 

We were both contently full from this meal...though we wanted to try about 4 other things (the egg scramble with rice cake, the vermicelli bowl, the pate...to name a few). Next time!
author: Jen N.

description:
Had an absolutely DELICIOUS lunch at OTD yesterday. I went in there skeptical due to the fact there is more than one location. However, I left very satisfied.

We had the Vegetarian Crispy Imperial Rolls which could really be enough lunch by itself. Came with noodles and salad with mint leaves. Sooooo delicious !  The Papaya Salad was also very good, and the black sticky rice was my wife's favorite.

We really enjoyed their wines on tap. Very good wines for the price. Skylark 'Red Belly', a cargnane-syrah blend, is an outstanding wine at $8.50 a glass. They also offer a California sauvignon blanc for $4.50 a glass. In these times of $12.00 to $15.00 for a glass for wine becoming more and more prevalent, it is nice encounter a true value.

Highly recommend OTD on Bush Street.
author: B. B.

description:
Where have you been during my tortuous years of school? I had to eat tacos (La Salsa, blah!). I had to eat sandwiches (royal grounds yuck!). I had to eat pizza (Dino! ) Finally real foods have arrived on the Fillmore! 

The best things on the menu are also the cheapest ($3!). I can seriously eat their steam buns every day for breakfast, lunch and sometimes dinner. I'd eat the chicken for the heartiness, the pork because of its robust flavors, and the vegetables for its lightness.  I'd finish every meal with a Vietnamese iced coffee. 

You are every UOP student's dream!
author: My T.

description: My wife and I used to really like the Out the Door at Westfield Mall and really missed it when it was closed.  Finally had a chance to head out to this location and it was great.  The food was terrific and the ambiance is much nicer than the mall location (no surprise there).  High energy level and lots of bustle.
author: Richard M.

description:
The location is very convenient on Bush off of Fillmore.  Parking can be tough but luckily we live in the neighborhood.  
The kids love the steamed 'Buns' and this is pretty well the only place they eat salad.  The grapefruit salad as well as the new flank steak salad are well done.  Not everything is a hit however.  The imperial roll is ok but is no better at twice the price c/w a 'regular' vietnamese place.  Ditto for the noodle soups.
The chicken clay pot is very good but probably their best dish is the overpriced 'shaking beef' which tastes like the version at the parent Slanted Door.
The service is good in general and the decor sleek and modern for a vietnamese restaurant.   It does feel a bit dark during the day since it's a long room with window only on one end. 
We end up coming here alot and along with pizzeria Delfina are our two most frequented place along Fillmore our 'hood'.
author: John P.

description: This place is awesome. Food is healthy and light. Spices just right. Lots of variety even for vegetarians. Super friendly service. It just gets packed so make sure you reserve.
author: Vijay S.

description: I don't mind paying a few dollars more for quality ingredients. You can really taste the difference in quality of ingredients at OTD. The broth of the chicken Pho is just so flavorful, delicate and satisfying. The broth is what makes the dish. Papaya salad also delicious-- veggies and papaya are so fresh. My husband and I dined here for brunch one day. I ordered chicken pho and he ordered the French toast. Toast was delicious but the portion is too tiny. If you are a grown man you would need to order some extra sides to fill you up. When the dish arrives you will think to yourself that this is a side did vs a main brunch item. It has great flavor with a fancy and delicious orange syrup but tiny portion size. I also had dinner here for friends birthday. The food was good and ingredients were good quality but the dishes themselves don't make a strong positive or negative stamp. I'd say stick with lunch items and you won't be disappointed. 4 stars bc the chicken pho  makes up for the other shortcomings mentioned above
author: kirstenbb c.

description:
Out the Door seems to have a bunch of hit and miss reviews. Chalk this one up to the hit category. 

We stopped in for a quick bite before a Saturday afternoon movie at the Kabuki. The first thing we both noticed is that this location serves brunch! Being a cold day, though, we both went the noodle route, after splitting a perfect pork bun! My chicken pho was a huge portion and just what the doctor ordered for my sore throat.

Prices were more than reasonable ($3 pork bun, $9 pho that was a big enough portion for two meals) and we were in and out the door (ha ha) in approx 45 minutes making this location of Out the Door perfect for a pre-movie or Fillmore show spot. I'll definitely be back!
author: phil h.

description: Came here on NY Day (Jan 1) - very crowded and busy (at 3pm) - glad I tried it though - outstanding food quality and freshness - imperial rolls were delicious - Pho was just ok though (had to try it), however, the rest of menu looked very intriquing - so will happily go back to try other options, but on my never ending quest for Pho perfection, Out the Door was not quite a player in that catagory for me!
author: Richard D.

description:
Our motto is when in San Francisco neighborhoods, pick a restaurant near your parking space! After parking, three people in the car said, "Isn't this near Out the Door?"

Very impressive and spacious feeling. Chicken porridge, Shrimp w/Bean Sprouts, Jicama and grapefruit salad, Vietnamese crepe w/shrimp, pork, bean sprouts, Chicken bok choy rice noodles, (All good stuff).
author: GARY C.

description:
Someone just told me that Michael Bauer completely panned Des Amis.  For some reason this makes me happy, in part  because I also thought that place was a mess, and I'll take validation wherever I can get it but also because, for those prices, in that space, in that location, the food should be damn good.  And it's not.  So mad props to the tower of Bauer for, once again, calling it right.  

The point is: places like Des Amis MUST have good food  because people aren't quite sure what to expect.  Yeah, yeah, it's the Spruce people, but the connection isn't entirely clear to the layperson.  Places like Out the Door, though, don't really HAVE to be good.  Places like Out the Door, which come with a pretty solid pedigree, a familiar menu, and the hipster seal of approval, can actually serve pretty mediocre food, and still manage to be packed on a random Wednesday night.  And, on my two visits so far, Out the Door seems to be fitting this bill just fine.  Food was pretty good the first time, bland and boring the second time.  Service was not memorable either time.  The second time, our food seemed to take an extraordinarily long time.  Prices are fine, although $24 for cod seems a little overboard.  Whatever, though.  Such is my level of enthusiasm for Out the Door.
author: Pammy C.

description:
Favorites are the buns, sandwiches, and salads (papaya, jicama). Also like the higher-quality ingredients used at OTD compared to other Vietnamese restaurants (e.g. beef and pork are from Nieman Ranch). Other dishes, such as the appetizer on banana leaves, and the fava greens are also good but oily. Service was ok, not friendly like other restaurants. This place is loud -- gotta shout to talk your dining companion (some insulation on the ceiling perhaps?). 

Food: 3.9 stars (good but oily), service: 2 stars, setting: 3 stars, sustainability: 4 stars.
author: Yvonne C.

description:
This review is for breakfast - yes, that's right BREAKFAST.  On a weekday.   I don't know of many restaurants short of diners that serve this meal, but I am sure glad that Out the Door has given us an alternative to a bagel and cream cheese from Noah's.

IMO, morning is the best time of the day to enjoy this space - it's so light and bright, and when not packed with people, very zen and delightful.  If your schedule allows you to have your first meal of the day in Pacific Heights with the sun shining brightly through the pristine windows - by all means, do it.

My friend and I shared several things for our breakfast meal, including the steamed buns (1 pork, 1 chicken), the Chicken Pho, and the Scrambled Eggs.  All were good, but the standout dish was the eggs - they are finished with something salty like soy sauce, and are absolutely silky and delectable. 

Washed down with a strong pot of Yunnan Black, it was the perfect start to our day.
author: Liz S.

description: Excellent food and service as usual but cold and hard metal bench seats against the wall remain a problem. Need to add cushions!
author: Michael B.

description: Have heard about this place for a while and finally had a chance to try it. I got the pho and my companion got grilled chicken on rice noodles. We also got the fresh spring rolls. The spring rolls were very generously portioned and everything in them was delicious especially the shrimp was perfectly fresh.  I was a little alarmed when my pho came and the meat was raw but it cooked perfectly in the broth when I stirred it in. This was good Vietnamese food. The broth was delicious and the meat was really tender and good. You are definitely paying for the atmosphere here compared to other Vietnamese restaurants I've been too and there is no question about the quality of the ingredients. We went for lunch and didn't have reservations and so sat at the counter. Good service and we got to see the food being made. So, it was a good experience food, service, and atmosphere-wise.
author: Anne S.

description: Good, fresh food.  Seating is very limited so showing up without a reservation at peak hours isn't recommended.  For two consider ordering for one and load up on appetizers.  Spring rolls are very good, so is the Pho served during lunch.
author: Jeff P.

description:
I'm going to preface this review by first saying that I am Vietnamese. I don't know, maybe that means I'm a little more critical than other diners who aren't? 

I've dined at this new OTD location 3 times now. twice for breakfast and once for lunch. On all occasions the food has been amazing. From the beignets and vietnamese iced coffee, to the pork buns and fried eggs and pate and poached eggs. It is a great twist on some more traditional vietnamese breakfast items and some new things that are to die for. I grew up eating fried eggs with maggi and a baguette, and that really brought me back. YUM! 

I was just there for lunch last week and had the most amazing food. My favorite vietnamese dish is the crepe, also known as Banh Xeo, and I had to have it. The crepe was perfect, crisp and refreshing the way it is supposed to be! Now don't forget the Chicken Porridge. this may be the sole reason why I go back to OTD. It is amazing. I really don't know anywhere else in the city to get such greaty chicken porridge, except for when my mom makes it. The flavors are spot on. LOVE IT! 

I definitely suggest sitting at the chefs counter, because then you get a great feel for the kitchen and its always fun seeing the chefs make the food! 

Also just found out they have wine on tap. Um, genius! It may sound odd at first, but the wines are actually delicious and a great value.

I can't wait to run back for my next visit!
author: Jennifer T.

description: Very good experience, everyone was so nice and the mix of flavors was really tasty. Although I happened to like the appetizers better than the dinner, the clay-pot was amazing!
author: Nicole L.

description:
Get In the Door & go for more...
 
Big fan of Phan's original Slanted Door in the Mission (yes, that  makes me old BUT tasteful) & always game to try new OTD spot.
 
Cool zen decor: open kitchen, wood walls & concrete floors but sound reverberates ...
I am a "loud talker" & still had to pump up the dinner chat volume!
Dig Bush street location...laid back locals looking for some tasty SD style food without hype of Ferry Building scene.
 
Nice mix of favorites along with some new dishes.
Classics I CRAVE:
Niman Ranch shaking beef (peppery vinegar & watercress are sooo good w/ beef)
Papaya salad with pickled carrots (big fan of the peanut crunch!)

New Additions:
Arctic char with persimmons & garlic chili sauce 
(*My prediction: arctic char is the "new salmon")
Pork meatballs with pineapple chili anchovy sauce (meat was little overcooked/savory sauce saved it)

Next time I have an early morning hankering for Pho, I will be the 1st in line to try OTD breakfast!
author: heather s.

description: Out the Door is excellent Vietnamese in a high-end environment.  It's a more-accessible version of its sister restaurant the Slanted Door, but the food is still great--I recommend the scallops and the lamb stir-fry.  A reservation is probably a good idea, especially on the weekends, but be warned that the restaurant can be somewhat noisy.
author: Dan W.

description:
Would have done 4 and half stars (there's always room for human error in a restaurant) chose 5 because they deserve more than 4!

I love this place!! It's nothing like the other OTD's (not that the other ones are bad). They have a completely different menu and serve all day. They do breakfast lunch and dinner but my favorite is weekend brunch. It's nice to find a place that serves a non American "comfort food" brunch. The staff is super friendly and the food is extremely consistent. I will never get sick of their Pho (best broth I've had to date in this city).

This is a great example of how to highlight the amazing ingredients we have access to in the bay area. Add in the service and the execution and they have a recipe for success!

I haven't read the other reviews on this place but I did notice they're not great. I do find it funny that some of my favorite places have the worst reviews on Yelp, i.e. Flour and Water and Nopalito to name a few... I stopped reading the bad ones because when it comes to places like this people are either complaining about the wait or the price. Sorry folks it's quality not quantity and sometimes that may draw a crowd.
author: Kara S.

description: I am a bad Chinese...I totally have no  shame paying a 40% premium to have pho at OTD versus a little hole-in-the-wall.  Their beef pho is so so darn tasty.  The noodles are cooked perfectly, the quality of the beef is great, the broth is just right and I can dump that whole plate of bean sprouts without having to have picked through to make sure the sprouts are cleaned.  Oh and the hot milk tea is no joke here!
author: Jen C.

description:
Overall, I'm a big fan of OTD.  The service is impeccable, the large space serene and quiet even when crowded (a trick I wish other restaurants in SF would heed and apply), the ingredients fresh, tasty, and beautifully plated.  A big plus is that it's in the neighborhood, there's a community table and OTD welcomes the single diner, and the vibe is low key friendly.  

I learn something new about Vietnamese food each time I'm there.  The entire staff is well-educated about the food and it's fun to talk with them about it.  It's not in that too precious "flaunting, let me educate you" manner  but in the way someone who knows their ingredients and likes to talk about food way--very natural and just enough.

My only problem with OTD is the cost.  I generally realize I'm hungry about 9 PM, too late for a Mollie's salad, way too late for Delfina's pizza or meatballs, and so I head to OTD.  I must say it's not a tragic choice, just pricey for an Imperial roll and papaya salad; no wine or beer.  It's about $23.00 with tip and tax.  I had cellophane noodles with crab (very, very little crab), an Imperial roll, and tea once.  It was over $35.00.  

Two people could easily run a tab over $100.00 with a couple of rolls, a beer and a glass of wine, splitting a salad, a noodle dish and a clay pot, and splitting a dessert.  Other Out the Door's seem less costly.  They, however, don't have the lovely milieu.  I walk in and the cares of the day fall away.  Some evenings that is more than worth the extra money even without the glass of wine.

For those who use walkers or wheelchairs.  I use a walker sometimes and have gone in OTD with it.  The staff was great.  I was given my choice of seats and not herded to the back of the room.  My treatment was matter-of-fact, polite, and "no big deal."  It was so refreshing not to feel as though a spotlight was turned on me (I go back when using my cane in appreciation).  The wait staff asked if I wanted my walker moved out of the way while I ate.  I said yes.  It was moved to where I could see it but no one would trip over it.  I was asked when I would like it returned to me.  It was returned with no fuss or big production.  THANK YOU OTD!!!
author: Julia C.

description:
I wanted to like this place, and even after a terrible food experience I still wanted to give a good review because the manager ROCKS; until I read all the other reviews and realized that my experience is a result of their clear failure to read these reviews and LEARN from their mistakes.  

We all want to love this place because we LOVE Slanted Door, and the Embarcadero location of OTD.  But the other reviews about the bland, too oily food are, quite frankly, correct.  

I went for lunch today because I was walking up Bush and happened to see a new restaurant.  I crossed the street and became immediately excited that it was Out the Door!  The no-personality hostess had to ask the waiter if it was okay if I (being just me, no one else with me) sat at a table alone, rather than the counter.  Honestly, I'm short, and I don't sit on bar stools if I can help it - my feet never reach the rungs.   

I ordered the 5 spice chicken with vermicelli, because that's what I always order - anywhere they have it.  I would eat vermicelli for every damn meal if I could.  After I ordered, the woman sitting next to me got hers, and immediately asked for extra fish sauce.  The waiter tried to tell her that they put the sauce on, and it seeps to the bottom.  I thought  "oh, that's probably true - she's gonna be sorry when she has too much fish sauce."  Then I got mine.  And guess what....almost NO sauce.  Just oil.  Lot's and lots of oil.  My skin is very silky smooth right now, and my tongue is still coated with oil  2 hours later.  No biggie.  I ordered extra sauce.  Applied the sauce.  STILL bland.  WHAT?  So I asked for some hoisin sauce - whatever, I always put that on at the end anyway to switch up the flavor a little.  I proceed to eat, but the chicken is flavorless.  The imperial rolls were tasty (it's difficult to screw up fried foods).  Then toward the end I use my chopsticks (thankfully),  to break open the last, and largest, piece of chicken.  Raw.  ???? Seriously????  I better check again.    Oh yeah.  Raw.  The waiter promptly took it away, and the manager came over.  I wasn't all that upset, but it was nice of him to come over - he was GREAT. "Obviously, it's on the house", and can he get me anything else?  Hmmmmm....tell me about the coconut bun.  YES, he says!  It's wonderful, I'll get that for you.  And ohhhhhhhhh YES - it is wonderful.  

So, free coconut bun, and the vermicelli was comped.  I'll go back again, and be specific about no oil on my noodles to see how that goes.  But be forewarned OTD - I'm only coming again once.  If you don't learn from this, and all the other reviews, that's you're fault.
author: Cori D.

description: The ribs are on another level - a must try!! They even bring hot towels for your hands after. This place is consistently amazing.
author: Ashley S.

description: Fantastic experience. AMAZING service. I suggest doing family style dinning here. Great selection of wine and pair with the food. Very modern yet romantic design. It's a lil tricky to find because there is no sign but the front is all glass so you'll know where it is when you see it. I can't wait to go back. The beef was fantastic.
author: Michael C.

description:
I love the food here.  Quality ingredients, fresh tasting and often organic.
And they are open for breakfast, which makes this a sweet option for a non-traditional morning stop.  It can be quite pricey but for the most part this place should be on your regular go to list. Not necessarily the friendliest servers around but as long as the food stays this good, I'll probably keep coming back.
author: Roberta W.

description:
I'm working my way through 7 x 7's Big Eat so my husband and I hit up this place to eat the reccomended Chicken Porridge.

I don't really like chicken or porridge, and I wasn't excited about the combo, but oh my, oh my, if this is what being wrong feels like I don't wanna be right. As always it was freezing in SF and that bowl of porridge gave me a kind hug. We slurped it up the way sailors on leave hit the bar. I'm sure there are lots of places where you get something that tastes just as good in the city for less, but I don't think that's always the point of eating out. Sometimes you want cheap eats in a dive  with your friendly neighborhood waiter but sometimes you want to eat something delicious and beautiful in a beautiful place. That's what this porridge was, it was presentation and techique AND quality. It was home style cooking with precise attention to detail. It was heaven. Perfectly balanced in every way.

I liked the decor too, it was homey and modern at the same time, just like the food.
author: Emily P.

description: Tasty and casual.  I like the hip atmosphere and service was good.
author: Frank M.

description: Really great food, the brunch is amazing. Must try the calamari and the spring rolls. At brunch, the Vietnamese coffee with beignets... Awesome!
author: K K.

description:
Delicious food! Hot and flavorful. Enjoyed both types of vegetarian spring rolls, crispy (amazing) and raw rice paper ones served with spicy peanut sauce. You get more for your money with the fresh rolls, but the crispy ones were incredible! 
Moving along, I had the bok choy and shitake mushrooms, my dad had the cellophane dungeness crab, and stepmother had the scallops. each item was delicious and innovative food! 

it was fun to watch the flames from the grill! high energy here. the waitress was wonderful, she made sure that i was not infected by any non vegetarian cooking practices (told me about veg stock instead of chicken stock phew!) and brought me a dish of chili sauce to liven up my dinner, and it kicked! coconut rice for dessert was stupendous!! 

NOTE: this place is extremely noisy, a big dining room with hard floors, walls, and marble tables. had to shout the entire time. bad for date night. bad for trying to catch up with friends. good for eating. good for date night if you and your partner are beyond oral communication and need only to gaze and hold hands..... 

all that said, this isn't my kind of place and i probably won't eat here again :)
author: Libra J.

description:
Ordinarily this chain of San Francisco restaurants is top notch - but this latest attempt at repeating the Ferry Building/SF Centre success is poorly lacking.  Here's why:

1.  Seating:  "Please wait for a table" then "There are no tables available tonight."  "You can sit anywhere at the bar" then "You can't sit at that part of the bar."

2.  Service:  We sat down at 7:00p and ordered at 7:15p.  Our appetizer came at 8:15 and entrees at 8:30p.  And what time did the first bus boy come up to clear our plates?  8:45p.  Seriously dude, can I set my fork down first?  And when we inquired about our order around 7:45p, they comped a rice cake.  Great, thanks for the free $4 side dish.

3.  Food:  I waited an hour for a small portioned mediocre attempt at what usually is delicious at the Ferry Building?  Flavorless, cold and obviously rushed.  The one star is because at least it was edible.

I'm game for a great restaurant treating you poorly, but a terrible restaurant treating you horribly is just unconscionable.  Save yourself the disappointment if looking for grub on Fillmore and stop in Woodhouse.
author: Lane K.

description:
We stopped here prior to going to the Fillmore for a concert - about a three block walk. 

Experience prompt service and servers were polite and attentive. We didn't feel rushed, nor did we feel like we had to wait too long.

Food was also good - no complaints there. We had a Tofu veggie dish and a Chicken dish in a clay pot. I'd go back again to try out their other dishes.
author: Mauricio P.

description:
I love their fresh rolls, starters and the chicken clay pot was pretty yummy. Favorites include:
- rice cakes - melt in your mouth 
- heirloom tomato salad with bits of lightly fried green tomatoes!
- grapefruit and jicama salad - refreshing and delicious!

The main courses are pricey for the portion size and the service leaves a bit to be desired when it comes to consistency.
author: Sarah T.

description:
I like the set up and the decor. 

However, I do not like the teeny barely there crab in their "signature" crab cellophane noodle dish. The noodles were deliciously seasoned (not as chewy as I like) but the crab was weak. It felt very stingy for an $18 dish. I could have bought 2 WHOLE crabs (and Safeway was having a buy one get one free sale so that's 4 crabs!) for that price. I know that doesn't include the yummy noodles but come on! I'm not a huge eater but there were only two and a half mini lumps of crab meat. I was very disappointed because it felt wrong. 

I also asked for my soup to be cilantro free but it came with cilantro. I didn't particularly like our server either. When I asked about recommendations he just listed the options on the menu without giving any insightful perspective. 

Loved the spring rolls - the wrapper was perfectly prepared. Nice and chewy.

Lastly, I asked about the porridge that I've had before and the server said they don't serve it for dinner. What a bummer considering it was such a cold night. As we were sitting next to the cash register, I could hear a pick up order being rung up - I am 90% sure I heard him say "One order of Chicken Porridge"!!! I don't know but if that is true, that is jacked up. -- I HAVE AN UPDATE! THE PERSON WHO BOUGHT THE PORRIDGE WROTE ME AND SAID SHE ORDERED IT AT LUNCH AND ASKED THEM TO PUT IT ASIDE FOR HER. I ALSO HAPPENED TO TRY THE PORRIDGE TODAY. NOT MUCH CHICKEN BUT VERY DELICIOUS. I'VE HAD THE DUCK AT THE FERRY BUILDING WHICH HAD MORE MEAT. MM...

I would go back but I will probably get the porridge as I know that is delicious. Their breakfast sounds yum.
author: Cindy F.

description: This review is specifically for the to-go customer service.  I simply called to find out whether the brunch buns were available for to-go orders.  The gentleman who answered the phone (I cringe to call him a gentleman), rudely declared "we're closed!"  I calmly said, "OK, what time do you open again" - to which he yelled "I said we're closed!"  Before I could ask anything else, he hung up.  I don't care how good the food is, there is no excuse for such rude behavior.  If you are closed and don't want to be bothered - simply don't answer.  When I called back - a nicer person answered and explained that they will open again at 5:30.  Now, was that too hard to say the first time?
author: Sylvia K.

description:
Was lucky enough to attend a sneak preview of OTD Bush this morning, and I feel great - nothing like a Vietnamese coffee to get you buzzing, right?

Charles Phan's newest location in Pac Heights is equipped with everything you've come to expect from an Out the Door: Sleek and simple decór, top-notch service, and inspired food with an affordable pricetag.
