...But it also offers something completely new: brunch. Items like airy beignets, smoked salmon with tangy whole-seed brown mustard, and soft eggs with soy sauce make this a unique and, most importantly, yummy spot to start the day.

Looking forward to trying the breakfast porridge next time!
author: Stephanie P.

description:
I know someone who knows the owner who took me here when I was in the area.  Nice trendy setting which screams "Gotta have a glass of wine with your meal" so I did.  We had the following for dinner:

~Green papaya salad - very good!  More used to this type of starter at a Thai place than a Vietnamese place but it's all good!
~Spring rolls - good
~Dungeoness crab with cellophane noodles - gotta say this was my fav!  Very tasty and different!  Can't remember having anything like it in other V-rests.
~Lamb - tender and good; again, not a common V-dish to my knowledge
~Baby bok choy - fresh, tasty and crispy

Yes, some consider it pricey V-food but it does set itself apart from typical V-food by adding creative taste combinations.  Wish they had a rest. in SoCal!  Guess I'll just have to make it a point to stop in each time I'm in SF.
author: Gigi M.

description: Consistently good. It's pricey, but a nice place to go if you want to splurge. The food is creative and flavorful. A seat along the kitchen counter gives a great view of the impressively busy-yet-super-organized kitchen. You'll need a reservation unless you arrive very early or very late. The imperial rolls are delish.
author: Molly P.

description:
The atmosphere in OTD is really good. All modern but still warm.
We had the five spice chicken and the chicken pho for lunch and both were good. The five spice chicken came on a bed of cold vermicelli and salad and the dressing was super.
The chicken pho had a tasty broth but also was a little boring.
It's a little expensive for what it is, but occasionally it works.
author: Alexandra D.

description:
I have eaten here a couple of times before today. The food has generally been pretty good, but the service is indifferent. Since I do work near the Slanted Door and go there often, I am pretty disappointed by this OTD. 
Today's experience has really done me in. The woman working the bar recommended the porridge since is was a bit gloomy out. This sounded good, and actually started out pretty good until I was about a quarter way into it.  I started to become aware of the large amount of black pepper that was added. My face started to flush and my throat became tight. I mentioned the over spice to her and I got a reluctant "sorry". I ended up paying for it, no offer to comp it, and left. Now I am at home feeling even worse with nothing to do but yelp about it.
author: jim S.

description: No self-respecting Asian person would be caught dead here. $9 for rice porridge?! My mama would slap me upside my head...
author: Joe C.

description:
Can't understand anything less than five stars.  This is the place for great unique fresh Vietnamese food in SF.  Staff is attentive and cares about their food and service.  I go once a week or so, sometimes eat in other times to go.  Always fantastic.  
(Only complaint is it is hard to find today's menu for takeout (changes every day) if you are on a mobile device.)
author: P S.

description: I was super happy with my experience here. I had a really hard time choosing what to eat, it all looked amazing and everything we ordered tasted incredible! I also thought the pricing was extremely reasonable, the service was friendly and my guests had a great time. Thanks OTD!
author: Kristen N.

description:
If you have a sudden craving for some "hot buns" while shopping in Pac Heights you will be totally excited like I am! 

Stopped in for a GIANT steamed veggie bun (they have pork & chicken buns also), $3 each

Also got a cup of the nice steeping hot White Crysanthemum tea on the house, so delicious and good for "cooling" the body temperature. That made me happy I stopped in!

I ordered it all "To Go" but since it was just Oh-so-nice and tranquil inside, great people (and I loved the long white marble bar) I decided to hang out here for a bit. Nice and unassuming location close to the action but not stuck in it.....and they have a big community table in front of restaurant....no wonder I felt so very invited!
author: Lee M.

description:
get:
vegetarian dumplings
sticky rice with sweet potato
jicama & grapefruit salad
chicken porridge

pass:  
beignets
chicken pho
vietnamese coffee

service is a crap shoot.   i've had really horrible slow service and pretty good service, always for brunch so be ready to take your chances.
author: Josie M.

description: The wine list is strong here and works well with the dishes here.  The small plates are a great way to taste the range of flavors and textures. I prefer this over the Slanted Door.
author: Roger H.

description: Love this place. Great soup, especially. It's off the main street (Fillmore), so take a few seconds to walk down bush and find it.
author: Jason H.

description:
Delicious, unique, tasty dishes that surprise every time.  Don't go here for Cheesecake Factory portions, but rather for interesting small items that delight the palate.  Everything we had was good.  

I agree with the other Yelpers when it comes to the acoustics of the space.  Be ready to shout cause it gets noisy with a crowded house, which it usually is at OTD.  Or just bring ear plugs if you're looking for a quiet meal.
author: Tom F.

description:
Out The Door is a neighborhood gem. Yes, it gets crowded and yes, it is noisy.
But if you go  there on less crowded times, it is the best place to go in that neighborhood.
The food continues to be high quality and the service is always great.
Highly recommended.
author: Susan C.

description:
I've been eagerly anticipating the opening of the newest OTD.

Yay!

I've been twice now and have been happy with both visits. 

The first was a take-out affair. It was great and ready within a reasonable amount of time. 

The second was a little brunch and I loved it. My girlfriend and I had beef pho, imperial rolls and green papaya salad (standard fare I know, but it's always so great). We ended with some Vietnamese coffee and beignets. Awesome. I wouldn't want to start with it but, I loved ending with it. 

I will absolutely be back and I plan on doing that often.
author: J B.

description:
My friends and I came here after a visit to Kabuki Springs and Spa. We were hungry and zen and we went a little crazy when we ordered. We started with the (perfect after a sauna) imperial rolls and the ribs. Followed by the crab and cellophane noodles, the gulf prawns, and the shaking beef. The noodles and the ribs were good but not great, but the prawns and beef were definitely great!

The service was ok. We walked in 15 minutes later than our reservation and the hostess mentioned that she would need the table in an hour and a half. But our server must not have gotten that message because she was taking her time in taking our order. As our hour and a half was coming to an end it seemed that whoever was meant to be there was running late too- but we still felt rushed and pressured to avoid eye contact with the hostess.  

Overall, the food was good and the place is aesthetically pleasing- definitely a great date spot.
author: Valerie A.

description:
I was a big fan of Slanted Door when it first opened years ago in the Mission.  Since then it's become a big "scene" and I hadn't been back. 

I tried Out the Door, and came away very disappointed.  First, the prices are outrageous.  Paying $36 for a small portion of Shaking Beef was outrageous. It wasn't even that flavorful.  $20ish for simple cellophane noodles with a bit of crab thrown in.  $15 for the shrimp starter which had 4 shrimp.  Second, as I just noted, the portions are small.  

Sure, Charles Pham is trendy, but as I've always thought, if you want good authentic Vietnamese food in SF, there are many quality places where you would pay about 1/3 the price.  

Go elsewhere.
author: Matt B.

description:
"Don't you ever for a second get to thinking you're irreplaceable..." -Beyonce

Gourmet/Semi-Gourmet Vietnamese food seems like one of the biggest oxymorons in existence.  I'd rather have a big bowl of pho on Clement Street or a vermicelli bowl from Cordon Bleu.  

Overall, my experience here was ok.  We were seated at the bar and were entertained by the cooks in the kitchen.  The food was not very tasty but the service exceeded my expectation.  We were not in a rush that night, but the server was very apologetic about the backup in the kitchen.  To be honest, we hardly noticed, but we scored a complimentary vegetable dish and dessert.  Is it bad that I don't even remember what we ate?  Enough said...
author: Melanie T.

description:
.Went here last night around 9pm.  We were seated right away with no wait, which was awesome.  Service was kinda slow, considering they weren't too busy. 

Appetizers: 
We chose the fresh meatball rolls.  Fairly tasty.  Wrapped in the usual fresh rice paper wrapper and filled with all the usual pickled and fresh veggies and excess noodles, was it worth the money?  Nah.  
The stuffed squid.  Now this was delicious!  Perfectly grilled, filled with clear noodles and other delectible ingredients.  

Salad:
The Grapefruit and Jicama w/ red cabbage salad was absolutely delicious!  Very refreshing and perfectly seasoned.  

Entrees:
Arctic Char:  Although, slightly on the salty side when eaten alone, the sweet sauce that it's accompanied with really balances out the flavor.  It was cooked PERFECTLY!  (Fish nice and tender with crispy skin) 
Shredded Pork:  The 2 items in this dish are typical Vietnamese dishes that I usually have as a side dish when going to "Mom and Pop" Vietnamese restaurants.  It wasn't worth the entree price.

Desert:
Basil Ice Cream with orange shortbread.  TO DIE FOR!  

Although decently priced for casual semi-fine dining in the city, I'm used to paying less than $10 for Vietnamese spring rolls of any variety, but, none the less, if not for the Basil Ice Cream alone, I'd still go back as there are so many other delicious sounding dishes to try.
author: Delilah B.

description:
Aside from the fact that basic Vietnamese food shouldn't cost this much, Out the Door was a nice light dinner option for this part of the city. 

We sat at the "Chef's Counter" (aka counter seats facing kitchen vs. those by cash register) atop high metal seats, hooks available underneath for purses and jackets (nice), and facing the open kitchen where the construction of our dinner took place.

My friend started with a rose that was served in its own beaker before being poured into a glass. Thought that was a nice touch. I tried the lychee infused ice tea ($3.50) - deliciously fragrant.

For dinner we shared the Green Papaya Salad ($8), which was fine and tasted like other papaya salads I've had, and the Prawns in garlic and shallots ($18), which had great flavor, plump shrimp, but overall portion size was small. Side of white rice ($2) additional.

We were filling a need for a different flavor and ordered the Vegetarian Spring Rolls ($8). These were surprisingly good. I say surprising because I typically avoid the vegetarian stuff, preferring the shrimp and pork variety. But this had really good flavor and texture from the wood ear mushrooms (one of the few varieties I like), mint, and veggies. It just tasted super fresh.

So now I understand why some people like OTD.  It offers an upscale dining experience and vibe, with solid good food. The upcharge comes from saving you the trek to the Tenderloin for better and cheaper food. It's all about trade offs, right?
author: Cindy W.

description:
I wanted to like this place. I wanted to really like this place. Especially with all the mediocre reviews.

But, I don't.

It's a waste of time and money. 

The fresh shrimp rolls were..too chewy.
The pork meatballs were...too small. 
The duck was...dry and tasted waaaaaaaaay too bacon-y. It was gross. We sent it back.

The good? The $16 wine, the tofu dish, and the green beans. Yum, but still not worth the price...sad day. And just 1 block from me :(
author: Misha F.

description: i give five stars for food and service, and no-stars for noise level.  As good as the food was, I was unable to carry on a conversation with my dining companion with shouting and competing with boisterous patrons all over the restaurant.  I mentioned it to the server and she said that she is starting to loose her hearing due to the noise level.  This can be remedied:  There are nothing but hard surfaces throughout the restaurant, nothing to absorb noise anywhere.  I think that this can be improved upon without insulting the interior designer, who put little thought into acoustics.   One must consider all the senses when dining.  I had a headache by the time I left and spoke to manager who agreed that something has to be done.  Why take someone to dinner if you can't talk to them or have to strain your voice through the meal? Pretty much defeats the purpose of dining out.  Manager was nice enough to comp the appetizer for the bad experience.
author: blaine s.

description:
Ovver priced Vietnamese food. It was a nice place for a brunch with gals. The portions are girly.... so it fits the area because it is not about taste it is about the style. It is very chic and modern.\
The food was just ok.
If you want authentic go to V town.
author: Alison W.

description:
Chucky was too busy with that Dog place...unheavenly and did not successfully inseminate until tonight's birth...Sept. 29, 2009 Tuesday.
Chucky gotta pay da mortgage on da place, so prices are super inflated compared to cost of labor and food.

Parking SUCKS...looks good...same Phan stuff. BUT he OWNS the building...NO outside seating, but BUSH is like a Freeway anyway...H

Try it out before the secret gets YELPeeed

Breakfast options are mainly chicken, beef pho, coconut buns, pork buns, etc. Weekend brunch egg options. Chinese jook with pork.
Throughout the day you can get the lemonade or fresh squeezed orange juice, tea pot options or strong coffee. 

Vegetable options.

Lunch: similar

Dinner: LOOOVE the fried tofu, mushroom, green onions and vinegared sauce!!! LOOOVE it!!! $7
Dessert: Tapioca beads with coconut SORBET and toasted coconut shaving!!!! YUM $6

You can now make reservations on OPEN TABLE too! It is basically busy with NEIGHBORHOOD people that don't make the parking thing an issue.

But if you are on a budget: go to Little SAIGON, you know, on LARKIN street. You are paying haole prices for Viet/Sino cuisine in a sleek environment with an ok wine menu.
author: miriam b.

description:
A nightmare! I don't like to write negative reviews, but I decided to write this one just to advise the managers of this restaurant of what happened to me. Yesterday night I was there with my wife. I ordered hue dumplings to share and then 2 dungeness crab cellophane noodles.
At 2 am last night began my hell. I got huge stomach pains, nausea and vomit. At 4 am my wife started to have the same problems. We both went to urgent care to the hospital and were diagnosed with food poisoning. At 9 am we went back home and I am still on the sofa with big pains, cursing my choice to go to this restaurant.
I don't know exactly what affected me yesterday night, but after yesterday night for sure I never will eat crab again.
I hope the restaurant reads my review and pays more attention in the future to prevent that other people have similar experiences.
By the way this was my third time at this restaurant which is in my neighborhood. The first two times were fine but with this experience I am definitely never going back.
author: Cosimo P.

description: So I went here for lunch and the Slanted Door for dinner ON THE SAME DAY! I know, I know... but I didn't make the lunch reservation so I didn't realize it until it was too late. I'm not complaining though, it was really good. I don't have any not-so-good commentary for this place (I did for my Slanted Door review). I don't like red cabbage, pecans, grapefruit or fruit on my salad period, but the jicama and grapefruit salad was good. That should tell you something. There was spicy noodle dish with fish that was pretty awesome, and I wish I had some sweet sticky rice right now it was so good! I really enjoyed the combination of choices. I wish I could have tried the imperial rolls since that what everyone raves about but I'm not eating meat right  now so I'll have to visit SF again to try them. And I can't give 5 stars to places unless the service is excellent... it's my biggest issue... and what do you know... Out the Door gets 5 stars from me! Check it out.
author: Alfreda D.

description: Meh. It's fine. I mean, the ambiance is tres chic full of hip girls in dresses and men in casual business attire sipping glasses of wine over the five spice noodle dish. Every now and then you even see a baby saddled up to a table...or two. But every time I go here I have to say that I am just a little bit let down. I don't know if it's the fact that I always order to go and the food is cold by the time I get to it or if it's the fusion blend of the ingredients. All I know is that it's not my first, or second, choice. Hell, probably not even my third.
author: Stephanie J.

description:
This is my favorite of all the OTD/Slanted door locations for a few reasons.  

First, you can actually get a table here and unlike the Slanted Door at the Ferry building, you are not RUSHED through dinner and the people are friendly!  I swore I wouldn't go to another Slanted/OTD location after bringing 12 of my work colleagues to the Ferry Building for a group dinner, only to be treated like an unwelcome guest,  but a friend told me about this one several months ago, and I'm a regular now.

On the menu, some must haves:
- daikon rice cake
- crispy imperial rolls
- cellophane crab noodles
- halibut when they have it
- anything with fresh corn in it
- the hoisin spare ribs
- the jook (chicken porridge)
and, all of the vegetable dishes.

The rose wine on draft is amazing.  All of the draft wines are.  

And again, you aren't rushed (wake up Slanted Door in Ferry Building) and your food server will actually SMILE at you here.  It's nice.
author: Jessica B.

description: Mayo on a spring roll?  So much mayo on a spring roll that it oozes out of the sides and covers the side of the take out container?  Disgusting.
author: Caroline K.

description:
Got takeout the other night and 2 dishes were quite good but 1 was so disappointing I have to write this review

The crispy spring rolls were great
The glass noodle dish good

The $20 prawns in a clay pot came with literally 5 small prawns and they were mushy and awful.  That's $4 per prawn folks.
author: Kay R.

description: So... I love Slanted Door. I get it that this is the more casual sister restaurant. Love the ambiance/place was packed last night. Nice hostess sat us without a reservation after a bit of a wait. Had to ask her 20 minutes later to send over a server so we could order drinks (not an auspicious start). Wine keg apparatus was not working... Bathroom was dirty. Spring rolls were amazing as was the shaking beef. Brussel sprouts yummy. Glass noodles with crab were flavorless. Sweet potato dish very dry. Fried chicken dry too. Peanut butter pie at the end was ok. Server was very nice but not around much/restaurant seemed understaffed. Overall a disappointment.
author: Lauren C.

description: Every time I've gone I've only ordered the crab with glass or cellophane noodles so I guess the five stars are just for that. However, I will say that I've always been there with groups of friends and I've never had any one of them complain about their entrees. Definitely a must try if you're in the area.
author: Christina S.

description: I give OTD four stars based on my first and only dish I have had, the beef pho.  The pho was great and tasty and I would definitely have it again.  It may be a bit pricey at $12, though. I will update my review once I return to try other dishes.
author: Paul C.

description:
The food was great. However, the service was really upside down. The beignets were out before the drinks (which sat on the bar for 15 minutes) got to the table 5 feet away. Just basic table waiting and restaurant management organization seems to be missing. 

Get take out or go knowing you could wait 15 minutes just to get water on the table.
author: shannon y.

description:
The food is quite good, service is friendly but unpolished and the prices will leave you feeling like you've just been robbed.

We had the cellophane noodles w/crab, 5-spice chicken and bok choy.  The taste on all three dishes were spot on, but the portions were so small I thought we had ordered from the children's menu.  Also, the flavors were predominantly Chinese and not Vietnamese.

We had a friendly waiter, but I felt a bit rushed through the meal.  

This would have been a 5-star find at half the price.
author: Oscar M.

description:
I came here and ordered off the brunch menu with high expectations. I left wanting something more, feeling that something was missing from my experience. It was not crowded on this particular saturday morning. The decor is typical of the Slanted Door/Out The Door. It is very clean and I am a fan of the open kitchen.

We started with the beignets and lotus sticky rice. Both of these starters did not impress me at all. This is especially try of the sticky rice which was almost flavorless.

The slow cooked eggs dish ALMOST made up for this disappointment. The eggs were cooked to perfection, the beef was VERY tender (though there was more salt and fat in the sauce), the potatoes were crispy and not overly seasoned, and the best part was the BAGUETTE. It had a nice crispy crust and very warm and soft on the inside. I just wish I had more. actually... i wish the dish had more for the price i paid, but i expected this.
author: James T.

description: My friend works around the corner from here and so i met her for lunch.  WOW it was soo good.  We got some sort of noodle dish with pork that was to DIE for.  I seriously think about it all the time!!! Also the imperial rolls are SO SO SO SO good, best ones i've ever had.  I have also tried the pho which was excellent.
author: Julie B.

description:
We went in around 12:30 on Saturday and the place was about 3/4 full, but luckly not too loud (nursing a hangover)!!

We started with the new coconut caramel bun and pork steam bun- delish! 

I had the bahn mi pork xiu mai sammich and it was off the charts. That sauce- I wish I could use it in half my sandwiches at home- so great!

My partner had the chicken pho and it was exactly what I needed to taste to cure the hangover. Wish I lived closer, but will be back if around the area. 

Grace Nguyen really does it well!
author: Art A.

description:
Not sure why this place isn't totally packed. Great alternative to shelling out major bucks at Slanted door. 

Highlights included the imperial rolls, dumplings and short ribs. Also the clay pot dish entree and glass noodle entree were delicious. 

This place is perfect for neighborhood locals or those strolling along Fillmore or hell, go there before a movie at the Kabuki. Just GO!
author: Brandi S.

description:
I'm giving this place a 3 star bc of A) the portion B) the price.  I'm a small person and even for me, the portions were super small.  They really should have been appetizers.  We paid $60 per person and walked out still hungry.. is something wrong here?

I went there with some friends for dinner and ordered the Dungeness crab with clear noodles (little did I know it should have been called noodles with crab).  There was so little crab meat in there and the portion was so small.  We also ordered the filet mignon $28, and each of us got about 2 small pieces, rice, fresh rolls and stir fried bok choy.  I have to give it up for the dessert.  The cashew tart was excellent.
author: Sam S.

description:
I normally had good experiences there for brunch and lunch. My fav was the shredded chicken salad appetizer. 
I decided to take a friend there for dinner and it was disappointing. The shrimp/pork spring rolls ($10) for appetizer was cold and not freshly made. The prawns clay pot had only 6 shrimps in there and it was $20. Sorry to say, it was not worth it. Will think twice about returning for dinner.
author: teatzar s.

description:
2 friends and I went for dinner on a Thursday night and the place was to near capacity. One note of warning in that the acoustics in the place is awful. We walked out of there with our ears ringing and still SHOUTING at each other 30 minutes afterwards b/c it took so long for our hearing to go back to normal. 

That being said, we did enjoy the Brussels sprouts, chicken in clay pot, chard, and tofu dishes we ordered. The menu was clean and unpretentious, though I was hoping for more of the Vietnamese inspired flavors in the options. 

Probably a better place for lunch when the prices are lower and when you're dining alone at night so that you don't have to shout your head off to be heard. 

Service was much better, in that it was prompt.
author: Linh T.

description:
I really like how the space lays out and the open kitchen.  I sat towards the front of the restaraunt with a group of 5.

The service was lacking and probably why I'm only giving three stars.  I don't think it was the servers fault as much as being understaffed.  We put our drink orders in and 5 minutes plus passed and the hostess came by to get our drink orders.  The drinks came out shortly after that.

We ordered the shrimp and jicama roll and the spring rolls to start.  I did not like the spring rolls, they were just average.  Presentation was great.

For starters we ordered the crispy oysters and the heirloom tomatoe salad.  The oysters were awesome, although for $13 you only get 4 of them.  Great breading and great taste.  I do not like tomatoes but everyone at the table loved the salad.

For the main we ordered the halibut, scallops and claypot chicken.  All were great and worth ordering again.

The last problem was on the timing and again I don't think it was all the fault of the server.  The entree's came out and we were half way done and the vegetables came out.  We ordered the eggplant and spinach which were both great but the timing kind of ruined the meal.

Even though I really like the ambiance, decor, plating of the food...I would hesitate to go back due to the service.  I also think the description shows $$, I think it is a bit expensive.
author: Tim G.

description: I ordered lemon grass pork over rice - the egg was overcooked and had the consistency of cardboard - no taste.  The pork was very sweet, but no other discernible flavor.  The rice was dry  and had been in the steamer way too long.
author: Alan F.

description: Great food, atmosphere, and service. A lot of veg options too. Love the big table they have for multiple parties. Would definitely go back .
author: Morgan O.

description: Had the chicken pho, it was great! Also had the shrimp rolls as an appetizer. Peanut sauce is great!
author: Juan Cheerio A.

description:
Overall impressions:  good food, struggling service, makes that joke about soft openings in Oceans 13 more relevant.

My group of four went during the "soft opening" for this restaurant and while there are some good things going on, I am going to have to see if the "hard" or "conclusive opening" fixes some stuff before I give this more than three stars.

The food is pret-ty choice.  We got the rice cakes which were fantastic, fried spring rolls, the steak bavette, halibut, and the claypot chicken, and all of them were received well.  The chicken was considered by two people to be the best dish, while Molly came down in favor of the halibut.  Everything was a little spicy, which was fun.  

The service and decor need some big time work though.  The benches are made of some sort of metal that never warms up - apparently, cushions are coming but weren't there when we ate.  Our server also wasn't totally sure about some of the dishes on the menu, which again may be corrected by the time the soft hard final opening comes around.  Or whatever.

One fun thing - all of our beers came in wine glasses.  A little quirky, probably wont happen again, but I thought it gave the evening a touch of class.
author: Dave E.

description:
We went there for Mother's Day after not being able to get a reservation at Slanted Door.  They had a brunch menu, rather than a full menu so maybe it was our mistake for not asking.  We ordered the few Vietnamese dishes on the menu expecting a creative take on the traditional, or a fusion inspired dish.  We started with the crispy Imperial rolls.  They were good, the skin was crispy just like in Vietnam and they were served with lettuce leaves and basil leaves. (a nice touch)  The entrees were a pork dish and Five Spice chicken.  Although the quality of the meat was excellent, the dishes were nothing special, and certainly no better than what you'd get in a basic Vietnamese restaurant at half the price.  I didn't care for the noise level (high), the high tech chrome and glass look of an upscale Denny's with tables right next to each other in a row.
The service was basic- our waiter took the order, brought it out and then gave us the check.  I was tempted to not leave a tip because there basically was no "service".

Anyway, we won't go again- a $50 bill for a basic lunch with no drinks.  Go dowen the street to Bun Mee and pay a third the price.
author: Deborah H.

description: I was not satisfied with the service.  I frequent neighborhood restaurants and this was the worst service I have experienced.  The food was overpriced and the quality was adequate.   There are much better restaurants in the Fillmore district.
author: Don M.

description: It's not bad for a quick lunch place. I came here for the chicken rice porridge. Although it was pretty flavorless, the consistency of the porridge was nice and thick. It came with things topped on it like crunchy onions and cilantro, which I was not fond of.
author: Stephanie Y.

description: My lord... that is just about all I could say walking out of out the door this past weekend... Currently living in DC where the indy restaurant scene is wretched I always rejoice in my trips to SF just for the unique flavors available! The various Asian cuisines within the city limits are particularly favorites for me so I am always up for new spots.. My sister brought me to out the door for brunch and it was pretty damn amazing.. We started with Vietnamese coffee and beignets (which were good but I like the ones at Kate's better), vegetable spring rolls and the green papaya salad... the ingredients were super fresh and the flavors fabulous! I had the Banh Mi for my main course, which is always a fav for me when I get to a Vietnamese spot!
author: Frank L.

description: 2nd visit to OTD.  It had been a while, so I can't say what I had previously.  Overall, it was good. Has the imperial rolls and the green papaya salad. The rolls were very good.  The salad was nice, but expected more.  Some additional papaya and maybe warm tofu might have made it better.  The big question is if the venue is really worth the price as you can really get similar quality at lower prices at some of the good hole in the wall spots in SF.  One note, it is loud, so if you want a quiet meal, this is not the spot
author: Markus S.

description: OTD is great!  It wasn't difficult to get a reservation, the vibe was relaxed yet busy, the service was great and our food was delicious.  There's not much more you can ask for.  It's also very reasonably priced.  Our server was very knowledgeable about the wine, especially the wines on tap that we weren't familiar with.  The spring rolls were pretty standard, but very good, the ceviche was cold and fresh, the chicken pot was super flavorful, and I think my absolute favorite dish of the night was the crab with cellophane noodles.  It was so delicate, but had incredible flavor.  Unfortunately we were too full to try the desserts, but we'll be back (which is saying a lot for this city)!
author: Brie B.

description: Totally underwhelming.  Hear great things about Slanted Door, but only had time for a quick lunch and thought this might be good.  I've had Vietnamese food twice and good with larger portions for half the price in less foody cities.
author: Chris G.

description: We came in during a busy lunch time and were seated right away (there were just two of us). The waiter was ready to take our order right away. The menu had a great variety of options and the food came out very promptly. My friend ordered the green papaya salad. I tried some and it was really flavorful. I had just a couple of sides- the vegetarian steam bun, which was delicious as always (mushrooms- yum!), and a side of sauteed kale, which was good as well (if you like your greens). We were just having a light lunch this time, but on another occasion I tried their desserts and they were great too- I seem to remember a pain perdue that was to die for.
author: Aimee L.

description: This place had pretty mixed reviews so I was a bit hesitant to check it out.  However, it made it on 7X7's Big Eat list which is recommendation enough for me.  I took my boyfriend here for his birthday this weekend and we had a very positive experience.  We ordered the jicama and grapefruit salad (which I'd had before at the westfield Out the Door), the chicken clay pot and kale, along with 2 glasses of wine.  All the food was delicious, service was great and the wine is awesome.  They have a very unique wine list with lots of local wines on tap and were very helpful with recommendations.  My only issue with it was the noise level which was loud enough to make conversation difficult.  Overall though a very solid dinner spot.
author: Heather D.

description: We went there during a late lunch and I just love the open space in there. We split the veggie spring rolls which are fresh and great and their version of lomo salltado but vietnamese style which was perfect. I always love returning to Out the Door
author: Chris D.

description:
Went there for lunch the other day while playing hooky from work. 

The place is a really nice, bright space that has a buzz of activity but (at least at 2 PM on a Tuesday) is not too crowded or chaotic. I was a bit sick so I opted for the Beef Pho noodle soup dish. We also got the Spring Rolls to start, and the shrimp noodle dish. Everything was very plentiful and quite tasty. (Nothing remarkable, but very satisfying - particularly for me in my weakened state...) 

I had been a bit confused by the name ("Out the Door"), thinking that they delivered (they dont, far as I can tell) and the association with Slanted Door. (It's quite a lot more casual, and the food is a *lot* more average.) Nevertheless, I was very happy with the lunch experience. Food was good, and service was attentive & friendly. I'm not sure, though, whether I'd make the trip back for dinner in the evening -- it just didnt seem that special. (In addition, the restaurant is located in a slightly odd spot in the Fillmore off the main Fillmore St. drag...) But - good for the casual lunch (and it serves as a superior replacement for the extinct Zao Noodles that used to be in the same general area.)
author: donal c.

description:
The meal at OTD had both its high and low points. I'll start with the positive. The space at OTD is very sleek and modern...in other words, just my style. There were some definite hits during the meal, namely the braised pork - mouthwateringly good! I also really enjoyed the Thai basil ice cream...I always get excited when a restaurant offers a more unconventional ice cream flavor, and this was deee-licious!

However, I had high expectations for this restaurant and the overall experience fell kind of flat. First off, the service was spotty - the waitress came by pretty much immediately after I sat down (my friend was patiently waiting for me) to take our order, and of course we weren't ready, so she said she would come back. It was definitely a while before she returned to take our order. My friend also had to follow up several times to determine the whereabouts of her second glass of wine.

In addition, the rest of the dishes were just ok, in my book. The pork meatballs were probably my least favorite: the vermicelli that they were paired with was sitting on the plate in a cold blob and didn't have the best texture. The brussel sprouts and mussels were both good, but not over the top amazing, which we expected based on recommendations we had gotten for what to order.

The bottom line: I won't be rushing out the door to eat at OTD for dinner again, but I am admittedly intrigued by the breakfast so plan to give that a whirl.
author: Rachel G.

description:
Having dined at OTD on three occations now, twice for lunch and once for dinner, I noticed that with each subsequent visit, there was less of a "wow" factor.

Service can be curt at the counter, but the hostess(es) on our visits were very police and courteous, trying to please the crowds coming in when there was clearly no space available.

After our most recent visit, I concluded that the food offerings here, be they Pho or buns, are really no more delicious than a much less expensive local Vietnamese restaurant in The Mission or The Tenderloin.
author: Rafael R.

description:
All I wanted was some Pho. It was rainy and cold, and I couldn't imagine any meal being anywhere near as satisfying. I was meeting a friend at her apartment in Lower Pac Heights, and Out the Door was the closest Pho we could find. Since moving to San Francisco and into the Marina, I haven't really had any good Pho and I was having MAJOR withdrawals! 

The restaurant was very nice and clean looking, and we were seated right away. Our server wasn't super friendly by any means, but she answered my questions and got the job done, so I won't complain. Maybe she was having an off day. Anyway, I started with a chicken steamed bun. I had never had one before because they are always filled with pork and I don't eat pork, so I have nothing to really compare this one to. It was ok. Nothing special. I moved along to my main course, the Beef Pho, which was $12! Pretty pricey for Pho, but I was expecting it and just dealt with it because I REALLY wanted some hot, steamy, delicious Vietnamese Soup that I had been deprived of. The soup itself wasn't bad, and the noodles were cooked to perfection, however, the beef was not good at all. I ended up pulling about 4-5 pieces that were just fat out of my soup. The flavor of the meat wasn't great and was just downright disappointing. 

I'm not sure that I would return to Out The Door--there are just too many good restaurants in San Francisco to waste my time on a mediocre one like this.
author: Holly G.

description:
Out The Door (or OTD) is another one of those Fillmore Street restaurants that seems like it would be unfriendly to families, but is actually welcoming.  The front desk staff is not baby-crazy, but most of the waitstaff is.  The first time we ate there, the entire kitchen came out one-by-one to say hi to B and squeeze her cheeks (this may be because B is the cutest baby in the entire world, so YMMV).  The chef also sent over a special bowl of rice porridge from off the menu because he thought B would like it.  She did, and we may have taken a few bites too.

The food here is amazing--lots of the same stuff you can get at Slanted Door, but without the endless wait and noise.  Most kids could find something they like on the menu.  We usually deconstruct some spring rolls for B, and order an extra side of non-spicy vegetables for her.  For us, our favorite is Chicken in a Clay Pot, but we've always been happy with what we've ordered, even when I got the sardines last time (I really ate two whole fish, bones and everything!  Well, not the heads).  And they have wine on draft, which is tasty and cheap.  The Free Flow Sauvignon Blanc is especially good with spicy foods.

High chairs?  Yes.
Changing tables?   Didn't ask, but I don't think so.
Stroller-friendly?  They will store your stroller in a closet if it's small, or stash it in a corner if it's not.
Noise level?  Not too bad, but I bet it gets really loud as the night progresses (lots of flat surfaces for noise to bounce off of)
General baby-friendliness?  Rather high, but I'd go during an off time to be sure.
author: Jennifer G.

description:
Perfect brunch for a chilly morning in the city.

My friends and I arrived at 9AM this past Sunday and we're immediately seated.  We started our order with the French press coffee and beignets and Vietnamese coffee, as well as the coconut pull bread.  The beignets and coconut pull bread were soft and very tasty and went well with the coffee.   I easily could have eaten multiple pieces of the coconut bread.  

For our main meals, two of us had the chicken porridge, one had the chicken pho, and the other had the poached eggs with crispy potatoes.  All meals were unique in taste and will continue to bring us back to Out the Door whether it is for brunch, lunch, or dinner.
author: Caroline Q.

description: I could give one more star solely for the woman busing our table, which was done better and with more graciousness than everything else last night. Our server did not appear to want to be there, or at least did not want to be serving us, and while I am totally understanding when restaurants can't accommodate my onion allergy with a particular dish, I have never been told (until last night) that there was not one dish that could be altered to fit my needs. Ouch. I stuck with the vegetarian spring rolls and the daikon cake (both good).  There were three of us, and we drank two bottles of wine, and the bill came out to over $200. For the kind of food we ate, and the lack of happy service, that's too much even for SF.  And the place is so loud! A good restaurant to take someone you don't want to talk to.
author: Margarita R.

description:
i mean you can't go wrong - Slanted Door WITHOUT THE WAIT!!

i love all the standard go-to's:  spring rolls, imperial rolls, crab cellophane noodles, shaking beef.  

also looooove their pho, wonton noodles, banh cuon off the breakfast/lunch menus.
author: Anna V.

description: Great place to take a veggie friend when you still want to enjoy yourself. Wine on tap + beaker (with about 3 glasses in it) = great value for 2! Service was great and loved the atmosphere.
author: Caeli M.

description: I guess it's what I would expect from a vietnamese style restaurant in pac heights -  overpriced, but quality ingredients, good vibe, nice decor. decent lunch spot to go with coworkers if you work in the area. I would recommend the grilled five spiced chicken over vermicelli noodles or the chicken pho.
author: Verna L.

description: A friend and I ate here after a concert in the area early on a Sunday evening. My Louisiana shrimp in a crock pot was delicious...but there were no veggies in it...my friend had a crab pasta that had almost no crabmeat in it. I will eat there again sometime, but not anytime soon.
author: Kay H.

description: My favorite time to go to OTD is for breakfast or brunch - it's one of my favorite breakfast spots in the City.  Love the fact that I can have a stellar Western or Asian breakfast.  Fave breakfast foods:  soft scrambled eggs (I prefer it without the crab), homemade brioche with whipped pate/butter/strawberry jam, pancakes, chicken porridge.  Great Vietnamese coffee too.
author: Mariam N.

description:
We've been fans of the Slanted Door and the other Out the Door locations so went to Bush St. to give it a shot.  Now this review is on take out because we were told that there was a 30 minute wait but being impatient that evening we opted for take out. Turns out the wait would have been 10 minutes...oh well, next time. 

We really, really liked the beef bavette. 

We were really, really disappointed with the green papaya salad. There was hardly any papaya just a lot of fillers (cucumber, carrots, and celery-the celery was so overpowering). 

Service is still being worked out. Everyone was very friendly but it seemed like they were all running around like chickens with their heads cut off!

Portions are tiny.
author: Romeo And Lola K.

description: I looked forward to this meal for a long time - there's so much buzz around Out the Door, the Slanted Door's sister restaurant, yet I felt like the food was a bit overpriced. I loved the cellophane crab noodles, but most of the other dishes I tried from the prix fixe menu were not too memorable. I believe we had the calamari, the fried chicken, brussels sprouts (way too sweet for my palate), and the pan seared scallops. The food quality is good, but I left feeling like OTD was pretty expensive for what it was.
author: Jana C.

description: Still sad over the closing of the OTD Westfield Mall basement location.  But, glad that the fillmore location is still open.  Food is always delicious and good quality - green papaya salad and chicken noodles soup are my favorite!
author: Dagny C.

description:
Update,

Since my initial visit I've been back here and it has improved drastically (the original review is below). They have tweaked the menu, and the selection is much improved. Also, their brunch service is a treat, and a pleasant change from the norm.


--------------------
I'll be eager to come back here once only after they've gotten the opening kinks worked out.

The Good:
  - Cellophane noodles with Crab, a great carryover from Slanted Door.
  - Pacific Heights location: we need more restaurants like this in the neighborhood.
  - The decor: for the most part the decor is modern and trendy, although in my opinion the pine wall looked lame.
  - The pepper appetizer was amazing.

The Bad:
  - The menu is very limited. There weren't many dishes that I wanted to try.
  - They don't have the duck from the other OTD locations, which is by far and away my favorite.
  - The pork dish is terrible. It's served at room temperature, lacks flavor, and has a soggy texture. Seriously, what were they thinking?
  - The service is pretty bad. I ordered a glass of wine with my meal and didn't get it until I was almost done eating. And they forgot to bring on of our appetizers (however the did give us a free glass of wine as an apology).
  - The corkage is $25. It is only $10 at the downtown location.
  - The wines by the glass are pretty boring, and a bit prescriptive.
author: Matthew S.

description:
this place is like pablo sandoval...  it can play 3rd, it can play first, it can catch in an emergency... stikes out from time to time, but leads the team in HRs and everyone loves it

seriously though, you can go for a casual brunch or lunch or early dinner with kids... oryou can take your girl on a nice date... or you can bring a client

the food is very good and you never have to wait too long.   the tap wines are great value

eat this:  spring roll, ribs, shaking beef, one of the fishes, a couple of the vegetables
drink this:  free flow
author: nick g.

description: The Slanted Door's little sister. . . it's a little more casual, but the spring rolls are just as heavenly and I had a very tasty jicama-grapefruit slaw that I would love to figure out how to make.  I'm always too full for dessert but the menu looked great.
author: Ann K.

description: I hadn't eaten here in a few years; I guess I just kind of forgot it was nearby, because I'm always wishing there was a place to get good Vietnamese food in Pac Heights. Anyway, I ate here today and tried the papaya salad, which was very good--not spicy (I prefer spicy, but can deal with that).  Portion was large and I wanted to try more than one thing on the menu so I ate some and brought the rest home.  I tried the bahn xeo, a dish that I totally fell in love with on a trip to Vietnam earlier this year. It was good but should have been cooked just a little longer, in my opinion.  The middle part of the crepe (the outer part, not the inside!) did not crisp up and was pretty soggy from the onion and sprouts, but the food was tasty.  Service was excellent; my water glass was never empty and servers stopped by throughout the meal to ask if everything was good and if I needed anything.  A great solid restaurant that I'll now remember to go back to much more often.  Looking forward to trying the congee on a cold foggy day!
author: Eve C.

description:
OTD Charles Phan's (Slanted Door) latest addition right on Pacific Heights. The restaurant space is very interesting and the food was very good we started with the crispy imperial rolls, shrimp, pork and mint, and read leaf lettuce plus my dinner companion and I shared the spring rolls, shrimp, pork shoulder, mint with a spicy peanut sauce this by the way is one of my favorite dishes and for our main course we had/shared organic tofu, lemongrass, shitake mushroom and roasted chili and jasmine rice delicious!  You may find the food portions a bit small.  

Now, service was friendly but not efficient and lacking promptness. It was a Tuesday night, so I guess they were not expecting that many customers. You can really tell that they were so short staff, since the hostess was acting as a food runner too.

I have been to Slanted Door a few times and as you know it is very challenging to get a table there since the views of the bay from Slanted Doors and just fabulous.  But OTD will be an option to you really want to try the cuisine of Charles Phan, plus Pacific Heights is a lovely neighborhood.
author: Ernesto C.

description: Not Oriental or real Vietnamese food at all! Just a copy but far from good especially the pho ( ph )! Not real stock soup at all! Doesn't smell star anise and beef / bones that have cooked for hours! They even spell it wrong and call it "phô"! I told the lady and she doesn't even care ....? Not friendly service here either...
author: Caty H.

description: This place is great!! The food is always delicious, no matter what you order. I particularly recommend the dungeness crab with cellophane noodles, green onion, and sesame oil. The seared day boat scallops are quite delicious with spicy pineapple-coconut sauce. Try the brocollini and egglplant too!
author: Mei F.

description: One of my favorite asian restaurants in the city.  Consistently excellent ingredients, dishes, and service. OTD's low star rating is really very surprising to me.
author: Blake G.

description:
We had a great breakfast at Out the Door today and the 40 minute drive to San Francisco is definitely well worth it. The restaurant on Bush street is not properly marked, in fact we passed it a couple of times. Parking, as expected, is very difficult to find even on a Sunday morning. The interior is modern and I really love the colors and combination of materials they used. very muted greens, grays, sage and whites makes for a relaxing and soothing experience. The service is really good and careful. The menu selection is easy to read and simply laid-out with prices very affordable. 

The coconut pulled bread, chicken bun and the beignet were delicious. My favorite is the beignet or fried soufle. Delicious! I had the pancakes and my wife had the chicken porridge. The pancakes was absolute heaven, probably the best I've ever eaten. The portion was perfect with diced assorted fruits and bacon bits. The warm maple syrup was just perfect. The porridge was very tasty and the chicken in it perfectly cooked but I was a little disappointed because I tasted a little hint of MSG or MSG like taste to it. It could have been a perfect meal if not for that. I would still highly recommend the place to friends.
Next stop would be the Ferry building branch.
author: Jim M.

description:
Stellar service -- and the food is amazing.  
We've gone here 4 times in the last year... and I can say that each time, the food and the service has been great.  Last night, I had the Organic Chicken Claypot... Simply delicious, the food arrived quickly and 2 glasses of wine later, I was super-satisfied and left with a big smile on my face.  Ambiance is nice, sitting at the bar is comfy too....  many wines on tap.  Good pours.  Highly, highly recommended.
author: Chris O.

description: Kind of cold and austere on the inside of this spot.  The food was sizzling in the clay pot and the sticky rice with coconut milk and plantains was far out.  Food is solid and staff works hard to make everything good.
author: D B.

description: I keep thinking of Out the Door every time I hear Altidore's name.  I love the veggie steamed buns.
author: Wakako U.

description:
I love the food but the service is not good. And now that my friends went there two nights ago, it confirmed how bad it is ...They had the WORST experience with the manager. Even tough the waitress was ok about them bringing their own wine,  the manager was very rude after he figured it out that they were drinking their own wine. 

It is a shame that they have good food but TERRIBLE service.... It is not a place to go back!!
author: Monica R.

description:
One of our favorite places to eat in the Lower Pac Hts hood. Interesting food, good service, cool dining room. They have reasonably priced house wines too, and great teas if you don't drink. The open kitchen assures that this place is also very clean, but without adding too much noise. We like to sit at the bar and watch them prepare the food on surface-of-the-sun-like hot wok burners. You can dress-up or not, the dining room has a mix of both.

The place is not very well marked with minimal signage, so look closely as you turn the corner going west off Fillmore. It's about 3-4 doors down.
author: Steven G.

description: For some reason, I've forgotten about OTD for the past year even though I live 4 blocks from the restaurant. Being a huge fan of Slanted Door and not wanting to waiting 1 month + for a reservation, my boyfriend and I decided to go back to OTD this past Friday. Why have we forgotten about you?!?! We ordered the drinks and the imperial rolls for appetizer, which were the highlight of the meal. We also ordered the clay pot chicken, the blackened cod and the corn with mushrooms, all of which were excellent. To top it all off, we finished with the lemon tart. Everything was fresh and delicious, but still a bit pricey. We noticed lots of to go orders and we're thinking about doing that next time since I live in the neighborhood and I won't be going a year without the imperial rolls.
author: Colby L.

description:
Reviews of OTD found herein and other "ethnic" food restaurants in the Bay Area that criticize the food as "not authentic," or some variation on that sentiment, miss what is so great about the Bay Area.  There are numerous restaurants that do provide an authentic meal and there are others that are aspiring to something different.  I don't get the impression that OTD is attempting to serve strictly authentic Vietnamese food, rather this OTD, and Mr. Phan's other Vietnamese restaurants are strongly inspired by Vietnamese food, but its not your mother's cooking.

On to the experience.  We sat at the bar and our server failed to bring us one of the appetizers we ordered, the green papaya salad.  The problem is, that it took over 15 minutes for the salad to come after we informed our server that it had not arrived.  This salad must already be prepared, at least its components, well before service.  Then, our entree arrived approximately 30 to 40 minutes after that.  During the interim between our salad and the entree, our server never returned to take an additional drink order or apologize for the wait, although a manager did come over and acknowledge the wait.  When our entree, short ribs, did finally arrive, however, the ribs were cold in the center near the bone.  This is inexcusable.  I understand things can get cross in the kitchen and take a bit longer, but especially when it does come late, it must be properly prepared.

The problem, of course, is that the meal cost over $100.  At such a price, the shortcomings in service and execution of the short ribs earned this OTD location 2 stars.  I get the sense that the Phan empire is expanding a bit too rapidly to maintain the quality service and preparation that was the impetus to the rapid addition of new Phan restaurants.
author: Colleen B.

description: I drive up and down this road a lot and never knew it was there!!! Maybe they should make their signage a little larger or maybe they are trying to keep this a secret gem.  This is a great place to go when you just want some home style cooking.  We had the crab corn soup which was really tasty.  I wish it came in a bigger bowl.  Why can't someone make a soup place where it is all you can drink???? Especially when the soup is sooooo good.  We also had the green papaya salad, the salt and pepper squid and the clay pot chicken, which is my favorite.  I can eat that every day....wish they made a noodle soup with that base and those chicken!!   My only suggestion is the rice....i know everyone would think rice is such an easy thing to make but to make very good rice, it is not that easy...you really need the perfect amount of water to have it come out just the right texture.  The rice here was a little tooooo wet and sticky.  It is almost like very early stages of congee.
author: Mee-stique K.

description: Food was delicious! As a group we tried a bunch of the vegetable dishes and the ribs - all were full of flavour. Love that they list the farms that supply each vegetable.
author: Kate G.

description: Black cod and roasted cauliflower are awesome.
author: Carlo M.

description: A little over priced for white-washed Vietnamese food, in my opinion.  I was disappointed with the pho.  The broth was not very flavorful and I was underwhelmed by the meat.  The green papaya salad is not bad.  Frankly, I would rather go to a cheaper Vietnamese restaurant on Clement Street or in the Tenderloin and get more down-to-earth food that is half the price.  That being said, the quality of the ingredients is very high and the space is pretty cool.
author: Jenny K.

description: I have never eaten at Slanted Door.  So it was great to try out the neighborhood sister restaurant.  Liked the open feel and helpful staff. Every dish was delicious!  Rice dumplings had a chewy texture and sat in a thin sauce that was sweetly spicy.  Glass noodles with lily buds was a wonderful mix of usual and unusual ingredients, prawns in a clay pot sizzled with flavors and fragrances and the warm medjool dates stuffed with sesame rounded the meal off perfectly.  Belgian beer went well with everything.
author: Ash A.

description: Love all the food here.  Imperial rolls nice crispy and slightly chewy...it doesn't get any better than this.  Also had the awesome clay pot chicken, cellophane crab noodles, fresh shrimp rolls, shanghai dumplings, and brown rice.  Everything was excellent.  I know it's a little pricy, but I always leave satisfied.
author: Kevin J.

description: I sat at the bar to watch the line of cooks. I was amazed at the sues chef inserting her fingers at the food while it was plated to check for salt. Mind you the plate was already salted. The food was Ok. Didn't care for the carpaccio too many peanuts and too acidic. I was also perplexed at the fact that every order had the ticket  order sitting right on top of the food. I guess don't sit at the bar if you don't want to see this. I do mind this as my dinner was not cheap and thats not the way to fire plates when you have an open kitchen.. Very disappointed!!
author: Sepulveda M.

description: Love that this is local for me, and a great approachable way to grab a casual Slanted Door dinner. Imperial rolls, short ribs and black cod made for a tasty dinner!  Ribs had a rich sauce.  Cod had a nice, light gingery sauce. Not inexpensive, but was a great meal on a rainy night! Walked in on Friday with no reservations and despite the fact we got that 'no reservations??' look, we were able to be seated at the chef's counter immediately.
author: Danielle R.

description:
Looks like my view is pretty different than most of the other reviewers.  
I think the food is incredible - I absolutely love the flavors (if someone knows of better papaya salad, spring rolls and/or crab noodles in SF, PLEASE tell me!!!).  I like that the portions aren't huge - and yes it is expensive, but I love the taste so much that I think it's worth it.  My peeve is with the service, as I've said before. The friendliness has improved a smidge, which is cool (I got smile the other day!). But the efficiency is still poor.  I've gotten to the point now where I insist on ordering my drink before my food because otherwise I am at least half way through my salad (sometimes finished) before the wine arrives.  Without any apology.  Why does it take longer to pour a glass than it takes someone to make a salad?  The cooks are busier than the person behind the bar - I watch.  It is such a mystery to me.  And forget trying to get your spring roll as your second course - I say pointedly every time that I want it after the salad and it always comes first - another seemingly simple timing request that cannot be met.  So again, I insist on waiting until after my salad has arrived before I order my springrolls. Sucks that I have to do this, but I cannot resist the food so I keep coming back.  Just wish they'd send someone out from the Ferry Building (where service is FAB in a much bigger, more hectic setting) to make service better.
author: Ellen H.

description: Great beef pho! Came here for brunch but I wasn't in the mood for eggs or breakfast food. I had a huge bowl of pho, and added in the spicy sauce that came with. Tons of noodles.. I was stuffed. Makes me want to find a pho place of my own this good back home.
author: Ander J.

description: Pretty good spot to have close by. Had the Spring rolls which were pretty good, but the highlights of the meal were the pork dumplings and the claypot chicken. We both really loved the claypot chicken, very delicious! Would definitely come back and order this again and again. Only downside is slightly more expensive then what I was expecting for what we got to eat.
author: Brian K.

description: Had a really fun dinner here! Saki, wonderful brussels sprouts (a favorite of mine) and something fantastic w/shrimp. Great waiter! The kitchen is visible and they're a hustlin' back there!
author: Natasha M.

description: A nice find this weekend. We enjoyed the great wine list (and wine). Tasty dishes and good portions. Vegetarian friendly too.
author: Randall R.

description: My boyfriend and I were able to get in here fairly easily (at the counter) on a Saturday night at the last minute.  I had the dungeness crab noodles which were excellent! We also loved the wine on tap.
author: Anne H.

description:
A solid four stars!  I feel kind of like I was cheating on Slanted Door by "settling" for Out the Door, but having just tried the more famous parent restaurant the previous week, I knew I was in perfect position to compare and contrast.

I really enjoyed the stylish interior of Out the Door.  No, it's not the sleek real estate that Slanted Door offers, but that's um, a function of the lack of a beautiful body of water called the Bay to provide diners with picturesque views of sailboats, the Bay Bridge, and Treasure Island.  None the less, Out the Door offered the same fare at slightly more reasonable prices (or were they the same?).  The service was excellent and friendly.

I had the crispy imperial rolls and the asparagus and dungeness crab soup.  I was puzzled by the purpose of the lettuce leafs that came with my rolls, but I loved the sweet/bitter dipping sauce on the side.  The asparagus soup was clean and filling, as any voluminous liquid might be.

I'm a lemonade freak, and this one was a refreshing thirst quencher.

I think I'll be back!  With so many great Asian influences fused together in bright and healthy dishes, I have nothing to sing but praises!  Friends in Pac Heights, you're lucky to have this place in the neighborhood!
author: Lindsay M.

description:
Being Vietnamese myself, I was very hesitant in trying a high-end, organic yet sleek-looking place...but I did give it a try (4x actually)! 

I was amazed that most of the dishes were not only delicious but tasted like authentic Vietnamese food! For starters, I absolutely love their salads which are very refreshing, light and tasty! I love their Green Papaya Salad (w/ tofu, picked carrots, rau ram, roasted peanuts & fish sauce), Jicama & Grapefruit salad (w/ red cabbage, candied pecans & sweet soy sauce) and daikon rice cakes (w/ shiitake mushrooms, cilantro & spicy soy sauce). Their Vietnamese crepes (banh xeo) are very authentic (loaded w/ shrimps, chicken & sprouts), crunchy & perfect! Their Banh Cuon (more like banh nam) is a steamed rice cake with ground pork, onions and mushrooms are really good, just slightly on the soft side. I also love their noodle bowls, especially grilled lemongrass pork, grileld garlic prawns and grilled five spice chicken breast all noodle bowls come w/ egg rolls (different but quite tasty!). Another must try is their Shaking Beef dish which is filet mignon sauteed w/ watercress, red onions and lemon - although it's not very authentic it is still very delicious and perfectly cooked dish.

 Unfortunately, one of Vietnamese fame dishes, pho, was a huge disappointing miss. The broth didn't have the proper seasonings of anise star, celery seeds, cinnamon, coriander & etc and it tasted very bland. In addition, it's not served with the traditional pho noodles. Seriously?! If you compare it to a regular soup then it's not too bad but it's definitely not cooked well enough to be called pho. Lost a star because of the price-- $12 for small pho bowl during lunch. Are you kidding me?

Overall, delicious food w/ a pricey menu. Come early or late during lunch hour-- trust me, it gets really busy!
author: linh d.

description:
Ive been to OTD several times since it opened and it was always at least 4 stars.  The service over time has really gone downhill and it shows in the quality of food.  The waiters seem unhappy to be there. 
It was a late lunch and  I was dining at the counter when someone placed an enormous platter of food close to me.  I realized  this was the feeding station for the wait staff.  They all took turns filling their dishes from this big platter and either sitting down for lunch or grabbing a bite on the go. I felt as if I were an intruder at a cocktail party. 
 After that was over, the counter was cleaned and our waiter brought the entire contents of the cash register to the counter and started making piles of bills. He was there close to a half hour counting and adding thousands of dollars. we were 15 feet from the front door and in full view from the street.  I felt so uncomfortable that they were inviting a holdup and I would be in the middle of it. 
The whole experience has turned me off to all the Slanted Door restaurants.
author: carmine g.

description: I have been to this restaurant about 6 times (lunch/brunch and dinner) because I like a few things on the menu and it's close to my home.   The service has always been dismal but I kept giving them breaks because they were new.  Enough.  A nice "hello" and smile isn't enough folks.  Every single time I have been, they botch the order (e.g., they bring me another person's glass of wine or food, forgot something we ordered).  About half of the time someone drops something and it shatters on the floor.  Even at half capacity on a Tuesday night, it is so loud you have to lean in to hear your dining companion (at a small table for 2 with nobody on either side of you!)  This is ridiculous. The imperial rolls and pho aren't worth this.
author: Sharon W.

description:
Best heirloom tomato n yellow watermelon salad ever! The halibut ceviche DELISH and calamri w jalapeno crunchy garlic and grilled pineapple AMAZING. Clay pot prawns also fab. Love the wine list too. 
Wait staff are so friendly and the hostess (short, curly hair, big smiles) a doll.
author: Christina g.

description:
I had a ladies catch up night with 2 of my faves here last night and it was a perfect weekday evening. The décor inside is ultra sleek but still cozy. We started with a carafe of Pinot, and loved that it was served in a laboratory flask! 

I highly recommend doing the sharing thing to try a little of everything. The vegetarian spring rolls were oh so fresh. We also got the pork meatballs (nicely flavored but awkward to eat in the lettuce wraps), bok choy with shitake mushrooms (one of my top veggies but slightly on the salty side), crab cellophane noodles (yum!), and the chicken claypot which we wanted to lick the bottom of. The total came to about $100 including tip, which was slightly on the high side, but because we had such a fun night it didn't bother us too much. 

The service was also attentive but never rushed us which made us dwindle just a little longer. Nothing stood out on the dessert menu, except for the tea, but at about $5 a cup, I would rather make myself some tea at home. 

I would def come back to this neighborhood nook!
author: Rena Z.

description: The food is delicious.  Go to when I need soup or any yummy plates.
author: Lisa E.

description: Food was awesome. Imperial and Spring rolls where perfect. Wine prices was unreal. $4.50 for a glass of Sauvignon Blanc. The crab with noodles tasted over the top good. The only criticism was the food came so quick, we actually had to stagger our order quite a bit otherwise we would have been done and out the door in 25 minutes.
author: Matt G.

description: After reviewing OTD yesterday, and an email to the manager, I must say the response from management was swift and sincere.  Still, I've experienced much better.  OTD Westfield's mall will still be my choice or, of course, the mother ship, Slanted Door.  Food is fine..just the service is horrifically, horribly, horrid.
author: Sonia C.

description:
Went here for a Sunday brunch recently and sat at the noodle bar/chef counter. The food was amazing from beginning to end. I am a big boy so I ordered lots of food, beignets, 5 spice duck noodle soup, soft scrambled eggs with a miniature housemade baguette, braised beef hash with slow eggs and a couple mimosas. All the plates were a good portion and a value. Remember, they use only the best ingredients from local sources and you can taste the quality in the food. 

They also have wine on tap ranging from $4 a glass to $16, something for everyone. 

My advice: dont listen to the haters and go eat there right now.
author: Thomas F.

description: eh. i really wanted to like this place given all i had heard about it, but i wasn't particularly impressed.  we started with the pork and shrimp summer rolls and shrimp and chive dumplings then shared the dungeness crab noodles.  everything was definitely tasty but nothing was really all that special.  and for the price i expected more.
author: Lisa C.

description: Great service, and fresh food.  Started with the papaya salad, and crispy imperial rolls, which were both awesome. The papaya salad was a great way to start the meal, I highly recommend.  While the crispy imperial rolls were fried they still tasted light and fresh. For dinner, shared the shrimp with a side of spinach. The shrimp were tasty, and from the gulf, no Thailand shrimp here! The greens were fine, but nothing spectacular...oh, and they also forgot to top with crispy shallots, which was a let down. Anyways, great place for dinner, and the open kitchen with bar seating is a nice touch. Bon apetit!
author: David M.

description: I've been here several times and I can say that I love the ambiance and food.  Its modern Vietnamese and I've never been disappointed with the food/service.  I love sitting at the bar getting a glass of wine and a few appetizers while catching up with a friend.  The decor is very much my style.  Minimalist and modern.  I gave it a 4/5 because the prices are on the high side for Vietnamese and its not the BEST I've had.  But-- overall-- a good staple to go to.
author: Sun M.

description: Thank you otd..i love the food and wine and people there. Props to all..esp david, johnny, val, grace..love it
author: sadao n.

description:
We had a wonderful lunch at Out the Door on Bush Street.  Three spiced chicken on noodles was delicious. My friend had another noodle dish that was equally good.  The wait staff was really nice and attentive.  It was lunch and the only negative I have to say is that it was a little too noisy.  Otherwise, great neighborhood restaurant.  
JG
author: Jackie G.

description: I have had diner here twice. Each time the food and the service was fabulous, from the manager, server and bus staff. The chef's ability to fuse the mundane of Asian standard faire and boost it over the top is truly artistic. The currently featured Ming bean sesame balls with caramelized  passion fruit syrup were SO good, I subjected my better half to deal with me licking the dish clean. :) YUM
author: MJ A.

description: Great neighborhood spot. Nice clay pots and spring rolls.
author: Joshua S.

description:
Out The Door is the popular offshoot of San Francisco's renown restaurant, Slanted Door. Their original to-go style cafés located in the ferry building and Westfield shopping plaza offer excellent gluten free friendly Vietnamese noodle dishes, spring rolls, and rice bowls that boast organic, local ingredients. With Out The Door's somewhat newly opened restaurant location, you can find inspired variations on those tasty takeout dishes in a more elegant setting. For the gluten free crowd, their wait staff is knowledgeable about which dishes are safe (at the ferry building location they have a list of menu items that contain common allergens). Our waiter directed us to the beef pho and five spice chicken dish, served with thin rice noodles (had to be modified to be gf by omitting a soy sauce marinade). Both meals were exceptionally flavorful, in part because of their seasonal, fresh ingredients. For any trained gluten intolerant eater, you know that finding great Vietnamese food can sometimes be a challenge due to the common use of commercial soy sauce and hoisin sauce (both contain wheat). With restaurants like Out The Door, gluten free folk  aren't left with a plate of plain rice and steamed vegetables. Instead, we can share in the fun of slurping down a bowl of spicy noodles with all of the traditional flavors intact.

For photos and more gluten free friendly restaurants in San Francisco: www.GFinSF.com
author: lauren v.

description: Saw this place on the Food Channel.  Love good Chinese porridge(jook).  Still looking for good jook.  Did not find it here.  Had steamed BBQ pork buns.  Blah.  Had chicken porridge. Blah.  Had Banh Mi ( Vietnamese sandwich). Blah.  No taste but plenty of bucks!  $12 for a small sandwich.  Bottled water, $8!  Iced tea $3.50, Very aloof service. Visually very nice space. Awful parking due to extensive street construction.  I would hit up Saigon Sandwich.  Won't be returning.
author: Diane D.

description:
went here for dinner on a wednesday with a good friend to catch up. got there around 6:30ish. walked over from her house.  as we're walking down Bush St, the store before this place had gone away.  and of course, the two blondes stop and say, "oh no. did the place close? now what?'  and at the same time, the hostess from OTD was behind us and said, "no, we're still open. just one more down."  

yeah, we're smart.  good thing the hostess was cool and didn't hold it against us. we did tip big ;)  plus i was dying for great vietnamese food. 

anyhow, we sat at the bar and had some amazing food.  place is trendy, delicious and fun.  Did get a bit loud around 7-8p - we sat right by the big table in front that was occupied by a bday.   

Had the crispy imperial rolls with the lettuce, mint etc.  perfect. 

next, the ni man ranch (said with accent) short ribs. fall-off-the-bone delicious. craving those right now.

then split the crab & noodles: dungeness crab, cellophane noodles, green onion, sesame oil - and the shaking beef (AMAZING and lots for what you get - eat piece cuts to about 3-4 bites)  grass-fed estancia farms shaking beef, cubed filet mignon, watercress, red onions and the SAUCE was delish.

would definitely go back again. want to check out the other locations as well. GO. get it.
author: Mike B.

description: This place is very yummy! The food seems very healthy, and there is a great wine selection. Both times I went I was seated promptly and attended to often, but not too often... There are plenty of interesting dishes to try and I will probably be back. The prices and service are great too!
author: Nora S.

description: Out the door is great for a family dinner or date.  The food is flavorful and deslicious in a fun modern setting.  Unlike most trendy settings you can actually hear your own conversations and don't have to yell, but the atmosphere is still very lively.  Both brunch and dinner are awesome here.  I love their Pho and thier spare ribs are to die for.  The papaya salad and the shrimp rolls are awesome also.  It can be hard to walk in but they have a great commual table for walks ins, but it is advisable to make a reservation.
author: Julia B.

description:
CHILLING EXPERIENCE

I made a reservation on open table, while driving down the Fillmore with my girlfriend we joked about how cold it would be to sit outside and eat dinner observing others brave the elements, little did we know what was ahead of us. We arrived and were told we could sit at a counter, looked very unappealing, agreed with the hostess we could go for a walk and come back in 10 minutes as there was nowhere to wait. 

Returned and were seated at a lovely table, liked the marble top, my girlfriend is 5'2 and sat on the aluminum bench, her feet could not reach the floor, she was cold so we swapped, I sat there we never removed our coats it was so cold the ac was gusting out at our table, I got a fleece from car to use as a pad, our server was attentive and told us she was too cold too. 

We had the imperial rolls and mushroom rice cakes for appetizers, followed by the beef bavette and eggplant, the beef was a small portion (7 pieces), we both had the chocolate to appease our poor disposition. Coffee was average; table wear is not in sync looks like they bought it at a close out sale of catering supplier. I Spoke to the manager and gave her feedback, she did not apologize, just spoke of difficulties, no allowance made on the bill for our poor experience, this is just poor etiquette.

So much is wrong with this place, it could be great, its a shame, we both eat in the other 2 restaurants regularly. I believe the leadership needs to step up and make swift changes or this very serious neighbor hood will punish OTD.
author: Michael D.

description: We finally made it in here for brunch yesterday and it was awesome, I can't wait to come back! Beautiful decor, awesome food, reasonably priced, I'm a fan! We split the shredded chicken salad which was very tasty and refreshing and the chicken porridge which was amazing. That porridge is something I will crave. So flavorful. And split into 2 bowls it was HUGE portions still. Spend $10 each. Can't wait to try the steamed pork buns, the beignets, the papaya salad, the pho, the slow cooked eggs, and the bacon.
