Would be great hangover food, the porridge is total comfort food, we were in a food coma afterwords. Very different from the Out the Door experience at the mall or at the Ferry Building, this is a beautiful restaurant. We walked in with no wait midday on a Saturday and got to sit at the chef's counter and watch all the action. Recommended!
author: Sarah R.

description: Don't bother going out of your door for this one. Very disappointing since we like Slanted Door and the Ferry Building OTD so much. Prices like SD but not the selection, very noisy and very expensive. The baby bok choy seemed somewhat elderly and the shitakes that went with it were the size of a dime and there 2-3 in the entire dish. So little crab in the glass noodle dish that it was hardly worth calling it a crab dish. Definitely not on my list for the future.
author: Meridithe M.

description: The food was really good, I'll give it that.  I went there with my friend and our two young sons for lunch one afternoon.  We had a fresh spring roll and both of us ordered soups.  We were there for over an hour before we got our soup!  Seriously?!?!  It wasn't like it was super busy or anything.  We actually had to ask for the soup to be packaged up to go, because I'm sorry, even with an iphone at his disposal, my kid can't sit still for over an hour.  Oh, and as we were leaving, we saw that there were crayons and paper for kids behind the hostess stand-  it would have been nice to have those while we were waiting for our food!  Hopefully it was just our server, and this is not the norm...
author: Jenny R.

description: I go to the Westfield restaurant frequently even though this OTD is only 2 blocks from my apartment. The reason is that the Mall restaurant has the MOST amazing lemongrass chicken with hot peppers that is my fave dish off all time. Anyway, 2 weeks ago, I took the plunge and went to OTD Bush. I asked the manager Valerie, if it was possible to have the same dish made here? She said not currently, but that she would write me when it was on the menu and they could make it specially for me. True to her word, a week later I got an email from her and she said they could make it next time I came in if I gave her a heads up. I did, and they did, and it was just as good as the dish they serve in the downtown mall.  I would give this place 5 stars overall (and definitely do for Valerie's customer service) but the only reason Im not is that the dish isnt on the menu all the time!
author: Brit C.

description: I was told i had to try the Cellophane lobster noodles. It was okay. My husband had the lamb, it was okay too. My waitress suggested i order a black tea, that was terrible. We had the scallops, there were 4 pieces. i dont know what all the hype is all about, but this place was super crowded.
author: Kimmy C.

description: Its a shame that my father visiting from out of town specifically requested to eat here, and we were denied a table. Granted, we did not have reservations, but the lack of interest, and rationalization from the hostess oozed "non-accomodating attitude". My father had fond memories of when the Westfield location just opened, and I thought it would be nice to take him to this location. I had eaten here before when this location first opened and was even kindly greeted by Mr Phan himself. Restaurant staff should remember that food is only part of the experience. Its a shame that the front of the house so poorly reflected the spirit of this restaurant, "good food in a relaxed atmosphere".
author: Michael M.

description: To those who had a chilly greeting...you are in good company. We arrived at about 1pm on a Saturday - place 3/4 empty - no host/hostess - so we approached the first staffer we saw...he couldn't be bothered -- rudely ordered us back to the hostess stand where we could "wait until he checked all his reservations" to see if he could fit us in. Give me an effing break! This is a hospitality business, no? Food was mostly good. Don't think it's worth coming back to, though. There are friendlier places with better value-to-food.
author: P W.

description: Terrific decor, service, and food, but I give it 3 stars because this isn't your typical Vietnamese value meal - the food is absolutely delicious in my opinion, just expensive.
author: Chihee K.

description: Went to brunch on Sunday with two of my friends and there was one waiter to serve the whole restaurant. The wait to take our drink order took almost 20 minutes, then an additional 15 minutes to bring our mimosas and coffee. All of the mimosas were completely flat, as though the bottle had been sitting open. We asked to get replacement glasses, but that process took an additional 15 minutes - and they were still flat. We also didn't receive any sugar or sweetener for the coffee. Our food took a very long time to arrive, and my friend who ordered pho didn't get her garnish plate for almost 10 minutes after we were served. The chicken porridge was also not very hot. It was clear that some of these problems would have been fixed with additional staff - but I will not be going back. Those mimosas were awful, and they are a very simple drink to make.
author: Hilary J.

description:
This was my first visit to the Bush Street location.  I started with the coconut carmel roll, which was hot and yummy!  I had the ham and eggs with baguette, which was very well seasoned and tasty.  I had the Vietnamese iced coffee which had a strong and fresh taste.  I highly recommend this location and I cannot wait to go back.

Bernie
author: Bernie B.

description: Came here with a group for dinner so we shared everything, about 8-10 dishes.  The portions are small.  Everything tasted fine, like all the rolls were standard, the meat dishes were tiny, and nothing stood out as that special or memorable.  I don't think I would return here.  The ambiance is nice, energetic and the service was prompt.  I paid a lot for not really getting much food.
author: Kari L.

description: Had dinner with my wife here while on vacation.  My pork chop was awesome and she had the noodles with crab....also very good.  Appetizer was a split of their spring rolls, highly recommend!  Beer was cheap at $5 for a 22oz bottle.  I would go back, just felt the menu need a few more options.
author: Alex A.

description: Great stop during a shopping excursion downtown SF!
author: Dorothy M.

description: I've been considering going vegetarian, but it is hard when there are pork ribs as good as I had at Out The Door last Saturday.  Direct quote from me: "These are the best ribs I have ever had."  My fiancée loves this place too, but for its many gluten-free options; she got some kind of rice noodle plate...  The egg roll things with lettuce wraps was a yummy start, the broccoli plate was great, and my veggie friend got fried tofu that hit the spot too.  Way good...
author: James E.

description:
Ok-ish....really small portions, rocky service.

Stopped by for dinner at the counter.  Took 15 minutes for anyone to take my order ( crab with cellophane noodles ($16)).  I think there was a busboy screw-up, as the  guy next to me at the counter came in 10 minutes after me, and got a salad AND a crab with cellophane noodles before I got my noodlels.  The waitress comped my glass of wine (unasked).  

The noodles with crab itself was very good, though a teensy potion for $16.  No veggies, no extras---just $16 for a salad sized plate of noodles with bits of crab.

I am hungry as I type this review.  Definitely a place for a starter AND a main.
author: Edie H.

description: Had lunch here yesterday.  Service was friendly and relatively attentive.  I started w/the coconut caramel brioche and am still savoring the experience.  Then had chicken pho, which was quite good and reminded me of pho I had in Vietnam.  Well, the flavor did.  Price and setting didn't. ;)
author: Kevin M.

description:
I went to The Slanted Door for my birthday last year, and had some of the most wonderful drinks and food I can remember.  So, when some friends came into town from back east, I thought I would take them to OTD since I knew the food would be good, but maybe a little less expensive.  I also fully expected the menu to be less extensive, so I didn't have crazy expectations to begin with. I just wanted reliably good food and service. 

Our reservation for 4 people was for 9:00, but we didn't get seated until 10:00.  In the meantime, our server was very polite and apologetic and comped us some spring rolls.  Great, we said, thanks!  Waiting was not a big deal particularly because we were all drinking and having a good time.  However, we didn't get seated until 10:00 and our food didn't arrive until 10:45 at which point my husband and I realized that our fish clay pot dinner was exactly that--two chunks of fish in a pot.  No veggies, no rice, nothing.  Sooooo, we politely asked for rice and were informed that the entire restaurant was out of rice!  An Asian restaurant who runs out of rice?  Really?  We were nice, and they were trying to be nice (though you could tell that by this time they were ready to close as it got freezing cold in there and some of the staff in the back started moving boxes around.) so they brought us a small bowl of glass noodles.  It was a weird combination--fish and glass noodles.  I think it's really important to be upfront about the fact that you must order sides separately here, least you end up with a piece of fish for a meal.  Just tell me, and I would have ordered more. It's not a big deal. 

Anyway, so we left hungry and I returned home to eat a bowl of cereal.   

I'm really hoping that OTD is only experiencing temporary discombobulation due to being new in the area.  But as Anthony Bourdain always says not to be greedy.  If you have one great restaurant, leave it at that. Why open three more mediocre ones?  

This experience was wicked blah, if you know what I mean.  My east coasters were not impressed, which makes me sad, because there's got to be some reason why we pay $1800 a month for a one-bedroom apartment. Guess it's not OTD.
author: Melissa M.

description: After our 4th or 5th time here having a perfect dinner, I realized a Yelp review is long overdue.  The food here has been perfectly executed every time.  We've had the same dishes like the shaking beef at Slanted Door and the old Out the Door at the Westfield--for some reason the same food is much better executed here.  Their fish offerings change periodically but are always good.  Today it was halibut with a lemongrass sauce that had almost a pesto quality--delicious.  I have never, despite trying many many places, ever had a fresh roll as perfect as the ones here.  The rice paper skin is perfectly soft.  Often places don't soak them enough or let the rolls sit around so the skin gets a little hard/chewy.  Many places overstuff them so you lose the flavors of the individual ingredients inside (often the shrimp gets lost).  These are the right size with the right proportion of ingredients, and the peanut sauce takes these over the top.  We love the crispy imperial rolls.  Their shanghai soup dumplings are surprisingly good given this is not a Vietnamese dish.  They always change-up the vegetables but they are always good--tonight baby bok choy with slivers of fresh shiitake mushrooms.  Often at Asian places the desserts are not amazing.  But the desserts here are off the hook.  The mini berry pies and ice cream sandwiches were way beyond what you would expect.  Instead of the usual dark cookie you'd expect on an ice cream sandwich, they used freshly baked sugar cookies of some sort that were just bursting with flavor.  And the ice cream inside was impressive in taste and texture.  I don't even like dessert but really enjoyed these.  I love that the food here is not heavy--no cream, minimal oil, just clean fresh flavors.  Of course, a meal here can definitely add-up, but I really feel given the beautiful atmosphere, the fantastic service, and the quality of the food, that the price tag is well worth it.  This has become one of our go-to restaurants for a really delicious weekend meal in beautiful yet not pretentious surroundings.
author: Mae O.

description: This neighborhood was really in need of this place.  The attention to food quality is up to par with that of Slanted Door.  Albeit, this is a more casual menu as far as menu items go.  The jook is pretty tasty and comes with the fried bread.  I still need to go back to actually sample everything else, but I will for sure come back to eat other things.  The pricing is very reasonable for the area, and you can easily drop in on your own as they have good bar and communal seating.  The only thing I'm not sure I like about the place, is that it's kind of nice inside.  Therefore, I might feel out of place showing up in my sweats after a run.
author: Simon Y.

description: Underwhelming food.  Tastes OK but nothing special.  The overcooked rice is unforgivable for a Vietnamese restaurant.  Nicely decorated space but hard surfaces make the place too loud.  The place is more about attitude than about food.  Charles Phan may be overstretched at this point with so many outlets.
author: Andrew C.

description: Overrated...Westernized Vietnamese food.  Papaya salad needed more flavor.  Also ordered eggplant, roasted chilies, fish sauce, coconut milk dish.  It came undercooked, and the flavor was not what I expected.  Tasted like Chinese stir-fried eggplant.  Didn't taste any fish sauce or coconut milk.
author: N A.

description: Stopped in for a bite on a Friday night a few months ago.  We sat at the bar and ordered the mung bean dumplings (texturally, a little odd, but then I started liking it), the pork meatballs (decent, but not amazing), the crab vermicelli (which does not compare to the crab and cellophane noodles at Slanted Door, but same idea, just not as good), a steamed clam special (which was delish!) and the lemongrass tofu (which was not as good as I would have hoped).  The original is still the best, in my opinion, but OTD is a good spot to grab a bite.
author: Mitzi C.

description: Sometimes I just want a bowl of steaming savory noodles for breakfast, and this was one of those days! I just loved the ambiance and decor at this location of OTD. It was pretty casual and relaxing on a Sunday morning. The menu is divided between east and west dining options. Vietamese pho and green tea v. beignets and hot coffee. We opted for the chicken and beef pho and started w/ the daikon cakes (we were starved)! Everything hit the spot. I also enjoyed the HK milk tea. Yum! Like other reviews said this spot is still new-ish and working out some kinks (but they didn't detract much). The metal bench that runs along all the tables is freezing as they are awaiting the cushions for it -- make your warmer blooded dining companion sits there. Can't wait to visit OTD again soon!
author: Jessica H.

description: This is my favorite place to eat right now. The quality, the tastes, the staff, are amazing. I live in Oakland and I drive here anytime I'm in SF.
author: Megan F.

description: Never been to Slanted Door but walked into Out the Door and had an amazing experience sitting at the chef's counter. The manager was incredibly friendly and gave us a free dessert!! The food is obviously amazing there too.
author: Christine T.

description: Out the Door is my favorite restaurant to eat at in SF. I have tried a lot here but over time I've found that I love the shaking beef so much, I now order it every time I come. My family loves the claypot chicken and any of the veggies and rolls. The service is great, and they really pay attention to you to make sure everyone's happy and doesn't need anything else. I once had the beef come out too rare, and they happily sent it back to the kitchen and took it off of our bill because of how much we come there and how much else we had ordered. Great food, customer service, and atmosphere!
author: Emily P.

description: Came here a couple of times after I figured out the place really existed. The steak and eggs are great. There's something about the interior that makes me feel like I'm eating somewhere before or after hours, though.
author: ryan c.

description: Great food, but the visually sleek interior design (open kitchen, all hard surfaces) gives visitors a horribly noisy experience, even when the place is half full.  As my teenage niece put it, "This place is just stupid loud." Take out, yes; eat in, never again.
author: tw s.

description:
Great modern look, replete with galvanized bar stools, walnut armed eames-like chairs in orange and black upholstery, requisite pinpoint track lighting, custom sized raw steel benches and the wall tacked with what looks like an unfinished hardwood flooring.
The food is tasty.  The iced coffee is neither as strong or as sweet as the kind of cafe sua that's served at other Vietnamese cafes.  The beignets were basically Chinese donuts with powdered sugar strewn atop them, no dipping sauce or filling are to be found.  Unfortunately, I tainted my chicken pho broth with Sriracha sauce before actually sampling it.  I can at least tell you it smelled good.  The porridge was a delightful consistency, the rau rum (akin to cilantro) brings a much needed zing to the mix.  Both bowls, $8 and $7 respectively use the same super white strips of succulent chicken.
The portion size is  Asian.  Can you say "under-size me"?  It's good for people looking to eat six small meals a day.
author: Sam N.

description: I really wanted to like this place.  Had wait a long time to have something like it closer to me.   Nothing special at all.  The flavors are just nothing special and I was disappointed about the quality.  The chicken was just not fresh.  You are still on time to work things out, do not wait to much.  Do not think I will be back.
author: Emi C.

description: amazing food. 5 star food. 4 star prices. Super loud and crowded. Also not fancy, it has kind of a mid scale feel so think people are surprised by the prices. You will pay $40/pp for sure.
author: Ryan P.

description:
went for dinner-- left feeling ripped

where was the f**in crab in the noodles?

slanted door rock though
author: Ross R.

description: Vibe was exciting. But food was just ok for me. I don't get the $29 for the shaking beef entree. My sister in law told me that I had to try this dish. Thought the menu was pricey for the food.
author: Isabella L.

description: First time going and wanted something light,healthy and fast to eat. I ordered the Spring Rolls to go. All the ingredients in the roll was fresh and good. Was a meal for me. Noticed therestaurant was busy and loud.  The hostess and staff that helped me ordered my meal was attentive. I would go back to try other items on the menu.
author: Gwen P.

description: Food was out of site (great).  Loud but so worth it.  I will absolutely go back.
author: Ray S.

description: Solid food, nice atmophere, decent but not great service.
author: Pablo M.

description: I eat here several time a week.  The service is quite good and the food is delicious.  And really underrated is their breakfast.  It's such a good way to start the work day.
author: A A.

description: I have always wanted to go to Slanted Door.  Colonial cuisine (French fusions, British fusions etc) is my favorite.  So when the more affordable OTD opened, I rallied my friends together to go get a meal.  When I entered, I was surprised at the layout and ambiance.  I am very particular about lighting (partially because of sensitive eyes, partially because I am aesthetically focused) and the lighting was too bright.  It felt like I was in a food court, very echo-y, loud and a bit crammed.  I ended up leaving without eating there because for 20 dollars a plate (food looked great, but small portions) I need my sexy lighting.  Call me crazy, but going out to dinner is not about only the food, but the experience.  I would not go on a date here, or rather a first date.
author: sophia s.

description: excellent food. service a little on slow side, but no biggie. tasty dishes, vibrant hip atmosphere. i'm a fan
author: Venktesh R.

description: Our first time there. Food was yummy (crab with cellophane noodles: kinda like Korean JapChae in my opinion) and claypot chicken (TO DIE FOR!) topped off with a Kabocha cake, which was a little dry but a great combination with the caramelized pineapple and green tea cheesecake topping, I'm guessing? Service was fine: a little slow getting the dessert menu but our waitress was nice and jumped on it and got our dessert out fast when i told her my meter was about to expire. Water refills were spot on...GREAT! My mom and i had a very nice lunch experience and we would definitely go back, this time for dinner.
author: Chris C.

description:
Out the Door Bush or OTD Bush is the name of this restaurant.
Great restaurant, chef de cuisine is the lovely talented Grace Nguyen.
Love the beignets!! The chicken soup is good too.
Did not try dinner yet, have to go one of these days...
But anything prepared by Grace Nguyen should be excellent! No, I am not related to her, just a fan...tasted her cookies at American Box and I was hooked since then....!
author: lovetoeat a.

description:
Had a great experience at OTD and really enjoyed the food.  The service was great and the staff was friendly.  We (group of 5) had a combination of breakfast and lunch foods and everything was delicious.  Johnny (the manager?) was great.

This OTD is soooooo much better than the one in Westfield Mall.
author: Garrett H.

description: Second visit - really pretty good place, especially if you don't need to wait.  Clean, good ambiance.  Strong beer and wine lists.  First time we had the shaking beef (like a Thai Beef salad made with filet  mignon) - really delicious, but you need a major craving for beef since it is substantial.  Last night, had the aspargus and crab soup - very good, imperial rools, and the carmerlized prawns.  Prawns came out pretty close to raw (which is fine for many things, but I don't know about raw prawns).  They graciuosly took them back and they were pretty good.  The jist of the place is high end vietnamese in a good atmosphere.  Food is made with good quality ingredients and creative, but it has a somewhat PF Chang feel with the flavorings.  It is pretty noisy.  I would keep it on the consideration list
author: Glenn S.

description:
salty salty salty.

the other out the door I ate at also?

salty salty salty. 

food in Vietnam and food (in general) stateside is NOT this salty.

WTF is up with the chief's lack of palette sensitivity - who can handle this much sodium on their staff everyday?
author: Haoming C.

description: We ordered 1 appetizer and 3 main dishes for 3 people.  They completely forgot about 1 of the 3 main dishes (which is a problem when you're eating with 3 people).  After waiting over an hour for the last dish and telling 2 waiters and our MIA waitress, we politely informed the maitre d'.  We finally finish with coffee/beignets, quickly pay the bill and we're gathering our things to leave.  The maitre d' obviously misses this cue and has the audacity to tell us (not ask) she'll have to move us to another area because there's another reservation waiting for our table.  Seriously?!  We waited for more than an hour for 1 dish of pork/egg/rice.  The maitre d', 1 waitress and 1 waiter need restaurant service lessons.  BTW, the restaurant was not overly busy or crowded at 11am or at 12pm.  A table sat vacant on either side of us for much of our experience.  My suggestion and next experience will be to get the food for take out or eat at the bar.
author: toloveisto b.

description: All is forgiven. The Chicken Pho is like a drug, it's so addicting. The service (we always sit at the bar) is great--friendly and attentive. We come here pretty much every weekend. And you really can't miss with anything on the dinner menu.
author: Eric H.

description: Yum!  Loved the sticky black rice with coconut and avocado and the vegetarian summer rolls.  The vermicelli noodle dishes were delicious.  Also enjoyed the chicken porridge.  And the jasmine silver needle tea was amazing.  There was nothing we ordered that wasn't good.  I found the staff to be friendly and attentive.
author: Emily F.

description: I've been here twice and the service and food is exceptional.  I will go back many times.  The atmosphere is much nicer than the location at the Ferry Building.  I will order the vege spring rolls again...and can't go wrong with the fresh fish specials.
author: Mark N.

description: Yum! I was so sad when Slanted Door move to its current huge space in the Ferry Building but Out the Door is even better than Slanted Door was when it was still in the Mission. Great food and great service without massive crowds of tourists. The rolls, soups and salads are my favorites but I haven't had a thing I didn't like!
author: Elizabeth K.

description: We decided to check out breakfast at the Bush St location and were happy that we did. The wait staff was very friendly, super accommodating and made great recommendations. Within our group there were orders for the melted leek quiche, the pancakes and the fried eggs. We all loved our selections. I'm not a coffee drinker, but the people in our group who were, said the coffee was outstanding. The yunnan black tea that I ordered was perfect. Portions are a bit small for the price, (I ordered the quiche) which is why I only gave OTD four stars. Definitely going back.
author: Cheryl K.

description:
One word:  HORRIBLE! I won't even walk by that place again.  We have never been treated so badly and disrespectfully anywhere in the world! 
We walked out of the restaurant literally shaking in disbelief! The restaurant manager, or whatever he is there, approached our table yelling and screaming because we have poured our own wine from a bottle we brought into the restaurant.   
We had explained to our waiter we wanted to taste two different wines we are considering for our wedding reception so she kindly brought two set of glasses for each one of us at the table.  After we poured one of the wines, this guy came over with a horrifying tone to tell us we could not do that.   We had to take the bottles out of the restaurant.  We tried to explain the situation, no harm intended, and he continued yelling we couldn't do that, he could loose his liquor license, and he even said my fiancé was extremely intoxicated! OMG, just because he has an accent, he was accused of being drunk!  
Horrifying experience, unbelievable.  
We couldn't even say a word, simply got up and left.  I feel horrible for the people working at this place!
author: Diana C.

description: This place is a good choice for big groups, family outings etc. Not a great date spot because it's a little loud and you are only getting a half genuine experience if you can't try a number of their dishes. It's a little pricy for the quality of food but some dishes are dead on. Wait staff is friendly and attentive but despite the great decor and location it had a bit of a mass service feel. A+ Vietnamese coffee. THERE IS NO BUSH ST LOCATION SO DON"T TRY TO GO THERE.
author: M L.

description:
Just got back from lunch at Out the Door and felt that I needed to write a review.
I had a reservation for 12:30 but when I arrived the hostess said there was not a reservation under that name. Immediately, he said it was not problem and worked around the situation. Even though it probably was my fault (could have called the wrong out the door) he could not have been nicer. Our waitress was also very attentive and nice. She was helpful and pointed out her favorite items on the menu. All of the food came in a timely manner too. 

Overall the food was delicious. Everything on the menu looked fantastic. We got the spring rolls (so good and fresh), the crepe also very good, the rice cake, and the chicken pot. (I know a lot of food but we just couldn't decide it all looked so good!). 
In the end, the service was great, the food was delicious and the space is beautiful. Great spot for lunch and can't wait to go back
author: Abigail W.

description:
Since I live in the neighborhood, I've been waiting for this place for a while now (they started construction, and then stop to focus on their place at the California Academy of Sciences).  

Note: Since I cannot give a 1/2 star, I am going to give this place 4 stars.  Not that I don't like this place, but I have only gone there for brunch so far, and I don't think their menu really shines for brunch; I have to say that my brunch experience is really 3.5 stars.

I would say that this place is an excellent addition to the neighborhood.  Went there for brunch, it had a very varied menu for brunch (a couple of egg dishes, beef or chicken pho, chicken rice porridge, etc).  We started with iced coffee and beignets, along with some coconut bread.  The ice coffee was typical for a vietnamese coffee (dark coffee with sweeten condense milk).  The beignets and coconut breads were really good; the beignets were rich and the coconut bread was kind of sweet.  I had the chicken porridge; while it was good, the spices in it was a little different from the typical chinese porridge that I grew up on (can't really say what the difference is), so I have to say that it is not my favorite.  One of my friend had the baked egg dish, it was OK, but then I am not a big fan tomato sauce on my eggs.  Someone else had the poach eggs (I think on top of pork), which I thought was better.  But honestly, if you come here, maybe you should focus on the Asian dishes.

Service was good, but I think they are still working it out: they gave us the wrong menus when we sat down, and we had to ask for the sugar and a spoon when someone got a cappuccino.  

One of the other reviewers disagree that the prices were affordable.  I think the prices are affordable for the neighborhood; sorry, you are not going to get bargain pho in Pacific Heights.  Yes, you can get good vietnamese food elsewhere in the city, but if you are not willing to track down to the Tenderloin (or Richmond or Sunset), then you should be willing to pay a couple of dollars more.
author: Steve Y.

description:
Was in town for a week during a work trip and made it to all three OTD's.  Love Vietnamese food and was pleasantly surprised to see it in such a modern setting.

Over the three visits, I managed to sample the Salad Roll, Grapefruit Jicama Salad, Papaya Salad, Beef Pho, Roast Pork Baguette, Claypot Chicken, and Lemongrass Chicken.  Umm, that wasn't all on my own by the way.  Note that the menus are different at each place, and that pho isn't necessarily on the dinner menu it seems like.

The first four were very good, with the mint coming through in the roll, and rau ram herb coming through in the Grapefruit Salad to make them distinctively more complex than regular Vietnamese food.  There was almost too many of them, but the candied pecans on the Grapefruit Salad were almost addictive.  Baguette had more pork than any sub I've ever seen, bordering on obscene almost, but was very tasty.  Pho was above average, but not mind-blowing.  I prefer the firmer dried noodles and I think these were the softer fresh variety or else they had been overcooked a bit.

Claypot and Lemongrass Chicken were not so spectacular though.  For the price of these two mid-range dishes and the caliber of the place, one expects something more than the usual I think.  While the Claypot was merely pedestrian, I found the Lemongrass Chicken to be devoid of any lemongrass flavour at all.  DIning partner agreed too and we thought it tasted more like Kung Pao Chicken, with all the chilis dominating the flavour.  Sold as Kung Pao, it might have been a 4 star dish, but sold as Lemongrass Chicken, I'd give it a 2.

BTW, the manager comp'ed me a side of bok choy when he saw me eating the Claypot Chicken without any rice (small effort at going low-carb), probably thinking that I was going to die from the salty sweetness.  Small touch, but to notice that detail when the room was pretty full and happening is what gets OTD a fourth star from me.  Also heard him tell one of the servers where some food critics had just been seated, and reminding him to make sure they had a good experience, so this guy was pretty on the ball.

So all in all, a four star experience slightly blemished by a couple of lower ranked dishes.  Wish they had a location in my town though.  Next trip, I'll start checking out the seafood section and some of that Niman Ranch Beef.
author: Howard J.

description:
I can't believe this place only has three stars!

The food here is DELICIOUS. Everything I've had has been good. The cellophane noodles and crab is amazing, as is the sort of honey chicken that comes in a clay bowl, I can't remember what it's called... We usually get a few things and share so we can enjoy a variety of tastiness. The rice is just right as far as texture and flavor and the veggies are made very well too, we had the spinach and kale sides. YUM! The service didn't stick out as being extraordinary but was perfectly adequate, we didn't have any problems - we were busy in conversation so probably didn't pay as much attention to the service as usual - oh, but they were very attentive about refilling our green tea with water when we told them at the beginning we would just keep re-steeping the pot. The silver needle green tea is delicious and is still great after a couple re-brews.
author: Therese H.

description:
we had the silver noodles with crab, which was good
chicken in a clay pot reminded was ok
fried chicken was as expected
author: eric w.

description: Delish.  Polite, attentive service with good menu knowledge.  A perfect place for a mid-shopping snack break!
author: Don N.

description:
My first impression when walking in is that it was a bit noisy and smokey in the restaurant.

We had a 7p reservation and were seated by 7:20p or so.  

We had the cellophane noodles which had a great flavor but I would have liked a little more crab.  

We had the bok choy which I enjoyed.

We also had the duck which was good.  

The servers and GM are super nice and they comped our thai basil ice cream which was nice.

We had two glasses of reisling which were great.

The total was $87 which was a bit high for a more "casual" Slanted Door experience.
author: Brian L.

description: If only it were a little less noisy, it would be ideal.  Great food, tho chefs are inconsistent with the way they cook dishes at times.
author: deb u.

description:
I was shocked when I came to review this restaurant and saw how low some of its rating were. I went for lunch here last Friday. I sat at the bar and had a wonderful time. The bartender was extremely helpful and she let me taste a couple of wines before I found something I really liked (I ended up going with the $4 wine on tap--Sauvignon blanc I think? Per her suggestion, and it was delicious!). 

The restaurant was packed when I arrived, but everything seemed to run smoothly. I ordered the spring rolls to start (it was between the rolls and the papaya salad--such a hard decision to make!) and I also ordered some dikon rice cakes. Then I ordered the Char for my entree. 

I've had the spring rolls at Slanted Door before and I absolutely love them there and I must say they are fantastic here too! The sauce on the dikon was super tasty (I almost asked for another order). The char was cooked perfectly and I really liked the greens that came with it. I didn't have any room for dessert, but I ended my meal with a hot Vietnamese coffee and a coconut bun. The staff was extremely attentive and friendly and I didn't feel rushed at all.

The only downside was the acoustics. It was so loud! I feel if I came here with other people we'd have to yell just so we could hear one another. And it was a bit chilly too (not sure if it was the air-conditioning?)

I am greatly looking forward to coming back for dinner and breakfast. I also hope I have enough room to have some dessert next time!
author: Angel D.

description: I thought it was pretty good.  Although I am a big eater and the food didn't have as much food as I would have liked.  The best part was the wine ON TAP!  I had a great glass of wine for only $4 bucks!!!  I had the crab with noodles was great!  Not enough crab though, but still great tasting.  Our service was good, everything came on time and no screw ups.  Although we did go at 9:15 on a Tuesday night.
author: Jason W.

description:
I think great restaurants get reviewed much harsher than average restaurants. If you think of the restaurants in the Pac Hts neighborhood and you think of "good/great" ones the top ones I think of are: SPQR, Dosa, Florio, Fresca, Delfina, and now Out The Door. It is definitely a great restaurant to add to the neighborhood. And as the little sister to The Slanted Door you get yummy food for a reasonable price (not cheap, but good "bang for your buck" if you will).

Ambiance is very important to me, as an architect. I love the vibe and I love the communal tall table at the front . I sat at the marble bar when my friend and I met there for dinner within the first 2 wks of it's opening; which is a fun experience.

I was surprised and impressed by the size of the summer rolls (thinking that as an appetizer they would be skimpy); but even sharing those I was full and we hadn't even received our entree yet! We ordered the crab noodles (a specialty that is also served at The Slanted Door). And they were simple but delicious. We also ordered the chard, which was another simple but yummy flavor really showcasing the vegetable.

The bar tender was very helpful in helping each of us get the glass of wine that we were looking for and gave EACH of us several samples of other wines before we each selected a glass.

Will I go back? Definitely. Have I recommended it? To several people. 

I am glad to have them in the neighborhood and hope more people go show their support so we can KEEP them in the neighborhood!
author: Lily M.

description: I've heard about this restaurant and when it opened in my neighborhood I was so excited, it's really good!
author: trish p.

description: went there for lunch.   i ordered their pork & wonton noodle soup.  my friend ordered the beef pho soup.   they are both very salty.   seriously, the pork & wonton noodle soup should not be hard to make.   the wontons don't even look decent.  the service was good -  our waitress was friendly and responsive.   i wouldn't be back.   hopefully the 'parent' co, the slanted door, has better food.
author: Kelly M.

description: Love the green papaya salad and the asparagus crab soup, so delicious! Great environment, I love when restaurants have open kitchens.
author: Jeanette B.

description:
awful.  
we had high hopes bc a) i love pho and b) i like the Out the Door westfield location, so we decided to try it this weekend.  It was a saturday afternoon, practically no one was there, and we still watched our pho sit there for like 5 minutes before our server brought it to the table!  Eating lukewarm pho is not very fun.  

Also, my fiance ordered the beef pho, and raw beef was on top.  our server said "the beef is supposed to cook in the broth" but since the broth was not piping hot the beef was pretty gross. we told the server that the broth wasn't that hot anymore, and she said "well it looks hot enough."  

then our server took the pho away while we were still working on it, and took the beer away while there was still beer in the bottle!  talk about annoying. 

the pho itself wasn't that great either.  no vegatables and very oily broth.  they also skimp on the siracha and plum sauce.  instead of putting a bottle of siracha sauce and a bottle of plum sauce at every table, they only have one bottle at the counter, and you have to wait for the server to put it in a tiny dish and bring it over to you.  and then you probably have to ask for more and it will take them like 10 minutes to bring you another little tiny dish of sauce.  they also brought out a tiny dish of the fixings that go with the pho (eg bean sprouts, cilantro, basil, lime,etc ) for my fiance and i to share.  i asked if we could get a second dish so that we could each have the fixings, and this also took another 10 minutes to bring out, so our pho was tasteless and got even colder.

we went over to our favorite spot in oakland for pho the very next day, and it was SO much better it wasn't even funny.  superb broth, tons veggies in it, tons of tofu, tons of fixings, tons of sauce, and great super fast service.  all for 1/2 the price!

i give this place 6 more months, tops.
author: rockridge o.

description: Charles Phan has hit gold again, and this time its in Pacific Heights. Take a detour off the busy drag of Fillmore and a couple doors down on Bush you'll find the second location of Out the Door. It's much smaller and more intimate than either of it sister restaurants downtown, but still serving up those delicious concoctions with an Asian flare. The chicken clay pot was absolutely amazing, with a thick, flavorful sauce accompanying the tender chicken pieces perfectly. The rice soaked up the sauce and we were able to enjoy every last bite. Once again, Phan has also done a great job with vegetables, this time cooking up roasted corn that pops sweetness in your mouth and green beans that I could have eaten by the pound. The same old favorites remain, like the crispy imperial rolls and the shaking beef, but new additions are really great. Lastly, Phan has decided to go with the new fad of "wine on tap" and it's definitely worth a sip...or two. Now I can enjoy one of my favorite downtown spots in the heart of the Fillmore.
author: Rebecca D.

description: I live not far from OTD and try to get there for lunch at least a few times a month .  The food is very consistent and fresh, and the kitchen is extremely accommodating re reasonable requests (less spice, no nuts, etc.).  The wait staff is well trained, efficient, relaxed and professional.  (No, I don't work there.)  The managers are friendly and welcoming to regulars, patient with newcomers negotiating what might be an unfamiliar menu, and models of diplomacy when situations get sticky.  Hands down, this is my favorite place to eat on Fillmore Street.  If there were a suggestion box, however, I would recommend the following:  improve the wine list, especially the very weak and limited by-the-glass list.  The wines are okay (I'm trying to be nice) -- like wine brought to a book club -- but I think the quality overall is far below what the kitchen puts out.  Second complaint: -- and I'm hardly alone in saying this: the restaurant is offensively and stunningly loud, especially at peak hours.  There's not a soft surface (other than human bodies) in the place.  Metal, tile, steel, marble, wood...  I have friends who, when I say, Meet at OTD?, will say, No, let's go someplace where we can talk.  (Actually, talking is fine -- it's listening that's the problem.)  Related problem -- the banquette along the wall is metal and cold, cold, cold.  No cushions, no pillows.  Sure, people have more "padding" than they used to, but, even so, why not a little bit of man-made comfort?  I'm posting this message so that people will know that the food and service at OTD are stellar, the wine list weaker than it should be, and that maybe, if enough people feel similarly (and give feedback), someone high up in management will address the noise level and provide customers a bit more comfort -- in exchange for their continued patronage.
author: Tiny M.

description:
My wife  (Vietnamese) and I went to this  Vietnamese restaurant tonight  prompted by the understanding that it is an offshoot of Slanted Door, one of the most  popular and highly acclaimed restaurants in San Francisco.   We expected the best  having been to the Slanted Door many, many times, always with a very good outcome.  This is not what we found at OTD however.  It's extremely loud--like Slanted Door.
 But unlike SD, which  can be forgiven because the food and service qualities way overcome this negative, OTD was a total bust.  The Spring Rolls were, in fairness, acceptable as a starter, but the Melon soup was was extremely salty ( to encourage  drink sales?), the Shaking Beef was tasteless with several pieces being tough and others being close to rare and chewy, and the rice was extra dry and tasteless. The crowning disappointment was that the Imperial Rolls ("cha gio") a Vietnamese staple and delicacy were totally miserable. The shrimp and pork fillings were only half cooked and terrible tasting, not to mention a health hazard.  
Having reached this point, we decided that it would be good to let the the waiter know that there were some real issues with the food and make them aware of the what we had encountered. This with the objective of expecting him to provide feedback  to the chef, who surely would be interested in how his or her food was being (mis)prepared.  We were seated at the counter and our (very polite) sever called over a person who was apparently one of the restaurant managers. In the spirit of being helpful we explained the experience to the manager, a young man with a spiked mohawk.  To our surprise he immediately became defensive, and with regard to the undercooked fillings for the Imperial Rolls, stated that  he personally had several years of experience making  these rolls and that they were always properly cooked. He stronglypointed out that we were wrong with our findings.  So much for constructive comments. At that point my wife, who is  a gourmet and an excellent Vietnamese cook, and I simply looked at him in amazement, realizing that any further conversation would be futile.
Hopefully for the new restaurant, this was a one-off occurrence and not something you will encounter.  However, based on our experience we are doubtful and this is definitely not a place we would recommend.  With all the choices in SF, it is not a restaurant we will visit again. We suggest you don't waste your time and money
author: K Michael F.

description: The lunch I tried to eat here recently was bar none the worst restaurant meal I have been served in years.  The iced tea tasted like the Wildroot hair tonic my father used to use.  The "bavette" steak comprised three small pieces of beef surrounded by french fries drowned in gravy--that's right, french fries in gravy.  We sent the tea back, of course, and then they tried to charge us for it.  I have had a number of takeout meals from the OTD at Ferry Plaza, and only rarely have they risen above mediocrity.  The famous Slanted Door itself is an intolerable environment, a complete assault on the eardrums, and better Vietnamese food can be had at almost any other Vietnamese restaurant in the city.  The whole outfit, in my view, is a fraud.
author: Francesco D.

description: LOVED this place.  First, the tiny lady running the place has the most pleasing personality. She makes you feel like she is welcoming you home.  And, she has eyes in the back of her head as you can see that while engaged in conversation with you -- she also has a bead on EVERYTHING going on in the place. Employees beware!  The food was good. We sampled through the menu and will surely be back.
author: Valerie P.

description: On principle I do not like going to Slanted Door/Out the Door because I'm Vietnamese and I ate this stuff growing up and let me tell you, it did NOT cost $8 for a banh mi sandwich. That stuff goes for $1.50 in downtown San Jose. I've become a fan of Out the Door though based on it's other offerings, namely the chicken rice porridge which I grew up eating but rarely make at home because I don't want to invest the time to wait for the rice to cook when I could just drive here and get it. I've also enjoyed some of their other dishes but it's the rice porridge that keeps me coming back, for those of you who enjoy rice porridge (aka congee and jook) OTD's is flavorful and light with lots of "Chinese donuts" and greens to fill out the flavor and add some interesting texture. It brings me right back to weekend mornings when I would enjoy a bowl before heading off to Kumon. Asian peeps you know what I'm talking about....
author: Cathy T.

description: I've been to this place 3 times. I take my guests here for lunch. The service has always been excellent. My favorite is the daikon rice cakes. Everyone I've taken and tried this dish has loved it. The pho (soups) have always been very good. I think lunch is the best bargain at this place. Also, the sauvignon blac for $4 a glass is also a bargain. I am glad OTD opened in this neighborhood near where I live. I've never gone here for dinner so my rating is specifically for lunch.
author: A M G.

description: I admit, I have gone back, just because it is in my neighborhood.  I find that the noodles, available at breakfast and lunch only, is not bad.  Although be careful of the spiced chicken vermicelli, the sauce you pour over it pacts some heat.  You can get it without the crazy chili seeds in the sauce and it makes it more editable.
author: sandy s.

description: Good food but portions are too small for the price!
author: Cardinal S.

description:
Ate here three times last weekend!
Saturday we had brunch. Were seated at the long communal table up front.  Great spot for people watching on the street and the light coming in from outside.  Well decorated in simple, yet earth highlighting tones and materials.  The flowers on the tables and through the restaurant were small, yet unique and elegant at the same time and lended a touch of color to the room. Four of us had the vietnamese coffee and beignets, which was reminiscent of the Cafe Du Monde in New Orleans.  The coffee could have been a tad stronger, but mostly good.  Having just been in NOLA two weeks ago, and missing it already, this is just what we needed.  Two ordered the soft scrambled eggs with dungeness and chives - incredible!  Light fluffy eggs, perfect crab, hint of chives, crunchy hot mini baguette, only thing missing is the potato side that normally fills the plate at most places.  To be honest, we didn't really miss it much.  One had the slow cooked eggs with the Niman Ranch brisket.  Loved it!  Souvied eggs over tender beef brisket hash with a crunchy hot baguette.  If you love hash, you must try this.  We had the Strawberry and Chantilly Cream Pancakes together as breakfast-dessert.  Excellent!  Very small, but very, very good.
Saturday Dinner was our next meal.  We ordered to go for 11 people a half hour before we needed it.  This is not recommened, however, they pulled it off  no problem.   We had discussed the vegan options on the menu with them earlier and had ordered half vegan dishes and half meat.  It was a huge hit!  One of the few times our vegan friends were able to have a full plate of food from take out.  Two of them even tried some new things!  We had both imperial rolls and spring rolls, papaya salad, jicama and grapefruit salad, daikon rice cakes, dungeness with cellophane noodles, stir fry gulf prawns, day boat scallops, shaking beef and some other things.  Everyone loved it.
Sunday - we made it in time for brunch.  New orders were the fried eggs and ham and the banh mi pork xiu mai.  All hits.  
Excellent, personable service from Marianna and Gus, and Valerie handled the take out order with ease.
author: Monica S.

description: I basically only come here for the beef Pho, and that's really all they need to cement their reputation with me.  The beef is tender, the broth rich, and the price is just a buck or two over the not so well appointed places in the tenderloin....their pho is proof that great, authentic pho doesn't have to come from a downscale neighborhood....although some of my favorite pho's can be found on Larkin street.
author: Dat P.

description: Went here for lunch.  Love the set up and decor.  We had the five spice duck confit/noodle soup and the shrimp/noodle dish, along with beignets for dessert.  Both the duck confit and shrimp/noodle dishes were tasty, the soup was yummy.  However nothing special esp for the price, and compared with a good Vietnamese place.  The beignets are just ok, esp compared with what you get 2000 miles away in New Orleans.   The center was soft, and had the consistency of scrambled eggs.
author: Paul C.

description: EVERYTHING we ordered was perfect and pleasantly surprising!  The papaya salad was superb....iight and a pleasant way to start our meal. We had a small dish of sauteed greens and also the daikon rice cake next. Both were absolutely wonderful but I have to say the daikon was superb. I've never had anything like it. Being with someone who loves pork, we tried the pork meatballs with sprouts and greens on the side. Uuummmmm! I love the atmosphere, the modern and clean decor and the variety of seating arrangements so that singles as well as larger parties can be accommodated. I watched it being prepared for its opening for so long that I am glad to say it was worth the wait. Will go back as often as i can!!!  Soup next time!
author: P G.

description: Horrible. Slighted same menus as Slanted Door. Horrible bland food.
author: yong h.

description: I came here with my boyfriend last night. He is a big fan of the "Out the Door" in the Ferry building where you can take togo kits to fix your own food at home. We tried to come to this location before but couldn't find it. It is off of Fillmore on Bush Street, you have to walk a ways down Bush to find it. It is located on a residential block with no restaurants or retailers located near it. We both were suprised when we showed up at 8:30pm and there weren't any open tables. We waited only about 10 minutes for a table. We started off with the crispy imperial rolls which were perfect! Then we shared the Shaking Beef, his long time fave and now I am a big fan. We also got the scallops, they were cooked perfectly but neither of us cared for the sauce they were in. I definitley will come here again when I want to get away from the regular scene on Fillmore.
author: Sarah R.

description:
LOUD, extremely uncomfortable environment (metal bar stools, even at the 'communal table) and less-than-enthusiastic (verging on downright unpleasant) service have reminded me, for the 3rd and final time, that this is not a restaurant I care to patronize in my neighborhood.  
Having been a fan of the Slanted Door since the early days in the Mission, when the food, ambiance and service made for an always great night out, the brand has lost much of its allure by over-extending its reach.  
I was alone on a Tuesday pm, sat at the empty bar (which offers a good view of the entire dining room and open kitchen) and ordered the fried calamari with chilies and pineapple, which I had previously enjoyed very much.  When it arrived, I felt it needed a kick (it tasted more fried than spicy) and attempted, discretely, to get my server/bartender's attention (she was standing across the bar, chatting) to no avail, until a customer seated near her noticed me and nudged her to come over.  I requested a  couple of wedges of lemon and  she returned with 3 slivers (from the bar); I asked, politely, if I could have  wedges instead and she looked at me like she was just 'oh so bothered' and said she'd see if the kitchen could do that ?!?  She then returned with a whole lemon, cut in half...
For the rest of my meal (I ordered the standard spring rolls to follow) she was surly (as if trying to get her attention had totally offended her sensibilities). As I exited the restaurant there was no one at the door to say 'thank you', nor was it ever apparent that a manager was in charge and cared, even remotely, about the experience the diners were having.  The staff, I had observed in my previous visits, all seem oddly unhappy, and brusque - as if they were the stepchildren of the employees at the Ferry building who clearly make bank nightly.  Something is truly remiss at this location.
There are many restaurants on Fillmore, a half a block away, that I will choose to patronize instead and since OTD is around the corner on an otherwise unpopulated strip of Bush Street, it'll be easy to forget it exists.
author: heather D.

description: I like this place. I think the ambience is great, and the beer and wine options are really interesting. The food is yummy, too. I guess my main disappointment is with the menu options and pricing, especially for a restaurant opening in this economic climate. The dinner menu is fine (love the oh-so-Slanted Door spring rolls and shaking beef), but the portions are miniscule and overpriced (oh-so-Slanted Door as well). The lunch menu is way too stodgy and steep. What about the fun, affordable Vietnamese sandwiches offered by the other OTD? Please evolve. Please?
author: Midori S.

description: Great food, but horrible service! The hostess didn't seem to have a clue about what she was doing. The waiter didn't take our order for about 30 minutes till we asked. The restaurant was 1/2 full. And no-one had a smile on their face.
author: jennifer c.

description: I have been to this restaurant on 3 occassions.  The food was very tasty and the combinations were unique and interesting.  The atmosphere is very nice although I would call it more of a lunch spot than dinner although dinner is also great.  The service has been pretty good as well.
author: D G.

description: We had the most amazing meal at OTD- the shrimp appetizer was fantastic, the cod succulent, spinach perfectly spiced -- and the basil ice cream dessert truly memorable....service was very friendly and efficient - overall a great experience and more intimate for sure than the main restaurant at the Embarcadero.
author: Emily O.

description: Delish. Loud noisy fun place... Tasty food. Love the Chicken claypot and the spring rolls. Perfect for a group of six or less. One of my favorites in SF. Always bring a newbie here to enjoy the food.
author: Jean D.

description: i have been to both, out the door on market street, and to slanted door. this location is placed food wise in between the two. initially i was expecting something like market place out the door. the food we had was neither new or very exciting to both of us. in fact we've been surprised how little food we got for our money. so i disagree with earlier reviews that this has an affordable price tag. if you want affordable food visit the market street location. better and more food for far less money. fancy little portions of normal food at a high price here.
author: Sven P.

description: I went to the Slanted Door last night for my one year anniversary and it was such a wonderful restaurant.  It was a bit noisy but that was part of the appeal.  The food was excellent.  We had cubed filet mignon, carmelized prawns, imperial rolls, and one of the best mojitos I've ever had.  The view  and atmosphere was wonderful. I will definitely go there again and I highly recommend the Slanted Door.
author: nicole r.

description: we've eaten here for brunch and dinner and have had a good meal both times...the soft scrambled eggs with dungeness crab and magi was delish, although SUPER small portion...we also tried the beneighs(basically doughnut holes), which were yummy...we went back for lunch a few weeks later, had the same server(who remembered us..big bonus points :)for lunch we had the egg rolls, daikon cakes, and rainbow trout(i think that was the fish!) the egg rolls are OK...my baby makes the best ever so every other egg roll has stiff competition.  the daikon cake was good too, but i am still on the fence about the texture.  the trout, on the other hand was spectacular!  definitely some of the best seafood i've ever had at a restaurant.  the filet was perfectly cooked,sitting a a little 'soy  sauce like' broth, and topped with shaved watermelon radish and fennel. YUMMY!
author: lc m.
